Name of case: United States of America v. Shane Leedon Jenkins
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:641 - Theft of government property; 18:1361 - Destruction of Government Property; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Additional details: Resident of TX; Defendant remains committed
Short narrative: Shane Leedon Jenkins was arrested and charged with 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:641 - Theft of government property; 18:1361 - Destruction of Government Property; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building following his involvement in the January 6th, 2021 Capitol insurrection. Jenkins pleaded not guilty, and sentencing details are pending. "Federal agents located a video showing Jenkins remove a metal survival hatchet from a backpack, put on black gloves and smash a window to the left of the Lower West Terrace tunnel, according to court records. The window repair cost roughly $1,500, officials said. Security and body-worn camera footage shows Jenkins throw a pole, a desk drawer, a metal rod and flagpole at a group of Metropolitan Police Department and U.S. Capitol Police officers, striking some of them in the head as they attempted to prevent the crowd from infiltrating a tunnel, court documents allege."- Houston Chronicle
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Releases, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Weeks & Carlton
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Released on conditions; "Bradley Weeks, 44, of Macclenny, Florida was found guilty of five charges in total, including one felony. The verdict followed a bench trial before U.S. District Judge Thomas F. Hogan. Weeks was found guilty of obstruction of an official proceeding, a felony; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a capitol building; parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building."
Short narrative: On March 24th, 2021, Jonathan Daniel Carlton and Bradley Wayne Weeks were indicted after they traveled to D.C. together to attend Trump's speech and both participated in the ensuing riot. Carlton and Weeks were inititally charged separately, however later were indicted together. Weeks was charged with Obstruction of an official proceeding; Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; Disorderly conduct in a capitol building; and Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building, and his sentencing is pending.
Source description: Court Documents, Local News Articles, Charging documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Ronnie Brian Presley
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; *18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a capitol building; *40:5104(e)(2)(E) Impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Additional details: Resident of TN; "Sentenced 11/30/22 to 12 months of incarceration, 26 months of supervised release, $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative: Ronnie Brian Presley, 42 of Tennessee, pled guilty to civil disorder and was sentenced to 12 months of prison for his role in the January 6 Capitol riot. He was identified by videos posted on social media where he announced himself by his name and home state. He appears to be grabbing a police officer's shield in one of the pictures. He also physically confronted a law enforcement officer by leaning into the officer’s baton, which the officer was holding and using in an attempt to push the defendant toward the exit.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Troy E. Sargent
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Additional details: Resident of MA; "sentenced 12/12/22 in the District of Columbia to 14 months in prison for felony charges of assaulting, resisting, or impeding officers during the breach of the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, civil disorder, and four related misdemeanor offenses. In addition to the term of incarceration, he was ordered to complete two years of supervised release and to pay $500 restitution and a $285 special assessment."
Short narrative: "The Justice Department's case against Troy Sargent began after the government received tips from multiple members of the public who allegedly told the FBI that they recognized Sargent from photos and videos from the Capitol on Jan. 6. One witness allegedly told investigators that Sargent is known for participating in rallies in the Pittsfield, Mass., area, and that he posted on Facebook ahead of the Jan. 6 Trump rally: "I ain't missing this." Federal prosecutors say that Sargent is visible in footage from police body cameras on Jan. 6. At one point, according to court documents, Sargent "appears to throw a punch with his right hand at a police officer, inadvertently strikes another member of the crowd, and then retreats back into the crowd." At another point, "Sargent approaches the front of the crowd of rioters, confronts the line of police officers attempting to hold the crowd back, and physically engages with one of the officers with his right hand while holding what appears to be a cell phone in his left hand."" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, News articles, Governmental reports and release

Name of case: United States of America v. Mark K. Ponder
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; *18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; *18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; *18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of D.C.; "Sentenced 7/26/22 to 63 months in prison, three years of supervised release, $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative: Mark K. Ponder, 55 of DC, pled guilty to Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and was sentenced to 63 months in prison. He was recorded on open source video and body cam footage participating in the Capitol riots and attacking U.S. Capitol Police Sgt. Aquilino Gonell with a pole. The officer sustained injuries such as a shattered foot and shoulder injuries. He has previously been charged with robbing a bank, stealing a car, and domestic assault.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Jeremy J. Vorous
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) and (2) Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) and (G) Violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; 18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of any official proceeding
Additional details: Resident of PA
Short narrative: "Jeremy J. Vorous of Venango has been charged with knowingly entering or remaining in a restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol Grounds; and obstruction of any official proceeding...According to the 12-page affidavit filed by FBI Agent Peter Wall against Vorous, Vorous gained entry inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6. The FBI received two tips which included screenshots of Vorous’ Facebook page where Vorous wrote “Yeah we in dis mofo” and “Bout to rush in again diff door.” Vorous’ Facebook page also included photos taken of the riot, including inside the U.S. Capitol...Vorous posted on Facebook a photo showing himself in the “Capitol Crypt in front of the bust of Abraham Lincoln saying ‘does that look staged to you I promise the beanbags were real the mase is still burning on me aft a shower and 6hrs, the gas was real the flash grenades were also real the dead girl was 10ft from me’.” Vorous also is depicted in the photo wearing a dark long-sleeved shirt with “Not Today Liberal” in white letters and holding a red, white and blue cowboy-style hat, the affidavit said. According to the affidavit, “Vorous also posted to Facebook a photo showing himself in front of a statute with the caption ‘We will take what we want' which the FBI obtained from an online tip by an identified individual.” “In the photo, Vorous is depicted wearing the same clothing as in Figure One,” the affidavit said. “The statute Vorous poses in front of is the statue of John Caldwell Calhoun of South Carolina, which is also located in the Crypt of the Capitol.” The affidavit said, “Vorous also posted messages on Facebook talking about the ‘coordination’ of the attack on the Capitol, as well as the fact that ‘we took’ the Capitol Building, which your affiant obtained from an anonymous online tip to the FBI.” The affidavit said the FBI reviewed a recording from the FBI’s National Threat Operations Center that Vorous made to the FBI Jan. 10. “In that recording, Vorous called to report that he was in the U.S. Capitol building on January 6, 2021,” The affidavit said. “He said he was in the building and went to the Capitol Police the next day to report himself. Vorous said that he absolutely did not participate in the rioting or take anything.” The affidavit said there were at two separate YouTube videos of Vorous being interviewed during the riot, and the FBI “was able to review footage from the Capitol that shows Vorous in the Crypt area of the U.S. Capitol building. The footage shows Vorous walking around inside the Capitol.” In addition, the affidavit said footage showed Vorous entering the U.S. Capitol building. Also, the FBI said it “learned from separate sources that at the time of his (Vorous’) entry, loud audible alarms were going off in the area and the windows adjacent to point of entry were broken out.” (Medville Tribune)
Source description: Local News, Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Russell Dean Alford
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent Entry and Disorderly COnduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Hokes Bluff, AL; Indicted via Information sheet; "Found guilty 10/5/22 by a jury of entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building."
Short narrative: In 2021, Russell Dean Alford, 60, of Hokes Bluff, AL, was charged with entering and remaining in a restricted building, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building, and violent entry and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building for his role in the Jan. 6th riot. Alford posted videos of his participation in the riot on his Facebook and personal YouTube page. "I wondered when y’all were going to show up. Guess you’ve seen the videos on my Facebook page,” Russell Alford said when FBI agents went to his house to detain him, according to court documents.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, News article

Name of case: United States of America v. Bryan Wayne Ivey
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Indicted by Bill of information; Sentenced 3/30/22, to three years of probation, including 60 days of home detention, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: "The Department of Justice says a "close contact" of Bryan Wayne Ivey contacted investigators in late January after recognizing him in photos from the Capitol riot, wearing a brown jacket, brown hat and sunglasses. The witness allegedly told investigators that Ivey also admitted entering the Capitol that day. Federal prosecutors say Ivey can also be seen in surveillance footage from inside the Capitol on Jan. 6 as he "attempts to assist others in entering the building." The FBI arrested Ivey on March 4 in Cookeville, Tenn." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Jeffrey Mckellop
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers [4 counts]; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon [2 counts]; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Additional details: Resident of Augusta, VA; Retired US Army Special Forces and military contractor
Short narrative: In 2021, Jeffery A. McKellop, was charged with four counts of Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers, two counts of Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon, Civil Disorder, Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly Weapon, Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon, Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon, Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building, and Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building. McKellop is a military contractor working for the CIA and a retired Green Beret. Footage shows McKellop attacking several police officers, jabbing one officer in the face with a flagpole during the riot, and attempting to grab officers' pepper spray. McKellop served for 22 years and did two tours in Iraq and Afghanistan.
Source description: Charging documents, Court Documents, News article

Name of case: United States of America v. Sean Carlo Cordon
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) and (2) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) and (G) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds
Additional details: Brother also arrested; Identified after appearing on Finnish TV, indicted by bill of information; Sentenced to 2 months’ probation, $4000 fine
Short narrative: Brothers Kevin Francisco Cordon, 33, and Sean Carlo Cordon, 35, of California, have both been charged following their participation in the Capitol riot. The Cordon brothers were identified after they were seen in a video posted on a Finnish news site. While they were on the same criminal complaint, they were later seperated and given their own information/indictment. Sean Cordon has accepted a plea deal, pleading guilty to parading, demonstraining, or picketing in the Capitol building in order to get the rest of the charges dropped.
Source description: Charging Documents, National News

A pretrial investigation showed two misdemeanor convictions in Schornak’s past and a dismissed charge of felony ethnic intimidation.

Name of case: United States of America v. Cleveland Grover Meredith, Jr.
Charges: 18:875(c) Interstate Communication of Threats; *D.C. Code 7:2502.01(a) Possession of Unregistered Firearms; D.C. Code 7:2506.01(a)(3) Possession of Unregistered Ammunition; *D.C. Code 7:2506.01(b) Possession of Large Capacity Ammunition Feeding Devices
Additional details: Expressed support for QAnon; Charged under DC and federal statutes; From Atlanta, Georgia; Sentenced to Twenty Eight (28) months incarceration, with credit for time already served, followed by Thirty Six (36) months of supervised release. Special Assessment of $100.00 was imposed.
Short narrative: In 20201, Cleveland Grover Meredith Jr., 52, of Atlanta, Georgia, was charged with interstate communication of threats, possession of unregistered firearms (DC code), possession of unregistered ammunition (DC code), and possession of large capacity ammunition feeding devices (DC code) for his role in the Jan. 6th riot. Meredith was charged after threatening Nancy Pelosi, sending a text message saying he would put “a bullet in her noggin on Live TV”. Meredith had a variety of firearms with him in D.C. as well. Meredith has expressed support for QAnon.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles, Local News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Ethan C. Seitz
Physical target: Federal site: non-U.S. embassy or consulate
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: From Bucyrus, OH
Short narrative: Ethan C. Seitz, 31, of Bucyrus, OH, was charged with Obstruction of an Official Proceeding, Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds,v Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building, and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Buildingfor his role in the Jan. 6th riot. Seitz was identified via tips provided to the FBI as well as Facebook posts made by Seitz, Capitol security footage, and a YouTube video interview of Seitz in which he describes his experience and motivation. "I did storm the f***** capitol and climb in through a window. Got gassed and pepper sprayed. Flash bombs thrown at me. And f***** rubber bullets shot at me" (statement of facts). Seitz states that he took part in the riot because of "election integrity".
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Local news articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Johnny Harris
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) and (2) Entering and remaining in a restricted building and disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent entry and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Shelby, NC; Indicted by Bill of Information
Short narrative: Johnny Harris, 56, of Shelby, NC was charged with Entering and remaining in a restricted building, Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building, Violent entry and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building for his involvement in the January 6, 2021 U.S. Capital riot. Harris's involvement is chronicled in the documentary, “January 6th,” which places him at the scene of the riot. "A law enforcement filing in federal court alleges that Johnny Harris posted photos of himself from inside the Capitol during the insurrection. Investigators tracked him down after an anonymous tipster flagged photos that Harris had allegedly posted on his Facebook page. In four photos gathered by investigators, including from body camera and security camera footage from inside the Capitol, Harris can be seen holding a flag inside the Capitol rotunda. According to prosecutors, two individuals who traveled with Harris to Washington, D.C., identified Harris as the individual pictured in several photos apparently taken inside the Capitol." (NPR). Harris has pled not guilty and this case is currently pending.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Michael Lee Hardin
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Former police officer from Salt Lake City; Indicted by Bill of Information; Pled guilty one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentencing set for 4/11/2022
Short narrative: Michael Lee Hardin, 50, was a former Salt Lake City Police Officer until his retirement in 2017. He served for about 2 decades and was named the department's Officer of the Year in 2012 for solving a 25-year-old murder case. FBI caught Hardin becuase of two tipsters who knew him and called the FBI hotline. He was not detained but was asked to give up his passport as well as temporarily give his firearms to a friend or family member.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Mark Roger Rebegila
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of St Marys, KS; charged by Bill of Information; Sentenced 4/20/2022 to 24 months of probation, including 30 days home detention, 60 hours of community service, $2,000 fine, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: Mark Roger Rebegila, 31 of Kansas, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building and was sentenced to 24 months probation and community service. He sat in a lawmaker's chair and stole a bottle of liquor while taking part in the Jan. 6 riot inside the U.S. Capitol.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Sherrill, Bishai & Irizarry
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Remains on release; Cadet in a Civil Air Patrol Unit; Indicted by Bill of Information; "Sentenced 7/29/22 to 14 days in jail, followed by 12 months of supervised release, $500 restitution."

Several witnesses identified Bishai and Irizarry in wanted posters published by the FBI, one of which made the identification due to the familiarity of being in the same Civil Air Patrol Unit, an official civilian auxiliary of the US Air Force.Irizarry is a current freshman and cadet at The Citadel. Bishae and Irizarry were charged with knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority, knowingly engaging in disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds, and violent entry and sisorderly conduct on Capitol grounds.

Name of case: United States of America v. Scott Kevin Fairlamb
Charges: 18:111(a)(1); ASSAULTING/RESISTING/IMPEDING OFFICERS/EMPLOYEES; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18 U.S.C. 1512(c)(2) and 2; TAMPERING WITH A WITNESS, VICTIM OR INFORMANT; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; *18 U.S.C. 231(a)(3); CIVIL DISORDER; * 18 U.S.C. 1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A); TEMPORARY RESIDENCE OF THE PRESIDENT; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *18 U.S.C. 1752(a)(2); TEMPORARY RESIDENCE OF THE PRESIDENT; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18 U.S.C. 1752(a)(3); TEMPORARY RESIDENCE OF THE PRESIDENT; Impeding Ingress and Egress in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18 U.S.C. 1752(a)(4); TEMPORARY RESIDENCE OF THE PRESIDENT; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D); VIOLENT ENTRY AND DISORDERLY CONDUCT ON CAPITOL GROUNDS; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40 U.S.C. 5104(e)(2)(E); FEDERAL STATUTES, OTHER; Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; *40 U.S.C. 5104(e)(2)(F); FEDERAL STATUTES, OTHER; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; *40 U.S.C. 5104(e)(2)(G); FEDERAL STATUTES, OTHER; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; *40 U.S.C. 5104(d); FEDERAL STATUTES, OTHER; Stepping, Climbing, Removing, or Injuring Property on the Capital Grounds
Additional details: Resident of New Jersey; QAnon supporter; 36 months supervised release, $2000 restitution
Short narrative: Scott Kevin Fairlamb, 44, from New Jersey, was charged for his role in the Jan. 6th Capitol riot after four concerned citizens submitted footage to the FBI of Fairlamb participating and verbally confirming his participation in the riot. Fairlamb was additionally identified in a video shoving and punching an officer. He traveled to Washington on Jan. 6 to attend the “Stop the Steal” rally. Fairlamb was part of a large crowd that forcibly pushed through a line of police officers and metal barricades. He obtained a collapsible police baton from the ground and posted a video to Facebook displaying the baton which he later hit police with. In the video he said, “What Patriots do? We f****** disarm them and then we storm the f****** Capitol.” Fairlamb pleaded guilty to counts two and three of the superseding indictment that charged him with obstruction of an official proceeding and assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers. The ex-MMA fighter Scott Fairlamb was sentenced to approximately three and a half years in prison and three years probation for assaulting an officer while he was part of the violent mob that stormed the U.S. Capitol on January 6 in support of former President Trump. He was the first person to be sentenced in the Capitol cases.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News, Governmental Reports and Release

The cousins were identified via videos posted to social media taken from inside the Capitol building as well as numerous comments on social media boasting about their participation in the riot, and a tip provided to the FBI.

Name of case: United States of America v. Damon Michael Beckley

Additional details: Changed plea from Not Guilty: Blind Plea, to No Contest, back to Not Guilty: Blind Plea

As of 4/14/21, Beckley again changed his plea to not guilty. This case is currently pending.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local news articles, Governmental reports and releases (DOJ)

Name of case: United States of America v. Jeffrey Alexander Smith
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(D) and (G) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol building; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building
Additional details: Indicted by Bill of Information; Sentenced 3/15/22, 90 days of incarceration, 2 years of probation, $500 in restitution, 200 hours of community service.
Short narrative: "Following the events on January 6, 2021, the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) received tips at the FBI National Threat Operations Center (NTOC) from individuals who reported that they identified JEFFREY ALEXANDER SMITH, aka ALEX SMITH, as being involved in the events at the Capitol. On January 7, 2021, one individual (“Witness-1”) who identified themselves and who has known SMITH for an extended period of time had discovered a photo of SMITH inside the Capitol on social media which had been posted to Instagram by @homegrownterrorists. The photo depicts SMITH wearing a black jacket and a Trump hat, with a red cell phone in his right hand which is raised in the air. On January 8, 2021, a tip was received by the FBI Tipline from an individual (“Witness- 2”) who grew up with SMITH in Coronado, California, and who texted with SMITH via Instagram after the riots. Witness-2 provided screen shots of the messages which included SMITH writing, “I’m a Patriot”, “I stormed the capital” (sic). In the text, SMITH stated that his purpose was “To send a message that Americans are[n’] t going to take a fraudulent election.” SMITH also wrote to Witness-2, “There is no way in hell I was going to drive 38 hours from San Diego and not walk right through the front of the capital (sic) building.” Witness-2 also observed that SMITH had since deleted his Instagram account...SMITH told the [FBI] agent that he drove 38 hours to Washington, DC, to attend the speech by President Trump on January 6, 2021. SMITH said that his girlfriend traveled by air and met him in Washington, D.C. SMITH told his girlfriend to remain at the hotel instead of getting into all the chaos at the U.S. Capitol. SMITH also identified the hotel he stayed at in Washington, D.C. SMITH admitted that when he approached the U.S. Capitol it was a chaotic scene. He heard people on loudspeakers, he saw tear gas, and heard what he thought were flash bangs going off. SMITH admitted he walked into the Capitol on January 6, 2021 and remained in the Capitol for about 30 minutes. SMITH admitted to deleting his Instagram account after he began receiving threats related to his involvement in the Capitol events." (DOJ Statement of Facts) Smith was an Army Sergeant and was seen moving the bench barricades from the rotunda doors.
Source description: Charging Documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Douglas Austin Jensen
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds With a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Des Moines, Iowa; Expressed support for QAnon; "Found guilty 9/23/22 of all seven counts. These include five felony offenses: assaulting, resisting, or impeding a law enforcement officer, obstruction of an official proceeding, interfering with a law enforcement officer during a civil disorder, entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a dangerous weapon, and disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a dangerous weapon. They also include misdemeanor offenses of disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building."
Short narrative: Douglas Austin Jensen, 41, of Des Moines, Iowa, was charged with Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds With a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following his participation in the Capitol riot. Jensen has been identified as taking part in the Capitol siege after Jensen truned himself in to local law enforcement. Jensen led a crowd of rioters into the Capitol and was seen chasing a Capitol officer up the stairs in videos taken from inside the Capitol. Jensen has expressed support for QAnon saying that he wanted to be one of the first individuals in the Capitol "because he was wearing his 'Q' t-shirt and he wanted to have his t-shirt seen on video so that “Q” could 'get the credit'." (affidavit). Jensen originally pled not quilty to all counts, but now has taken a plea deal, intending to plea guilty to aggrevated felony.
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, News articles, Local news articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Sibick, Head, & Young
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding and Aiding and abetting; 18:231(a)(3) Civil disorder [2 counts]; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers [2 counts]; 18:2111 Robbery; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(3) Impeding ingress and egress in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(E) Impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physcial violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings
Additional details: Residsent of Redsfield, IA; "Sentenced 9/27/22 to 86 months in prison, three years of supervised release, $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative: "Albuquerque Cosper Head, 41, of Kingsport, Tennessee; Kyle James Young, 37, of Redfield, Iowa; and Thomas Sibick, 35, of Buffalo, New York, were indicted on charges related to their assault of Metropolitan Police Department (MPD) Officer Michael Fanone, as well as other crimes, committed during the breach. All are charged with obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; civil disorder; assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct on restricted building or grounds; impeding ingress and egress in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence on restricted building or grounds; impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings; and acts of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings. Sibick is charged with an additional count of robbery; Head is charged with an additional count of civil disorder; and Young is charged with additional counts of civil disorder, assault on an officer, and robbery." (DOJ Press release)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Local news articles

Additional details: Resident of Kingsport, TN; "Sentenced 10/27/22 to 90 months in prison, three years of supervised release, restitution to be determined later by the Court."
Short narrative: "Albuquerque Cosper Head, 41, of Kingsport, Tennessee; Kyle James Young, 37, of Redfield, Iowa; and Thomas Sibick, 35, of Buffalo, New York, were indicted on charges related to their assault of Metropolitan Police Department (MPD) Officer Michael Fanone, as well as other crimes, committed during the breach. All are charged with obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; civil disorder; assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct on restricted building or grounds; impeding ingress and egress in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence on restricted building or grounds; impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings; and acts of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings. Sibick is charged with an additional count of robbery; Head is charged with an additional count of civil disorder; and Young is charged with additional counts of civil disorder, assault on an officer, and robbery." (DOJ Press release)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Christopher Worrell
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon;
Additional details: Resident of FL; trial date set for 2/13/2023
Short narrative: Christopher Worrell, 49, of FL, was charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; Civil Disorder; and Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; for his participation in the January 6th Capitol riot. Worrell is a member of Proud Boys. Worrell was seen on camera spraying pepper spray gel into the crowd at the riot. Worrell has pled not guilty. This case is currently still pending.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Jeffrey Grace
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of WA; Indicted by Bill of Information; Pleaded guilty in April 2022 to one count of entering and remaining in a restricted builing or grounds
Short narrative: Jeffrey Grace, 61, was charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for his role in the January 6th riot. Grace admitted to traveling to DC and entering the Capitol building amidst the raid. A tipster provided this information to the FBI and was verified by photographs taken by others inside the Capitol as well as Grace's own admission. His son, Jeremy Grace, was also arrested in the Capitol protests. Grace has pled not guilty and the case is currently pending.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Mariposa Castro
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of CA; Indicted by Bill of Information; Sentenced 2/23/22 to 45 days in jail, $5,000 fine.
Short narrative: Bay area yoga studio owner, Mariposa Castro, from Gilroy, CA, was charged with two misdemeanors in connection with the Jan. 6 Capitol protests. She entered the Capitol through a smashed window and recorded her participation on video shared on Facebook.
Source description: Charging documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Stephen Ethan Horn
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Raleigh, NC; Indicted via Bill of Information
Short narrative: Stephen Ethan Horn, 23 has been arrested and charged with his role in the January 2021 Capitol protests. Horn claims he was there as a journalist to document what was happening. "FBI agents say Horn walked over a fence on the ground with a “No trespassing” sign before walking into the Capitol building during the attack and making his way to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s office" (Spectrum News 1) and was heard chanting U.S.A. on a video posted to his Facebook page.  In a post on his personal Facebook page, Horn wrote, “I did not enter the capitol building as part of the protest, or for cheap thrills, but to accurately document and record a significant event that was taking place.” (WBTV). The FBI became aware of Horn after being notified by an individual who has known Horn for years after seeing a picture of Horn on a NY Times Magazine social media page. Horn has pled not guity and this case is currently pending.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. John Clarence Wilkerson
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Indicted by Bill of Information; Resident of MD; "Defendant is sentenced to a term of 36 months (3 years) of Probation as to Count 4 of the Information. The Defendant is further sentenced to pay a $10 special assessment, a fine of $2,500 and to perform 60 hours of community service. The Government's oral motion to dismiss the remaining counts (1-3) of the Information is GRANTED."
Short narrative: John Wilkerson has been identified by tipsters that said he attended the Capitol protests in January, 2021. He is from Maryland. "A person who knew John Clarence Wilkerson IV from a decade earlier but still followed him on social media turned him in to the FBI. That person called the FBI after seeing a photo of Wilkerson at a bar on Jan. 6 with the caption "today was a good day, we got inside the Capitol," according to court documents. Wilkerson also allegedly said he wouldn't be posting photos or videos from inside the U.S. Capitol “for obvious reasons.” According to court documents, Wilkerson lives on a boat in Maryland." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Jason Riddle
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 18:641 - Theft of government property; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of NH; US army Reserves Motor Transport Operator 2011-2016; Indicted by Bill of Information; Sentenced 4/4/22, 90 days in jail, followed by three years of probation, including 60 hours of community service, restitution of $754.
Short narrative: Jason Riddle, 32, has been arrested and charged for this role in the Capitol protests on January 6th, 2021. When he arrived to the Capitol, he drank a glass of wine from a bottle he found in a refrigerator in the Office of the Senate Parliamentarian and took a selfie with the bottle. He stated in a later interview that he was a military veteran. While Riddle was in the Capitol, he told the FBI he took two things, a small FOX News football and an old-looking, reddish-brown leather book from the same office where he found the wine. He then sold the book outside the Capitol for $40. "At some point, Riddle tried to delete messages, photos and videos from his phone, but the FBI was able to recover the digital evidence and found a photo of the book, titled "Senate Procedure." (USA Today)
Source description: Charging documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Jason Douglas Owens
Charges: 18:111(a) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers or Employees; 18:231(a)(3) - Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(2), (a)(4), (b)(2) - Knowingly Entering or remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority, Knowingly Committing an Act of Physical Violence in any Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2) - Violent E entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds
Additional details: Resident of TX; Evidence from crowd-sourced Sedition Hunters used as evidence in Statement of Facts; Confirmed via geolocating cell phone and a Liscense Plate Reader
Short narrative: "The father of a Florida man charged with assaulting a D.C. police officer with a skateboard on Jan. 6 has also been arrested and accused of assaulting a cop before storming the Capitol. Jason Douglas Owens, a Texas resident, faces several charges, including assaulting an officer, for his role in the insurrection ... During the riots, Owens and his son were separated from their group and violently engaged D.C. police officers. Videos show Owens shoving at least one officer who had also been attacked by his son. Prosecutors allege Grady Owens, a 21-year-old Winter Park music student, hit the officer with a skateboard before entering the Capito;" - local news (Daily Beast)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Von Bernewitz & Von Bernewitz
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2); Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D); Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G); Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Released on recognizance; Brother also arrested; Charged by information;Von Bernewitz pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentencing set for 4/26/2022; Sentenced 4/26/22 to 24 months of probation, including 60 days home confinement, $500 restitution, $1,000 fine.
Short narrative: Brothers Eric V. Von Bernewitz, 46, and Paul H. Von Bernewitz, 50, both of Virginia, were charged with "18:752(a)(1) and 18:1752(a)(2) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) and 5104(e)(2)(G) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds following their participation in the Capitol riot. They were identified via a tip provided to the FBI and photos posted to FaceBook.
Source description: Local News, Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Von Bernewitz & Von Bernewitz
Additional details: Released on recognizance; Brother also arrested; Charged by information; Paul Von Bernewitz pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The other charges are dismissed. Sentenced 4/26/22 to 30 days in jail, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: Brothers Eric V. Von Bernewitz, 46, and Paul H. Von Bernewitz, 50, both of Virginia, were charged with "18:752(a)(1) and 18:1752(a)(2) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) and 5104(e)(2)(G) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds following their participation in the Capitol riot. They were identified via a tip provided to the FBI and photos posted to Facebook.

Name of case: United States of America v. Jon Schaffer
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of an Official proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1),(b)(1)(A) Entering and remaining in a restructed building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon
Additional details: Resident of Columbus, Indiana; Indicted by Bill of Information; Described by DOJ as "founding" member of the Oath Keepers
Short narrative: Jon Ryan Schaffer, 53, from Columbus, Indiana was charged with Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon following his participation in the Capitol riot where Schaffer sprayed "bear spray" at Capitol officers. Schaffer is a member of the Oath Keepers and has long held far-right opinions. Schaffer is also the founder of the heavy metal band "Iced Earth". Schaffer was the first person to enter a guilty plea in the Capitol riot investigation, and agreed to cooperate against others in the case.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Pezzola, Pepe & Greene
Charges: 18:731 Conspiracy; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding; 18:231(a)(3), 2 Civil Disorder; 18:1361, 2 Government property or contracts; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4), 2 Disorderly Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds
Additional details: Also facing three unrelated, state-level gun charges; Resident of Syracuse, NY
Short narrative: Matthew J. Greene, 33, of Syracuse, NY, and William Joseph Pepe, 31, of Beacon, NY were charged with Conspiracy, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding Abetting, Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting, Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting, Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds and Aiding and Abetting for their participation in the January 6th Capitol raid. Both Green and Pepe are memebers of Proud Boys and communicated with other Proud Boys memebrs prior to and during the Capitol raid. Additionally, Pepe posted a video of his presence inside the Capitol building, and Greene communicated via encrypted messaging channels confirming his participation. Greene initally pleaded not guilty, but later pleaded guilty per a plea bargain. The case is currently pending. [Note: Greene and Pepe were initially charged with Dominic Pezzola (A.K.A. Spazz, Spaz, Spazzo, Spazzolini; Case ID: 06062022_DP_4PROUDBOYS6), but Pezzola was removed from the case. Pezzola was named 3/7/22 in superseding indictment in new case, replacing 1:21-cr-52, and named again in a supersceding indictment 6/6/2022, having been added to the 4PROUDBOYS group case.)
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, Governmental reports and releases (DOJ), News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Wagner & Tutrow
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Facial tatoos; Indicted by Bill of Information; From Greenfield, Indiana; Sentenced to a term of Thirty Six (36) months of Probation. Special Assessment of $10.00 and Restitution in the amount of $500.00 were imposed.
Short narrative: High school classmates, Joshua Wagner and Israel David Tutrow, 22, both of Indiana have been charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Restricted Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following their participation in the Capitol riot. Wagner and Tutrow sent messages on Facebook messenger prior to the riot coordinating their arrival and during the riot. Wagner and Tutrow were identified via numerous photographs taken at the Capitol and through tips provided to the FBI.
Source description: Charging Documents; Court Docutments; Government report or release (DOJ), News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Russell James Peterson
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Indicted by Bill of Information; "Sentenced 12/1 to 30 days incarceration and $500 restitution."
Short narrative: "Peterson, 34 of Pennsylvania, streamed video live from inside the Capitol at least twice on Jan. 6, the FBI found through a search warrant issued for his Facebook account five days later. Court records state Peterson attended the rally with his mother, Shelly, and wife Elizabeth. A tipster reported to the FBI that Peterson's mother posted on Facebook that her son stormed the Capitol and 'sat in Pelosi's chair.'" (USA Today) Peterson pled guilty to one of the charges and was sentenced to 30 days.
Source description: Charging Document, Court Documents

Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Indicted by Bill of Information; Resident of Greenwood, IN; sentenced to 30 days, $500 restitution

Wagner and Tutrow sent messages on Facebook messenger prior to the riot coordinating their arrival and during the riot. Name of case: United States of America v. Kenneth Kelly
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Additional details: Resident of Florida; Family member told federal agents that Kelly "held extreme political views and had mentioned 'QAnon' a couple months before the January 6 riot." Charged by Bill of Information; "Sentenced 1/14/22 to 12 months of probation, including 60 days of home detention, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Kenneth Kelly, 58 of Florida, was identified as taking part in the Capitol riot via a tip provided to the FBI from a family member, CCTV footage from inside the Capitol building, and many photographs and texts sent from Kelly's personal phone throughout the incident. Kelly self-surrendered in the Middle District of Florida (Ocala, FL). He made his initial appearance and was released on a $25,000 unsecured bond.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Bennett & Williams
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(B) Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Expressed support for QAnon; Partner Elizabeth Rose Williams also arrested
Short narrative: Elizabeth Rose Williams and Brad Bennett were arrested and charged with knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct, and obstruction of an official proceeding after allegedly entering the US Capitol building during the January 6th insurrection. According to court documents, Williams and Bennett were seen on Capitol grounds and inside the building in security camera footage and social media posts that Bennett had posted onto Facebook.

Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(B) Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
