Name of case: United States of America v. Andrew Jackson Morgan
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Expressed support fort QAnon; From Maxwell, Texas
Short narrative: "Andrew Jackson Morgan Jr. came to the Jan. 6 rally wearing a press badge. He runs a YouTube channel called the Political Trato take over the building, saying, "I wnce Tribune, and he uploaded a video of the riot from both outside and inside the U.S. Capitol that day, court documents indicate. But unlike the journalists who were there, Morgan can be heard in his videos encouraging the mob ant my bullet! Give me my bullet! Give me my tear gas," as he reaches an entrance where a police standoff was occurring, according to court documents. In an interview with the FBI, Morgan said he traveled to Washington, D.C., because “something unprecedented” was going to happen. He said he was there as a "chameleon" and law enforcement "auditor" but now regrets yelling what he did, according to court documents. He told the FBI he is a QAnon follower and believes that those in power "use child pedophilia to control the masses."" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Shawn Bradley Witzemann
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly consudt in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Farmington, NM; Indicted by Bill of Information; Sentenced to 7 days in jail, ordered to serve two years probation, 60 hours of community service and pay a $500 restitution fee. (St. Louis Record)
Short narrative: Shawn Bradley Witzemann, 38 was charged for knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; and parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building for his participation in the January 6, 2021 Capital riot. According to the FBI who received a tip in containing a Facebook page link with a video that was taken on January 6, 2021 from inside the Capitol building. The video was posted to the Facebook page of The Armenian Council for Truth in Journalism by an Instagram user with the username “@krampusnatch.” which read “moments ago... Shawn was inside the capitol building!” Using open source information, the FBI was able to determine that SHAWN BRADLEY WITZEMANN was the registered Instagram user of “@krampusnatch.” Witzemann admitted to the FBI during an interivew to being inside of the Capitol building on January 6, 2021 after he traveled to Washington, D.C. on or about January 4, 2021. Witzemann pleaded guilty to count 4 - Parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building and was sentenced to 7 days in jail, ordered to serve two years probation, 60 hours of community service and pay a $500 restitution fee. (St. Louis Record)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News, Databases

Name of case: United States of America v. James Leslie Little
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; *18:1752(a)(2); Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D); Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of NC; Indicted by Bill of Information; Sentenced 3/14/22 to 60 days of incarceration, to be followed by 36 months of probation, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: James Leslie Little, 62 of North Carolina, pled guilty to Parading or Demonstrating in Capitol Building following his participation in the Capitol riot. He was sentenced to 2 months in prison. He was identified via a relative providing information to the FBI and his identity was confirmed through photographs taken inside the Capitol. Before January 6, Little posted online warning of a "civil war" if the U.S. Supreme Court did not side with then-President Donald Trump in winning the 2020 election.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Larocca & Cortez
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of TX; "Sentenced 8/10/22 to 60 days in jail, one year of supervised release, 60 hours of community service, $2,000 fine, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Benjamin LaRocca, 27, was charged with Obstruction of an Official Proceeding, Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds, and Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds after participating in the Capitol riot on 6 January. LaRocca, accompanied by his friend Christian Cortez, 27, allegedly filmed a crowd of rioters pushing toward a line of law enforcement officers inside the Capitol. Later in the video, Larocca appears to flip the camera to himself and chants, “Our house!” in response to other rioters chanting, “Whose house?” He is currently on recognizance.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Larocca & Cortez
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:111(a)- Assaulting a Federal Officer
Additional details: Resident of TX.; "Sentenced 8/31/22 to 4 months of incarceration, 36 months of supervised release, 60 hours of community service, $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative: Christian Cortez, 27, was charged with Assaulting a Federal Officer, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding, Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building, and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following his participation in the Capitol riot on 6 January 2021. Cortez, accompanied by his friend Benjamin LaRocca, 27, allegedly hurled expletives at police officers in the Capitol building doorway and egging them on to fire at him with pepper spray and fire extinguishers as they tried to force the doors closed. He is currently released on recognizance.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Jeremy Ryan Sorvisto
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of MI; Indicted by Bill of Information; Special assessment of $10.00; Restitution of $500; Sentenced 12/15/2021 to 30 days in jail;
Short narrative: Jeremy Sorvisto, Sr., 37 of Michigan, and his fiance Ashley Aho pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing a Capitol Building. He was sentenced to a month in prison. His charges grew out of the investigation into Karl Dresch, who was arrested in January. "A court affidavit says a former grade-school classmate sent photos posted on Ashley Aho’s social media accounts to the FBI taken inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, showing her and Jeremy Sorvisto, whom she identifies online as her fiancé. Posts included in the affidavit show Sorvisto and Aho in the backseat of a car traveling from Michigan’s Upper Peninsula to Washington, D.C., captioned with the hashtag “#trump2020.”" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Danielle Nicole Doyle
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent entry and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Additional details: Resident of OK; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced 10/1 to two months probation, $3,000 fine, and $500 restitution to the Architect of the Capitol."
Short narrative: Danielle Doyle, 37 of Oklahoma, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for her participation in the January 6, 2021 Capitol riot. She was sentenced to 2 months probation. "According to the FBI, Danielle Doyle can be seen on surveillance video entering the Capitol through a broken window and walking around. Two witnesses came forward identifying Doyle as a former co-worker, according to court documents. The Oklahoma City Thunder NBA team confirmed to local media that Doyle was a former employee who worked as an account manager for the team until December of last year." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Boyd Allen Camper
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of MT; Indicted by BIll of Information; Sentenced to 60 days incarceration and $10 special assessment
Short narrative:
Boyd Allen Camper, 54 of Montana, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for his participation in the Capitol riot. He was sentenced to 2 months of prison. 

"Multiple witnesses confirmed to the FBI that Camper went inside the U.S. Capitol building carrying a GoPro camera on a stick. Days later, Camper told FBI agents in an interview that “in my mind, we were going to take the Capitol steps.” He also said he entered the building through a small door that led to the Rotunda and then proceeded to a room “with statues.” According to court documents, Camper told the FBI they couldn't review the footage he took on his camera if they would use the content against him. In a sentencing memorandum filed in federal court, Camper is identified as having military service. In that memo, a U.S. prosecutor wrote: "While Camper’s military service is laudable, it renders his conduct on January 6 all the more egregious. As a former military member, Camper was well aware that taxpayer status does not bestow upon a person the right to enter restricted government buildings. His voluntary decision to storm a guarded government building is nothing short of shocking in light of his former military service and training."" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Robert Scott Palmer
Charges: 18:111(a(1) and (b); ASSAULTING/RESISTING/IMPEDING OFFICERS/EMPLOYEES; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon, Inflicting Bodily Injury; *18:231(a)(3); CIVIL DISORDER; *18:111(a)(3); ASSAULTING/RESISTING/IMPEDING OFFICERS/EMPLOYEES; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; *18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A); TEMPORARY RESIDENCE OF THE PRESIDENT; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon [3 counts]; *40:5104(e)(2)(D); VIOLENT ENTRY AND DISORDERLY CONDUCT ON CAPITOL GROUNDS; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(F); VIOLENT ENTRY AND DISORDERLY CONDUCT ON CAPITOL GROUNDS; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
Additional details: As of 12-21-21 this was the longest prison sentenced levied
Short narrative: "Palmer, who owns a cleaning service in Largo, Florida, was dubbed #FloridaFlagJacket by online sleuths, because he wore a jacket styled like an American flag with the word Trump on the front and a Trump campaign pin to the Capitol. The FBI reported he threw a wooden plank at officers, sprayed the contents of a fire extinguisher toward officers, threw the fire extinguisher at them and then picked it up and threw it at them a second time. Court records in Pinellas County, Florida show Palmer has been in trouble with authorities more than a dozen times over 35 years, including a 1989 felony charge of fraud and theft and a 1998 felony charge of false imprisonment. Records show he declared bankruptcy in 2014 and was ticketed with driving on a sidewalk or bike path in 2018:" (USA Today)
Source description: National news; Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Jonathan Joshua Munafo
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding and Aiding and abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and remaining on restricted grounds with a dangerous weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a dangerous weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Act of physical violence against property on restricted grounds with a dangerous weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) Act of physical violence against person on restricted grounds; 18:641 Theft of Government property; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence on the Capitol grounds
Additional details: Resident of NY
Short narrative: Jonathan Joshua Munafo, A.K.A. John Joshua Munafo, 34, of Albany, NY is charged with Civil Disorder; Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; Obstruction of an official proceeding and Aiding and abetting; Entering and remaining on restricted grounds with a dangerous weapon; Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a dangerous weapon; Act of physical violence against property on restricted grounds with a dangerous weapon; Act of physical violence against person on restricted grounds; Theft of Government property; Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; and Act of physical violence on the Capitol grounds for his participation in the Jan 6th Capitol riot. "According to court documents, Munafo was on the Lower West Terrace outside the tunnel where he was captured on video striking a U.S. Capitol Police officer twice in the head and body with a closed fist. Munafo then violently ripped the officer’s riot shield out of his hands and passed it back to others in the crowd behind him. At one point, Munafo used a wooden flagpole to strike a window of the Capitol in an attempt to break it. (DOJ Press Release)". Munafo has pled not guilty. This case is currently pending.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News article

Name of case: United States of America v. Luke Russell Coffee
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon [2 counts]; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(3) and (b)(1)(A) - Impeding Ingress and Egress in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(E) - Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Additional details: Resident of TX; Believer in QAnon conspiracy
Short narrative: Luke Russell Coffee, 41, of TX, was charged with Civil Disorder; two counts of Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Impeding Ingress and Egress in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; and Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building following his participation in the Capitol riot and his alleged assault of a DC metropolitan police officer with a crutch. There is extensive video footage of Coffee at the US Capitol with the crutch beating several cops. Coffee has pled not guilty. This case is currnetly pending.
Source description: Charging documents, Court Documents, Local news article, Governmental reports and release (DOJ)

Name of case: United States of America v. Michael Fitzgerald
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds
Additional details: Resident of Janesville, Wisconsin
Short narrative: Michael Fitzgerald was charged and arrested for his role in the January 6 Capitol protests. He wore a shirt that stated "There will be a wild protest. January 6, 2021" on the front of it. The complaint does not say whether Fitzgerald himself assaulted any officers. Photos show him near the front of the line, “participating in the push against law enforcement officers.” In total, it appeared that he was in the Capitol for about 40 minutes before he left through a window.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Dovid Schwartzberg
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) and (2) Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted buiding or grounds wihtout lawful authority to do so and engaging in disorderly or disruptive conduct in a reastrcted building or gorunds with intent to impede; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parding, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Resident of Brooklyn, NY; Indicted by Bill of Information; "Sentenced 9/7/22 to 45 days of incarceration, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Dovid Schwartzberg, 19, of Brooklyn, New York, was charged with knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted buiding or grounds wihtout lawful authority to do so and engaging in disorderly or disruptive conduct in a reastrcted building or gorunds with intent to impede, and uttering loud, threatening, or abusive language, or engaging in disorderly or discuprtive conduct at the Capitol Building or Capitol grounds with intent to impede, disrupt, or distrub the orderly conduct of Congress and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in any of the Capitol Buildings. Schwartzberg was identified through Capitol Building security cameras, and by a tipster through photos and a video uploaded to Facebook. The same tipster also provided photos of Schwartzberg in the Capitol Building, a video link on Twitter showing Schwartzberg exiting th Capitol Building.
Source description: Court Documents, News Article, Local News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Derrick Evans
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Impeding, Obstructing or Interfering with law enforcement during a civil disorder;
Additional details: Resident of WV; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Sentenced 6/22/22 to three months in jail, three years of supervised release, $2,000 fine, $2,000 restitution.
Short narrative: Derrick Evans, 35 of West Virginia, pled guilty to Impeding, Obstructing or Interfering with Law Enforcement During a Civil Disorder for his role in the January 6 Capitol riot. He was sentenced to 3 months in prison. During the event, the West Virginia Delegate live streamed footage of himself entering the Capitol building in Washington DC. Evans, a newly elected state representative from West Virginia, reportedly deleted the video soon after the siege ended, but it soon re-emerged on Reddit. Days later, Evans resigned from his office in the House of Delegates.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Jeramiah Caplinger
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building;  *40:5104(e)(2)(D) and (G) Violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; 40:5104(d) Climbing on U.S. Capitol grounds;
Additional details: Resident of MI; Charged by bill of information; "Sentenced 8/1/22 to 35 days in jail, followed by 24 months of probation, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution"
Short narrative:
Jeramiah Caplinger, 25 of Michigan, pled guilty to Stepping, Climbing, Removing, or Injuring Property on the Capitol Grounds. He was sentenced to 35 days in prison. He attended the protest in Washington D.C. on January 6 and ended up inside the Capitol building. He described the damage he saw inside, including seeing someone urinating in a corner and seeing officers with their guns drawn. 

"According to court documents, Jeramiah Caplinger told a Detroit news website in mid-February that he scaled the U.S. Capitol's wall and went inside the building during the Jan. 6, 2021, riot. Caplinger told the news organization the events of 2020 “fueled outrage” among former President Trump’s supporters and “being told the election was stolen was one poke too many." Videos from social media show Caplinger wearing a red bucket hat labeled Trump 2020 and carrying an American flag attached to a tree branch through the halls of the Capitol, according to court documents. Caplinger also told the Detroit news website he hopes to run for political office some day and said, “My rage towards the establishment, Democrats and RINO Republicans is great. Think of Pompeii when it was destroyed by Mount Vesuvius.”" (NPR
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Nelson & Markofski
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent entry or disorderly conduct; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Resident of WI; WI Army National Guard PFC Delta Company, 1st Battalion, 128th Infantry Regiment; Sentenced 12/10/2021 to 24 months probation, $500 restitution and $1,000 fine.
Short narrative: On May 6th, 2021, Abram Markofski and Brandon Nelson were indicted on charges of *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent entry or disorderly conduct; and 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. Both took a plea deal and pleaded guilty to the charge of 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. Sentencing is pending. Of note is that Markofski joined the National Guard in 2019 and is currently a private. An FBI affidavit says Nelson told agents that he and Markofski drove to Washington to see President Donald Trump’s political rally and both he and Markofski admitted to entering the Capitol.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Glen Mitchell Simon
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of GA; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Sentenced 8/12/22 to 8 months of incarceration, 12 months of supervised release, $1,000 fine, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: On May 7, 2021, Glen Mitchell Simon, 30 from GA, was indicted for his involvement in the Capitol raid. "He was identified via social media by multiple tipsters, including one who attended school with him. Photos and videos posted on Simon's Facebook account showed him inside the U.S. Capitol, with one video saying, "We weren't invited, we broke in here," according to court documents. One photo shows him on the steps of the Capitol building, embracing a person wearing a rubber mask shaped like a bald eagle. Simon reportedly deleted many of the posts, but FBI agents tracked him down via a search of publicly available databases." (NPR) He pled guilty to the charge of Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds and was sentenced to 8 months incarceration and 12 months of supervised release.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Duke Edward Wilson
Charges: 18:111(a)(1),2 Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds: 18:1512(c)(2),2 Obstruction of an Official proceeding; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings
Additional details: Resident of Idaho; Sentenced 3/4/22 to 51 months in prison, followed by three years of supervised release, $2,000 restitution.
Short narrative: Duke Edward Wilson, 66, of Nampa, Idaho, was arrested for assaulting law enforcement officers, among other charges, during the breach of the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6 that disrupted a joint session of the U.S. Congress in the process of affirming the presidential election.
Source description: Court Documents, Charging documents, local news

Name of case: United States of America v. Bingert, Sturgeon, & Johnatakis
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and abetting; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(E) Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Additional details: From Slatington, PA; Joined PA State Police Department's training academy in 2015 for one week before being "saparated" (COAN Daily/News)
Short narrative: In 2021, in Washington D.C., Taylor James Johnatakis, 37, of Kingston, Washington, Craig Michael Bingert, 29, of Slatington, PA, and Issac Steve Sturgeon, 32, of Montana, have been charged with Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Obstructing, or Impeding Passage Through or Within, the Grounds or Any of the Capitol Buildings; Engaging in an Act of Physical Violence in the Grounds or Any of the Capitol Buildings following their participation in the Capitol riot. Bingert's statement of facts explains that he actively broke past barricades at the US Capitol amidst the riot. The roles of Sturgeon and Johnatakis during the Capitol riot are less clear. Sturgeon fled the US for Kenya shortly after the January 6th riot and was deported back to the US in early March. Johnatakis has a podcast, "The Peasants Perspective", on which he stated that "he considered the QAnon theories 'a good source' and didn't want to be too critical of them but disavowed putting the person behind the theories on a pedastal and making an idol out of them...'We overlap with a lot of things Q believers believe in, but there is a difference'", referring to how his Mormon beliefs (Kitsap Sun). It is also unknown whether the three men know each other or have any connection beyond being at the Capitol riot.
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, Government reports and release (DOJ), News article

Name of case: United States of America v. Vic Don Williams
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; *18:1752(a)(2) Knowingly Engages in Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Resident of TX; Sentenced 2/7/22, 12 months of probation, including two months of home confinement, $1,500 fine, $500 restitution
Short narrative: "“Do Terrorist break into the building to take selfie’s? Do they stop to ask the riot police in the Capitol where the bathroom is? Do they ask if they can take selfies with the riot police? Patriots do. And this is what happened,” wrote Vic Don Williams, who goes by Stiemy Vic Williams on Facebook, next to a picture of himself on the steps of the Capitol, according to court documents. Several witnesses contacted the FBI and reported that Williams participated in the Jan. 6 events at the Capitol based on content they viewed on Facebook. Agents interviewed Williams at his home, where he admitted posting on social media and being outside the Capitol, but not entering. According to the FBI, Williams, who owns a roasting company, gave two bags of coffee to the interviewing agents as they were leaving. Later footage reviewed by the FBI shows Williams inside the Capitol, contradicting his previous statements." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Antionne De Shaun Brodnax
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly conduct in any Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds
Additional details: Charged by Bill of Information; Resident of VA; "Sentenced - 12/19/2022 to 5 months incarceration, 12 months supervised release, $500 restitution"
Short narrative: Antionne De Shaun Brodnax was charged with 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly conduct in any Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds following his participation in the Capitol riot. Brodnax was identified through numerous social media posts (Twitter and Instagram) depicting Brodnax inside the US Capitol. Brodnax then confirmed his participation as well.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Vinson & Vinson
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Accepted plea agreement where defendant pled guilty to USC:5104(e)(2)(G); Sentenced on October 22, 2021 to five years' probation, $5,000.00 fine, $500.00 restitution, and 120 hours of community service; Husband also arrested and charged
Short narrative: On May 12, 2021, Lori Ann Vitson, 49, and her husband, Thomas Roy Vinson, 54, were formally charged for their participation in the January 2021 Capitol riots. After traveling to Washington D.C. for the Stop the Steal rally, the couple allegedly spent approximately 35 minutes inside of the Capitol building. Mrs. Vitson believes that they are not guilty of any transgression. She claims that she will always remember that day and feel proud that she was there (USA Today). After initially pleading not guilty to all counts, the couple accepted a plea deal in which they pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. On October 22, 2021, the couple was sentenced to five years' probation, a $5,000.00 fine, $500.00 restitution, and 120 hours of community service.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles

On October 22, 2021, the couple was sentenced to five years' probation, a $5,000.00 fine, $500.00 restitution, and 120 hours of community service.

Name of case: United States of America v. Kevin Sam Blakely
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of TX; Indicted by Bill of Information; "Sentenced 7/14/22 to 120 days in jail, 18 months of probation, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Kevin Sam Blakely, of Texas, was charged with Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; Knowingly Engaging in Disorderly or Dirsuptive Conduct in any Restricted Building or Grounds; and Violent Entry and Disorderly Condyct on Capitol Grounds following his participation at the Capitol riot.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Nicholas Languerand
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; *18:231(a)(3); Civil Disorder; *18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(a) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds With a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(a) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Ground with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
Additional details: Accepted plea agreement where defendant pled guilty to 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers with a Dangerous Weapon; Also sentenced to 2 years' supervised release, 60 hours of community service and $2,000.00 restitution; Dishonorably discharged from the US Army for cocaine offense; QAnon follower; Resident of SC
Short narrative: On May 12, 2021, Nicholas Languerand, 26, was formally charged for his role in the January 2021 Capitol protests. According to the complaint issued against him, Languerand allegedly threw a variety of objects at law enforcement officers along the Lower West Terrace tunnel of the Capitol building. Among these objects were an orange traffic cone, a canister of pepper spray, and several stick-like objects. "While Languerand admitted he had participated in the assault on the Capitol, investigators say he showed little remorse and even indicated that he wanted to see more violence" (CBS News, 2022). Languerand ultimately pled guilty to assaulting, resisting, or impeding officers with a dangerous weapon, and was sentenced to 44 months in prison, 2 years' supervised release, 60 hours of community service and $2,000.00 restitution.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Garret Miller
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:875(c) - Interstate Threats to Injure or Kidnap; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(3) - Impeding Ingress and Egress in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(E) - Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of Richardson, TX; "Garret Miller was sentenced in the District of Columbia to 38 months in prison and 36 months of supervised release."
Short narrative: 2021, in Washingon D.C., Garret A. Miller, 34, from Richardson, TX, was charged with 12 counts following his participation in the Capitol riot. Miller was identified via numerous photographs he then posted to Facebook including a selfie with the caption "just wanted to incriminate myself a little lol". Miller also used Twitter and Facebook to issue threats to Congress and police. Miller threatened NY Democrat Ocasio-Cortez after she wrote “Impeach” on Twitter on 1/6/21 and Miller responded with “Assassinate AOC.” Miller also threatened the Capitol Police officer who shot Ashli Babbitt, referred to her as his “sister in battle” and regarding the officer, Miller said he would “hug his neck with a nice rope.”
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Articles, Governmenrtal Reports and ReleaseCharging Documents, Local News Articles, Governmenrtal Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Thomas B. Adams Jr.
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of IL; "Thomas B. Adams, Jr., 41, of Springfield, Illinois, was found guilty on January 31, 2023, of the felony charge of obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting entering and the misdemeanor of remaining in a restricted building or grounds."
Short narrative: On May 12, 2021, Thomas B. Adams Jr., 39, was charged with entering a restricted building, violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds and obstructing an official proceeding for his participation in the January 2021 US Capitol riots. Although Adams confessed to entering the Capitol, he clarified that that he did not go into the Capitol with "an agenda" and that he did not try to destroy anything inside. Adams pleaded not guilty to all charges, and is currently released on personal recognizance.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Marc Bru
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(B) - Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding;
Additional details: Identified with information sourced from anti-fascist researchers (Pacific Northwest Resistance) according to Statement of Facts; Resident of WA
Short narrative: "On Feb. 3, a tipster called the FBI to tell agents that shortly before Jan. 6, Marc Bru had said he planned to travel to Washington, D.C., to "witness history in the making." When the tipster asked Bru what he meant, Bru replied, “You are about to see — it’s going to be big.” According to court documents, several photographs and videos from Jan. 6 show Bru marching with the Proud Boys and flashing the "OK" hand sign, a gesture associated with the far-right hate group. Later, he is allegedly seen grabbing a police barricade in an attempt to wrench it away from officers. Photographs and security camera footage from inside the U.S. Capitol that day, as well as location records obtained from AT&T, also place Bru inside the building that afternoon, court records show." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Ester Schwemmer
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; *18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in Any Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Sentenced to 2 years probation, 60 hours of community service, and $500.00 restitution; Accepted plea agreement where defendant pled guilty to 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; Indicted by Bill of Information; Resident of KS
Short narrative: On May 14, 2021, Ester Schwemmer, 55, was formally charged for her role in the January 2021 U.S. Capitol riots. Schwemmer, who attended the protest with her friend Jennifer Ruth Parks, 57, entered the Capitol building through broken-down doors before singing the national anthem on the second floor. Schwemmer accepted a plea deal in which she pled guilty to 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. On January 10, 2022, Schwemmer was sentenced to two years' probation, 60 hours of community service, and $500.00 restitution.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Jennifer Ruth Parks
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Sentenced to 24 months probation, $500 restitution and 60 hours community service; Accepted plea agreement where defendant pleaded guilty to 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Indicted by Bill of Information; Resident of KS
Short narrative: On May 14, 2021, Jennifer Ruth Parks. 59, was indicted for her participation in the January 2021 U.S. Capitol riots. After her attendance at the protests was discovered through a screenshot of a text from her daughter, Parks turned herself in on April 23, 2021. Parks pled guilty to one count of the charges, and was sentenced to 24 months' probation, $500.00 restitution and 60 hours of community service.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Michael Timbrook
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Indicted by Bill of Information; Resident of TN; Sentenced 5/20/22 to 12 months of probation with 14 days of intermittent incarceration (weekends for seven consecutive weeks), $500 in restitution.
Short narrative: On May 14, 2021, Michael Timbrook, 56, was indicted following his participation in the January 2021 U.S. Capitol protests. from Cookeville, TN has been arrested and charged for his participation in the 2021 Capitol protests. Surveillance footage from that day captured Timbrook entering the Capitol through the Senate Wing Door before walking into a room designated for Congressional employees. Timbrook changed his plea from not guilty to guilty on February 9, 2022, and is currently on personal recognizance.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Wangler & Harrison
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of IL; Pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; Indicted by Bill of Information; Sentenced to two years probation, 60 hours of community service and no fines.
Short narrative: Douglas K. Wangler, 53, faces several charges for his role in the U.S. Capitol riot on 6 January 2021. According to court documents, Wangler could allegedly be seen in an 11-second video standing in the Capitol Crypt on Jan. 6, pumping his right fist in the air and chanting, “U.S.A.” Wangler has pled guilty to one out of four charges against him, and is due to attend a sentencing hearing on 16 December 2021. The government wanted three years probation for Wangler and four years for Harrison, who had deleted some digital files from the D.C. trip. Judge Friedrich said the men committed serious misdemeanors but sentenced both of them to two years probation, 60 hours of community service and no fines. (ABC)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Wangler & Harrison
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of IL; Pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; Indicted by Bill of Information; Sentenced to two years probation, 60 hours of community service and no fines.
Short narrative: Bruce J. Harrison, 58, faces several charges for his role in the U.S. Capitol riot on 6 January 2021. Harrison initially traveled to D.C. for the Trump rally with his friend Douglas Wangler, 53. After hearing President Trump say that the crowd should move toward the Capitol, the men walked toward the Capitol, according to court documents. Harrison said the doors were open when they went in. They told the agents that although they saw violence, they only went in and looked around" (USA Today). Harrison has pled guilty to one out of four charges against him, and is due to attend a sentencing hearing on 16 December 2021.The government wanted three years probation for Wangler and four years for Harrison, who had deleted some digital files from the D.C. trip. Judge Friedrich said the men committed serious misdemeanors but sentenced both of them to two years probation, 60 hours of community service and no fines.(ABC)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Micajah Joel Jackson
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of AZ; Wore orange armband presumed to be signaling affiliation with Proud Boys, and was photographed marching with PBs, but denies affiliation with group. Micajah Jackson sentenced 3/24/22 to 36 months of probation, including 90 days in a residential re-entry center, $1,000 fine, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: "Jackson, whose social media pages say he's a 100% disabled Marine, surrendered to the FBI on May 18: The FBI stated in court documents that he posted photos on social media of himself on Jan. 6 in a plaid shirt and other clothing he wore to the riot, photos agents later used to identify him. He was dubbed #TartanPlaidPB by online sleuths who are researching those who participated in the Capitol riot, then turning that information over to the FBI. Jackson is seen in photos numerous times on Jan. 6 with Proud Boys from Arizona, and wore one of their orange arm bands, the FBI stated. However, in an interview with the FBI at his home, agents said Jackson told them he is not affiliated with the Proud Boys and doesn't support their ideology. He said they gave him the orange band and he stayed with them for protection because he had traveled to Washington, D.C. alone. However, the FBI noted that in December, one of his social media connections tagged him in a post about a group of Proud Boys being in New York City. In a social media post included in the court records, Jackson said he didn't agree with the "MAGA tribalism," and didn't commit any violence. Jackson stated in the post that he had evidence of BLM, Antifa, police officers and "Non Trump" extremists "causing the mayhem." Jackson also stated that he's a college student studying to be a political science professor. "My only love is the United States of America," he wrote. At the Capitol, records show he carried a U.S. flag and was with a crowd singing The Star-Spangled Banner after the detonation of an explosive device in the crowd. He then pointed toward the Senate Wing of the Capitol and moved that direction. The agents noted he was seen on video in Statuary Hall and other locations inside the Capitol." (USA Today)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Couy Griffin
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building
Additional details: Charged by Bill of Information; Serves as a county Commissioner; resident of NM; Founding member for "Cowboys For Trump"; Sentenced 6/17/22 to 14 days in jail (time already served), one year of supervised release, 60 hours of community service, $3,000 fine, $500 restitution. Credit for time already served (20 days).
Short narrative: Couy Griffin, a Otero County New Mexico Commissioner and founder of the group Cowboys for Trump was charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building, and Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building. "According to court documents, Griffin told investigators that he was “caught up” in the crowd, which pushed its way through the barricades and entered the restricted area of the U.S. Capitol, but he said he did not enter the building and instead remained on the U.S. Capitol steps. A video posted to Griffin’s personal Facebook page shows Griffin in the restricted areas, according to the affidavit...Griffin said he planned to travel with firearms to Washington, D.C., for Biden’s inauguration. FBI special agents said Griffin told them that "he hopes a change in leadership can be accomplished 'without a single shot being fired,' but noted that there was 'no option that was off the table for the sake of freedom,'" according to the affidavit. (NBC News)"
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Andrew Michael Cavanaugh
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Indicted by Bill of Information; Resident of MT; "Sentenced 8/4/22 to 24 months of probation, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: On May 14, 2021, Andrew Michael Cavanaugh, 29, was charged with Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building, Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority, and Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds following his role in the January 2021 Capitol riots. Cavanaugh's participation in in the events of that day was confirmed through "a video posted to the social media app Parler, where he was reportedly seen in a camouflage baseball cap with the logo for "Tactical Citizen," a Belgrade-based business founded and owned by Cavanaugh" (KTVQ, 2022). Cavanaugh pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building in exchange for the government's agreement to drop the charges of entering and remaining in a restricted building, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building and violent entry and disorderly conduct in a Capitol building.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Gary Edwards
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(C) Disruption of Official Business; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: From Churchville, PA; Indicted by Bill of Information; "sentenced to one year of Probation, a $2500 Fine, $500 in Restitution, and a $10 Special Assessment on count 5. Oral motion by the Government to "dismiss the remaining counts", HEARD and GRANTED. The Court ORDERS counts 1-4 are DISMISSED."
Short narrative: In 2021, Gary Edwards, 68, of Churchville PA, was charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disruption of Official Business, Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building, Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for his role in the Jan. 6th riot. Edwards was identified through security video and livestreams on social media. Additionally, Edwards' wife directly addressed and described his role in the riot on Facebook.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. James Breheny
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:1512(c)(1); 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding;
Additional details: Bergen County coordinator of the NJ Oath Keepers and in direct contact with leader Stewart Rhodes prior to 1/6. Breheny organized a regional OK meeting in PA on 1/3
Short narrative: ""We weren't burning down the city. We wanted access to the Capital [sic] to watch the vote and have our voices heard. They put barricades up. It's our house not theirs,” wrote James Breheny on Facebook on Jan 6. Breheny, a member of the Oath Keepers, served as the coordinator of the Bergen County, N.J., chapter of the organization, according to court documents. On Jan. 3, Breheny is believed to have held a leadership meeting for the Oath Keepers of the Mid-Atlantic region in Quarryville, Pa., to prepare for the rally on Jan. 6, according to the FBI. “This will be the day we get our comms on point with multiple other patriot groups, share rally points etc. This one is important and I believe this is our last chance to organize before the show. This meeting will be for leaders only,” he wrote to the group. On Jan. 14, Breheny was interviewed by law enforcement about his involvement on Jan. 6, but further investigation revealed that he lied to the FBI on multiple occasions about his actions that day. Breheny stated to the officers that he was unwillingly pushed inside the building by the large group and did not engage in violence. Footage, however, shows Breheny in close proximity to ongoing violence involving assault on police officers with flagpoles and irritants, as well as communication between him and other members of the Oath Keepers on the platform Signal that read, “We breached the door Baby” and “Made it in Brother.” In addition, Breheny indicated on the same chat that he is deleting all his social media posts in order to avoid being caught. Breheny goes by the alias “Seamus Evers.”" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Jody Lynn Tagaris
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(C) - Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of FL; Wearing MAGA hat and US Olympics American flag jacket; Sentenced 6/6/22 to 24 months of probation, 60 hours of community service, $2,000 fine, and $500 restitution.
Short narrative: "Tagaris posted a photo of herself on Facebook wearing a Make America Great Again Hat and a U.S. Olympics American flag jacket while posing in the frame of a broken window in the U.S. Capitol, the FBI wrote in federal charging documents. An anonymous tipster sent a copy of the photo to the Metropolitan Police Department. The FBI stated Tagaris is seen on surveillance video inside the Capitol, and in the Senate Breakout Room. Public records show Tagaris is a registered Republican who voted early in the November 2020 election. Se has been an officer or director in two political groups, Floridians for Responsive Government and the Florida Republican Assembly." (USA Today)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. John Earle Sullivan
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:231(a)(3), 2 Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(1)(A)(i) Unlawful Possession of a Firearm on Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:1001(a)(2) False Statement or Representation to an Agency of the United States; 18:2 Aiding and Abetting
Additional details: Indictment includes forfeiture (18:981; 21:853; 28:2461) of ~$90,000 in monies earned by defendant selling video footage of rioter being shot and killed by police; Pled guilty to counts 1-6 of charges; Previously arrested and charged with Rioting at a BLM protest in June 2020
Short narrative: On May 19, 2021 John Earle Sullivan, 26, was indicted on charges of Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Civil Disorder; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly Weapon; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; Unlawful Possession of a Firearm on Capitol Grounds or Buildings; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; False Statement or Representation to an Agency of the United States; and Aiding and Abetting following his participation in the January 6, 2021 raid on the U.S. Capitol. Sullivan, a self-proclaimed Black activist and leader of the group Insurgence USA, filmed many of the events of the riot, including the fatal shooting of fellow protestor Ashli Babbitt. In addition to the charges relating to his role as a participant and instigator in the events of that day, Sullivan also faces perjury charges for lying to law enforcement about his possession of a knife during the protests. Sullivan pled not guilty to counts 1-6, and remains on recognizance bond.
Source description: Charging Documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Middleton & Middleton
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers (2); 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D)- Disorderly Conduct in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
Additional details: Resident of TX; Wife also arrested; Defendant remains on personal recognizance bond
Short narrative: Mark Middleton, 52, was arrested and charged with assault of a law enforcement officer, interference with a law enforcement officer during civil disorder, obstruction of an official proceeding, unlawful entry on restricted grounds, and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds following his participation in the U.S. Capitol riots on 6 January 2021. Middleton, who was accompanied by his wife Jalise, 51, can be heard on police body cam footage yelling “f*** you!” at police and pushing against a barricade as officers repeatedly ordered him to get back. The footage also depicts the Middletons grappling with and striking two MPD officers. Middleton has pleaded not guilty to all counts and currently remains on personal recognizance.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Middleton & Middleton
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers (2); 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D)- Disorderly Conduct in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
Additional details: Resident of TX; Husband also arrested
Short narrative: Jalise Middleton, 51, was arrested and charged with assault of a law enforcement officer, interference with a law enforcement officer during civil disorder, obstruction of an official proceeding, unlawful entry on restricted grounds, and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds following his participation in the U.S. Capitol riots on 6 January 2021. Middleton, who was accompanied by her husband Mark Middleton, 52, allegedly reached over the police barricade to grab and repeatedly strike two different police officers with her hands. Middleton has pleaded not guilty to all counts and currently remains on personal recognizance.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Jennifer Heinl
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of PA, charged by information doc; Sentenced 6/8/22 to two years of probation, including 14 days of intermittent incarceration, 50 hours of community service, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: Jennifer Heinl, 43 of Pennsylvania, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building and was sentenced to two weeks in prison for her role in the Capitol riot. Heinl was seen in security camera footage from inside the Capitol rotunda. Investigators obtained a search warrant for Grayson's Facebook account and found messages between Heinl and Grayson discussing travel plans to Washington, D.C., in the weeks leading up to the riot. The defendant's husband, Michael Heinl, is a detective with the Shaler Township Police Department near Pittsburgh and serves on an FBI task force.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Jonah Elijah Westbury
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of MN; Indicted by Bill of Information
Short narrative: Jonah Elijah Westbury was arrested and charged Friday with various crimes relating to the riot, in which supporters of former President Donald Trump stormed congress to stop certification of the 2020 election. Westbury is the second Minnesotan arrested in connection with the riot in as many days. His brother and father, Isaac and Robert Westburry were also charged later in a seperate indictment.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Anthony Richard Moat
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of PA; Indicted by Bill of Information
Short narrative: “On February 19, 2021, Anthony Richard Moat (‘MOAT’) contacted the FBI and admitted to being inside the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021,” says an agent’s Statement of Facts
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. John Daniel Andries
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and abetting; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a restricted building; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *50:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Charged via Bill of Information; USMC veteran; Accepted a plea deal, pled guilty to Count One in the Indictment, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; "John Andries Sentenced 1/17/23  to 12 months and one day in prison for a felony charge, $2,000 restitution and three years of supervised release"
Short narrative: John Daniel Andries, 35, former Marine One Squadron Crew Chief, of Maryland, was charged with Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and abetting; Entering and Remaining in a restricted building; Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; and Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol Building. Andries was identified via a tip provided to the FBI as well as numerous videos taken inside the Capitol. Andries initially pled not guilty, later accepting a plead deal and pleading guilty to Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and abetting.
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Anthony Robert Williams
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of Southgate, MI; Found guilty by jury of all charges on 6/30/22; "Sentenced 9/16/22 to 60 months in prison, followed by 36 months of supervised release, $5,000 fine, $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative: Anthony Robert Williams, 45 of Michigan, pled not guilty but was found guilty on all charges by a jury, leading to a sentence of 60 years in prison. Williams took a selfies and smoked marijuana in the Capitol. "According to the FBI, Williams also discussed on tape having “stormed” the building and having “pushed back cops.” "Was the proudest day of my life…felt like the founding fathers were smiling down on us in that room, and I guarantee my dad and gramps, both vets, would be proud,” he wrote on Facebook three days later, according to a complaint." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Brian Gundersen
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officersl 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Origionally charged by Bill of Information, later by Indictment; "Found guilty by Court on 11/9/22 of obstruction of an official proceeding and assaulting, resisting, or impeding law enforcement officers. Defendant agreed to a set of stipulated facts at trial before the Court."
Short narrative: Brian Gundersen was charged with knowingly entering/remaining in a building without lawful authority, engaging in disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds, and parading/demonstrating in the Capitol building among other charges on his superseding indictment following Gundersen's participation in the Capitol riot. Gundersen was identified via various tipsters as well as photographic evidence made clear by the fact that Gundersen was wearing his high school letterman jacket.
Source description: Charging documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Timothy Wayne Williams
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering aor Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) disorderly or disruptive conduct, at any place in the grounds or in any of the Capitol Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) parade, demonstrate, or picket in any of the Capitol Buildings
Additional details: Resident of CO
Short narrative: "An anonymous tip to the FBI identified Timothy Wayne Williams as entering the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6 after attending President Trump’s rally, according to court documents. In March, the FBI interviewed Williams in person, where he confirmed to the agents that he had entered the building. Williams also told the FBI that he previously worked for a company called “GrowGeneration,” a hydroponics equipment supplier, but lost his job because he would not take a COVID-19 test. He denied having been involved in any acts of violence or property damage but stated that he “got pushed” inside the building by the crowd and that he saw people “tearing things up inside.”" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Stacy Wade Hager
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Indicted by Bill of Information
Short narrative: Stacy Wade Hager posted pictures and videos of himself while trespassing in the U.S. Capitol building on his Facebook page. He was later identified and charged for his role in the January 2021 Capitol protests.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Jonathan Ace Sanders, Sr.
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of IN; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Sentenced 11/4/21 to 36 months probation, $500 restitution, and 60 hours of community service within six months
Short narrative: Jonathan Ace Sanders, 60 of Indiana, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building, resulting in 3 years of probation. He bragged about being at the U.S. Capitol riot on Jan. 6 and being 70 feet away from Ashli Babbitt when she was shot, as indicated in court documents. In a subsequent interview with the FBI, Sanders admitted that he had entered the Capitol and had taken pictures and videos while inside. His presence was corroborated by Capitol security footage from that day.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. James Bonet
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(C) Entering and remaining in certain rooms in the capitol building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; *18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding
Additional details: Resident of NY; Sentenced 3/9/22 to 90 days of incarceration, followed by a year of supervised release, including 200 hours of community service, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: James Bonet, 29 of Glens Falls, New York, pled guilty to Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds and was senteced to 90 days in prison for his role in the riot. The defendant, a shift manager in Saratoga Springs, was spotted in several photos and videos participating in the riots, including his own posted online while smoking marijuana in the Capitol.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Munchel & Eisenhart
Charges: 18:1512(k) Conspiracy to Commit Obstruction; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A), 2 Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A), 2 Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(1), 18:2 Unlawful Possession of a Dangerous Weapon on Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(B) Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) DIsorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Short narrative: Eric Gavelek Munchel, of Tennessee, was charged with one count of knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority and one count of violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds. [from DOJ release] He was later charged with conspiracy and civil disorder, along with his mother Lisa, for attacking police officers with zip ties.
Source description: Charging Documents, Governmental Reports and Releases
