Name of case: United States of America v. Patrick Alonzo. Stedman
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of Haddonfield, NJ; QAnon follower
Short narrative: A South Jersey man, Patrick Stedman, 32 of Haddonfield, is accused of taking part in the Jan. 6 riot at the U.S. Capitol, authorities say. Stedman is a follower of the Manosphere movement, and the federal complaint identifies him as a "dating and relationship strategist." In one Jan. 6, 2021 tweet, the federal complaint alleges, Stedman "discussed the details of his presence inside the U.S. Capitol, including sitting in Speaker of the House of Representatives Nancy Pelosi’s office." The FBI was alerted to Stedman's alleged role in the Washington, D.C., riot by acquaintances who saw his Twitter posts, the complaint says. One witness, identified as a college classmate, said Stedman discussed his involvement in the riot in a Jan. 6 post, according to the complaint.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Articles, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Nicole Prado
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of MD; Wearing MAGA hat; Sentenced 2/7/22, 12 months of probation, including 60 hours of community service, $742 fine, $500 restitution
Short narrative: "Nicole Prado was identified from a tip given to the FBI that she had participated in the Jan. 6 riot at the U.S. Capitol with another person. Court documents allege that the FBI found images and cellphone video footage from Instagram that appear to show Prado. A person narrating the video says, "Please meet the new Congresswoman... she uh, she just was in the Capitol for the first time today. She stormed the Capitol, she's the new Congresswoman. She's the new Speaker of the House." Video footage of the Capitol on that day shows a woman who resembled Prado walking through the building and matching the clothing in the Instagram video. FBI agents confirmed with other complainants that the person in the video was Prado, court document say." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Bauer & Blauser
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of PA; Defendant remains committed; "Sentenced 2/3/22 to $500 fine, $500 restitution."; "Pauline Bauer found guilty of obstruction of an official proceeding; entering and remaining in a restricted building; disorderly or disruptive conduct in a restricted building; disorderly and disruptive conduct in any of the Capitol Buildings with the intent to impede, disrupt, and disturb the orderly conduct of a session of Congress or either House of Congress; parading, demonstrating, and picketing in a Capitol Building."
Short narrative: Pauline Bauer, 53, faces several charges for her role in the U.S. Capitol riot on 6 January 2021. Accompanied by her friend William Blowser, 74, Bauer was heard shouting at police to “bring Nancy Pelosi out” to be hanged. Bauer has pleaded non-guilty to all counts, and claims to be a "sovereign citizen" who is not subject to U.S. law. Bauer remains incarcerated before her status conference, set for 29 October 2021 (Associated Press, 2021).
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Bauer & Blauser
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of PA; Pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; Sentencing scheduled for 3 February 2022; "Sentenced 2/3/22 to $500 fine, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: William Blauser Jr., 74, faces several charges for his role in the U.S. Capitol riot on 6 January 2021. Accompanied by his friend Pauline Bauer, 53, Blauser allegedly held a sign that read "Walk as Free People" inside of the Capitol Building before getting into a slight skirmish with police. Blauser accepted a plea deal and pled guilty to one out of five counts. He is scheduled for sentencing on 3 February 2022.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Audrey Ann Southard-Rumsey
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2) - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(4) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of FL; "Southard-Rumsey Found guilty 1/27/23 on counts 1, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, and 9 of the Superseding Indictment."
Short narrative: Audrey Ann Southard-Rumsey, 52, has been arrested and charged for her role in the January Capitol Protests. She was charged with assault on a federal officer or employee, obstruction of law enforcement during a civil disorder, obstruction of justice or congress, knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, knowing engaging in any act of physical violence against any person or property in any restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a U.S. Capitol building, parading, demonstrating or picketing in a U.S. Capitol building and engaging in an act of physical violence in the grounds or any of the U.S. Capitol buildings.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Joseph Elliott Zlab
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(C) Entering and remaining in certain rooms in the Capitol building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Resident of WA; Carried 'Dont Tred on Me' flag; Sentenced 4/1/22 to three years of probation, including 200 hours of community service, $500 fine, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: Joseph Zlab, 51 of Washington, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. He carried a yellow "Don't tread on me" flag as he walked through the Capitol on Jan. 6, an FBI agent wrote in a federal charging document. Zlab, co-owner of a commercial concrete company, admitted to entering the Capitol and taking photos, which he later posted on Facebook, the FBI stated.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Leonard Gruppo
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of NM; Sentenced to 24 months probation with 90 days of home detention; $500 restitution and a $3,000 fine.
Short narrative: Leonard Gruppo turned himself in for his participation in the January 2021 Capitol Protests. He has been charged with Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority, Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds, and Parading, Demonstrating or Picketing in a Capitol Building. He accepted a plea deal, pleading guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building, so the other charges were dropped.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Ryan, Schwab, & Hyland
Charges: 18:1725(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent entry and disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of TX; "Sentenced 8/9/22 to seven days in jail, $4,000 fine, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: On June 7th, 2021, Katherine Staveley Schwab, Jason Lee Hyland, and Jennifer Leigh Ryan were indicted on charges of 18:1725(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent entry and disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building; and 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol Building. Hyland's plea and sentencing are pending. Jason Lee Hyland was arrested and is charged with knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds and disorderly conduct. Hyland arranged for a private plane to take himself and four other individuals to DC to "stand up for America". Hyland was identified in photographs taken inside the Capitol.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Ryan, Schwab, & Hyland
Charges: *18:1725(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent entry and disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of TX; "Sentenced - 12/9/22 to 45 days incarceration, 36 months probation, $500 restitution"
Short narrative: On June 7th, 2021, Katherine Staveley Schwab, Jason Lee Hyland, and Jennifer Leigh Ryan were indicted on charges of 18:1725(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent entry and disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building; and 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol Building. Schwab's plea and sentencing are pending. Schwab flew to Washington D.C. on Jan. 5 with several other Texas residents, whom she called "patriots," on a private jet, on a trip arranged by her Facebook friend Jason Hyland, according to the FBI. Jenna Ryan, who has also been charged in the Capitol riot, was also on the jet, the FBI said. Schwab told the FBI during questioning that the group went to the events on the Ellipse, according to court documents, but returned to the hotel because "nothing was happening" and it was very cold outside. When they saw on TV that the Capitol had been breached, Schwab told the FBI they took an Uber over. They walked up the steps and Schwab said she was pushed by the crowds through the first set of doors and then went through a second set of doors. The FBI identified her in surveillance footage. Schwab told the FBI she was being pushed because of her small stature and that she asked a Capitol Police officer to help her leave the building. The FBI also reports that Schwab said Ryan used "very bad" words in a video she posted of Schwab inside the Capitol and that some of the videos Ryan posted made members of the group look "bad."
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Ryan, Schwab, & Hyland
Charges: *18:1725(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent entry and disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Sentenced on 4 November 2021 to 60 days' incarceration, $500.00 restitution, and a $1,000.00 fine; Chartered private plane to DC; Defendant remains released on personal recognizance
Short narrative: On June 7th, 2021, Katherine Staveley Schwab, Jason Lee Hyland, and Jennifer Leigh Ryan were indicted on charges of *18:1725(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent entry and disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building; and 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol Building. Ryan took a plea deal, pleading guilty to the charge of 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol Building. Ryan was sentenced to 60 days in prison, $500.00 restitution, and a $1,000.00 fine. Ryan, a Texas real estate broker flew on a private jet to attend the Capitol riot, and was arrested by Dallas FBI January 15, 2021. She was under investigation beginning when police found a trove of evidence online about her participation in the Jan. 6 pro-Trump riot. An FBI agent wrote in court papers that Ryan posted video footage of herself on board a private plane en route to the siege, explaining what she was prepared to do in Washington. Another video showed Ryan plug her realtor business as she and throngs of other Trump supporters stormed the Capitol building.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Dillon Colby Herrington
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2)(4) - Knowingly Engage in any act of Physical Violence Against any Person in a Restricted Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Willfully and Knowingly Engage in an act of Physical Violence on the Grounds of the Capitol Building; 18:231(a)(3) - Commit or Attempt any act to Obstruct Impede or Interfere with Law Enforcement in the Lawful Performance of his Official Duties; 18:111(a)(1) - Forcibly Assault, Resist, Opposes Impede, Intimidate or Interfere
Additional details: Resident of Alabama
Short narrative: Dillon Colby Herrington, 29, from Madison, Alabama is accused of attempting to throw a 4 by 4 piece of wood and a metal barricade at Capitol police during the January 6, 2021 riot and has been charged with a number of federal offenses.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Christian Kulas
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) and (2) Unlawful entry on restricted building and grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) and (G) Disorderly conduct on U.S. Capitol grounds
Additional details: Resident of Illinois; Sentenced 4/26/22 to six months of supervised probation, including 60 days home detention, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: Christian Kulas, 24, has been arrested and charged for his participation in the January 2021 Capitol protests. Kulas has been arrested for unlawful entry to a restricted building and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds, both misdemeanors.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Matthew Martin
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of AZ; Firts Capitol acquittal case
Short narrative: Santa Fe man, Matthew Martin, 42, was arrested and charged for his role in the Capitol protests. He pled not guilty and was the first January 6 defendant to be acquitted. According to the judge, it was reasonable for Martin to believe that outnumbered police officers allowed him and others to enter the Capitol through the Rotunda doors on Jan. 6, 2021. The judge also said Martin's actions were "about as minimal and non-serious" as anyone who was at the Capitol that day. Following his arrest he was fired as an engineer for a government contractor in Los Alamos, N.M., losing “Q” Energy Department security clearance that he held.
Source description: Local News; Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Kevin James Lyons
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(C) - Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(C) - Disruption of Official Business; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting;
Additional details: Resident of IL; Lyons was separately charged in July 2014 with obstructing a Chicago police officer; Charged by Bill of Information then Indicment
Short narrative: On February 3, 2021, Kevin James Lyons, age 40, of Chicago, Illinois, was charged with entering and remaining in a restricted building, entering and remaining in certain rooms in the Capitol Building, and disorderly donduct in the Capitol Building. Lyons entered the Capitol Building on January 6 in connection with the riots. Hisactions were motivated by his rightist: anti-government beliefs.
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, Local news articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Hunter Palm
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2),2 Obstruction of an official proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(C) Entering and remaining in certain rooms in the Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Resident of CO
Short narrative: "Palm narrated a video as he walked through the Capitol, documenting people searching for and screaming about House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, including one who stated: "We're gonna kill her." A family member identified Palm to the FBI, saying he had entered the Capitol when police allowed the crowd to enter, court records show. Palm handed over his photos and video to the FBI on a flash drive during an interview with his attorney present on Feb. 6, court records show. He also took along the clothes he'd been wearing. Although Palm told the agents he was pushed into the door of the Capitol, the FBI stated he could be seen walking into the building and holding up his phone to record, with no one pushing him. In Palm's video, as they yelled about Pelosi, the crowd approached a closed door marked "OFFICE OF THE SPEAKER." He then enters the office as someone screams an obscenity about Pelosi and then approaches a laptop on a conference room table and asks "Who's good at hacking." Eventually Palm sits down and puts his feet on the table and said "I think I like my new dining room. I pay for it."" (USA Today)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Hostetter, et al.
Charges: 18:1512(k) - Conspiracy to Obstruct Official Proceeding; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1512(c)(1) - Tampering with Documents or Proceedings;
Short narrative: "Alan Hostetter, former chief of the La Habra police department, faces charges along with fellow Californians Russell Taylor, Erik Scott Warner, Felipe Antonio “Tony” Martinez, Derek Kinnison and Ronald Mele on multiple counts. Though all are charged with being in restricted areas of the Capitol, Warner, a registered nurse, is the sole indictee to be accused of entering the building, via a broken window. Kinnison and Warner are charged with destroying evidence, while Taylor also faces a weapons count for carrying a knife with a blade longer than 3 inches.In the Hostetter case, prosecutors allege that as early as November, the six men were communicating on social media platforms including Telegram about their anger over the results of the presidential election. Kinnison, Mele, Warner and Martinez allegedly joined a chat started by Taylor in January, introducing themselves as “part of so cal 3%,” a reference to the anti-government militia known for attracting military and law enforcement members. Taylor, according to court documents, described the Telegram channel as serving as the communications point for militants traveling to the Capitol." -LATimes
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Emanuel Jackson
Charges: 18:111(a) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; 18:111(a) and (b) Obstructing or impeding certain officers; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building
Short narrative: Emanuel Jackson was arrested for his role in the 1/6/21 Capitol siege and for attacking Capital and Metropolitan police with a baseball bat. He is facing a number of charges including assault on a federal law enforcement officer with a dangerous weapon; knowingly engaging in any acts of physical violence against any person or property in any restricted building or grounds; and knowingly entering or remaining in a restricted building or grounds without lawful authority. He turned himself in on 1/18/21 after images of him were circulated by police. The affidavit claims he was one of the first to enter the Capitol and is videoed "repeatedly striking" Capitol police with a closed fist.
Source description: Charging documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Leonard Pearson Ridge IV
Charges: *18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of PA; Sentenced 1/4/22 to 14 days of incarceration, one year of supervised release, 100 hours of cmmunity service, $1,000 fine, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: Leonard Pearson "Pearce" Ridge, 19 of Pennsylvania, pled guilty to Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds and was sentenced to 14 days of prison. "In the days following Jan. 6, a confidential witness contacted the FBI, stating that Ridge uploaded multiple pictures and videos of himself inside and outside the Capitol to a Snapchat messenger group. “Currently making history,” one caption read. Additional footage and geodata show Ridge walking inside the rotunda. “I got tear gased [sic] and maced five times,” he wrote to a friend that same day in the evening. “Yeah man so epic I have a video of me fighting riot police in the capital [sic] building.”" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Sara Carpenter
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) and 2 Civil disorder and Aiding and abetting; 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding and Aiding and abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; 18:1752(a)(2); Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D); Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(E) Impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings; *40:5104(e)(2)(G); Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Richmond Hills, Queens, NY; NYPD police officer; Initially charged via Information sheet, later charged by supersceding indictment; "Sara Carpenter found guilty 3/9/23 after a trial in U.S. District Court of civil disorder, obstruction of an official proceeding, both felonies, and five misdemeanors."
Short narrative: Sara Carpenter, 51, a retired NYPD officer who lives in Queens, drove to Washington, DC to participate in the Capitol Protests. According to Department of Justice documents, On or about January 7, 2021, an anonymous tip was submitted to the FBI stating that Sara Carpenter had called a relative and stated that she was inside the Capitol Building on January 6, 2021 and was teargassed, then returned home that night. Members of FBI JTTF conducted a voluntary interview of Sara Carpenter. During this interview, Carpenter stated that she left her residence in New York and drove to Washington, D.C. on or about the evening of January 5, 2021. Carpenter said she went to the rally point where President Donald J. Trump’s Twitter page had instructed all supporters to meet to hear about the election fraud and began to walk witha large group of people to the Capitol. Carpenter stated  that she entered the Rotunda of the Capitol and told FBI agents that police were yelling for individuals to get out, then pushing and shoving the crowd. Carpenter he exited the Capitol building after she was trampled and pepper sprayed. During the January 18, 2021 interview with FBI, Carpenter stated that she had taken video of the interior of the Capitol Building on January 6, 2021 using her cellular phone and voluntarily sent me a text message containing video footage of the Capitol. Carpenter has pled not guilty and this case is currently pending.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Article, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Anton Lunyk
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of NY; Indicted by Bill of Information; "Sentenced 9/15/2022 to 12 months of probation, including two months of home confinement, $742 fine, $500 restitution, 60 hours of community service."
Short narrative:
Anton Lunyk, 26 of New York, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building and was sentenced to 12 months probation for his role in the Capitol Raid. According to the NYTimes, a phone from the White House called Lunyk on January 6, but is unknown who placed the call and whether the call was answered or went to voicemail.

"A person that went to college with Anton Lunyk contacted the FBI after recognizing him in the background of a New York Post Twitter image from the Jan. 6 U.S. Capitol riot, court documents say. The photo in which Lunyk allegedly appears is from inside the Capitol building, and it is a screenshot from a video livestreamed by well-known far-right personality Tim Gionet, known as Baked Alaska. Ahead of Jan. 6, Lunyk also allegedly posted on his Instagram account, "This is going to be an interesting next few weeks . . . who else is going to DC this week?” Law enforcement used license plate reading technology from New York City and Washington, D.C., to capture Lunyk's travel to the Capitol as well as surveillance footage from the Capitol to confirm his presence inside the building, court documents say." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. John Juran
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of NY; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Sentenced 2/23/22 to three years of probation, including two months of home detention, $500 fine, $500 in restitution.
Short narrative: John 'Jack' Juran, 51 of New York, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building and was sentenced to three years of probation for his role in the Capitol Raid. According to NPR's WBFO, "[a]uthorities said cell phone analysis indicated he was in the building for only about 10 minutes and left when told to do so by police. Juran has since expressed his regret for participating in the uprising."
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Daniel Warmus
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of NY; Marched holding 'Fuck Antifa' flag, Trump 2020 hate, and 'CNN is Fake News' sweatshirt; Claims to have smoke marijuana inside the Capitol; Indicted by Bill of Information; "Sentenced 9/27/22 to 45 days of incarceration, 24 months of probation, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: "Warmus was apprehended in Buffalo, N.Y. A tipster had reported to the FBI that they overheard him in a dentist's office talking about smoking a marijuana cigarette inside the Capitol on Jan. 6 and refusing officers requests to leave. Agents began surveillance at his home and his business and matched photos of him with video taken inside the Capitol. The FBI stated he was seen in photos taken outside the Capitol carrying a large flag on a tree branch that stated "(expletive) Antifa."" (USA Today)
Source description: Charging Documents

Other names/aliases: William Tyrone, Bill Tryon, Billy Tryon
Name of case: United States of America v. William Tryon
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Selkirk, New York; Indicted by Bill of Information; "Sentenced 1/14/22 to 50 days of incarceration, followed by 12 months of supervised relese, $1,000 fine, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: On June 21, 2021, William Tryon was indicted on charges of Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The defendant's rmade incriminating remarks on a Facebook page for a group called "Liberty Bell Alliance 76," of which Tryon is the founder, according to footage included in the complaint. Tryon accepted a plea deal in which he pled guilty to Count 1 of the charges, and was ultimately sentenced to 50 days in prison and 12 months of unsupervised released. He was also ordered to pay a $1,000.00 fine and $500.00 restitution. "A 70-year-old Coeymans man who staunchly opposes what he called "ungodly socialist forces" was arrested by the FBI on Tuesday and charged in U.S. District Court with taking part in the Jan. 6 insurrection at the U.S. Capitol in Washington, D.C. William Tryon, whose attendance at the Jan. 6 storming of the Capitol was caught on YouTube.com - and also by a relative who turned him in - was charged with three federal misdemeanors: knowingly entering a restricted building without authority, knowingly engaging in disorderly conduct in a restricted building and violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds." - Times Union.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Parks & Baggot
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:641 - Theft of government property
Additional details: Resident of TN; Indicted by Bill of Information
Short narrative: Stewart Parks, 29, of Middle Tennessee, was arrested on June 3rd in Columbia, TN, for entering the capitol building with Matthew Baggot during the January 6th riots. He was carrying a Don't Tread on Me flag and stole a handheld metal detector.

Name of case: United States of America v. Parks & Baggot
Charges: 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of TN; Indicted by Bill of Information

Name of case: United States of America v. Chase Kevin Allen
Charges: 18:1362, 2 - Destruction or injury to Buildings or Property in Special Maritime and Territorial Jurisdiction; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of MA; https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=STV3L1YxPcM
Short narrative: Chase Kevin Allen, 25, from Seekonk, Massachucetts is charged with federal crimes for his connection in the Capitol raid on January 6, 2021. Allen allegedly assaulted media personnel, smashed their equipment and made unlawful entry into the US Capitol.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Eric Bochene
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of NY; Indicted by Bill of Information
Short narrative: "Bochene is one of the people to the right in the now infamous photo of Jacob Chansley, in the horned helmet, confronting officers inside the Capitol. A tipster told the FBI that Bochene bragged that he was one of the first people in the Capitol on Jan. 5, according to court documents. Another tipster told the FBI that Bochene said he had broken a window to get into the Capitol. When interviewed by agents at his home, Bochene admitted that he was at the Capitol and showed the officers a video he had taken. Four different tipsters provided information to agents about Bochene, and the agency tracked his travels to D.C. with license plate readers." (USA Today)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Philip Edward Kramer
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:641 Theft of government property
Additional details: Resident of CA
Short narrative: On June 21, 2021, Philip Edward Kramer was indicted for his role in the Capitol riot on January 6, 2021. He confessed to attending the riot and willingly interviewed with the FBI. He brought a snowboard helmet and a walking cane into the building which he claims were for self-defense, as well as a Master Lock and climbing rope “in case someone was coming at [his] throat or something.” He also stole a "do not enter" sign from the building and disposed of it when he returned to California.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. John Maron Nassif
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of FL; Indicted by Bill of Information; "John Nassif found guilty of entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol Building."
Short narrative: John Maron Nassif, 55, from Florida, bragged on Facebook about having attended the Capitol riot. Federal officials arrested him after discovering posts where he said, "I was there." Nassif, if convicted, could face a year in prison, a year of probation, and a hefty $100,000 fine.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Articles, Governmental Reports and Releases

Name of case: United States of America v. Sean David Watson
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of TX; Wore 3% t-shirt to Capitol riot though no additional confirmation is available; Joined Oath Keepers in 2012; Also arrested 1/5/21 by MPD for "crossing a police line during a protest" accorign to affidavit; Sentencing Scheduled for 08/26/2022
Short narrative: "Sean David Watson showed a coworker videos on his cellphone that he claimed to have taken inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, court documents indicate. That coworker then called the FBI to turn him in. In an initial interview with the FBI, Watson said he had participated in the Jan. 6 rally but denied being inside the Capitol building. In a second interview with agents, the FBI seized Watson's cellphone, and he admitted that he had entered the building. On that seized phone, law enforcement found photos from inside and outside the building and texts sent shortly after the riot, one of which read "I was one of the people that helped storm the capitol building and smash out the windows . We made history today. Proudest day of my life!” According to local news reports, Watson’s home is covered with messages, including “COVID1984," “Democrats stole the election" and "Veterans for Trump." NPR was not able to confirm his military history." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Nicholas Patrick Hendrix
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of ME; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Carried sign reading "Stop the communist & terrorist revolution"; "Sentenced - 12/9/22 to 30 days incarceration, 36  months supervised release, $500 restitution"
Short narrative: "Hendrix faces charges of unlawfully entering a restricted building and disorderly or disruptive behavior inside a restricted building, which are Class A misdemeanors with a maximum penalty of one year in prison, $100,000 in fines, and one year of probation.The other two charges of violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds, and parading, demonstrating or picketing inside a Capitol building are petty misdemeanors, and carry maximum penalties of six months in prison and a $5,000 fine." - Pressherald. Hendrix, 34, turned him self in and has been reported to only have been inside the Capitol building for a minute or two.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Larry Rendall Brock
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive Conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(3),2 Impeding ingress and egress in a restricted building or grounds and aiding and abetting; 40:5104(e)(2)(A) Entering and remaining on the Floor of congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Engaging in Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct on the Capitol Buildings or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(E),2 Impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings and aiding and abetting; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capital Building
Additional details: Resident of TX; "Brock was a lieutenant colonel and an A-10 pilot in the Air Force, serving on active duty from 1989 to 1998, according to the Air Force. He retired from the Air Force Reserves in 2014." (NPR); "Larry Brock Sentenced 3/17/23 to 24 months in prison, $2,000 in restitution."
Short narrative: On January 6, 2021, in Washington, D.C., Larry Rendell Brock, 53, of Texas, was initially charged with one count each of knowingly Entering or Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Impreding Ingress and Egress in a Restricted Building or Grounds and Aiding and Abetting (later dropped); Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress, Disorderly Conduct in a Capital Building, and Impeding Passage Through the Capital Grounds or Buildings and Aiding and Abetting (later dropped). A superseding indictment charged Brock with Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capital Building. Brock, an Air Force veteran, traveled to Washington, D.C. on or about January 6th to participate and encourage forcible entry into the U.S. Capitol. Two witnesses, one of which was Brock's ex-wife, called the FBI National Threat Operations Center to report that they recognized Brock in a picture taken inside the Capitol building during the riot. He was photographed in a military-style helmet and tactical vest carrying flex cuffs.  Brock was found guilty 11/16/22 of the felony offense of obstruction of an official proceeding, and five misdemeanor offenses: entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a Capitol Building; entering and remaining on the floor of Congress; disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol Building. Brock is to be sentenced on Feb. 14, 2023.
Source description: Charging Documents, Government reports and release

Name of case: United States of America v. Kene Brian Lazo
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of VA; Indicted by a Bill of Information; $500 restitution under Plea Agreement; separately arrested on charges of rape, aggravated sexual batter of a minor under 13 years of age, and assault and battery of a family member
Short narrative: On May 28, 2021, Kene Brian Lazo, a Filipino American of Norfolk, Virginia, was arrested for his role in the January 6 riot at the Capitol. He is charged with: Knowingly Entering or Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority, Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority, Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds or in a Capitol Building, and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The FBI investigated him and learned of his participation through Facebook, where he went by "Fam Council".
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles, Governmental Reports and Releases

Name of case: United States of America v. Kurt Peterson
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1361 - Destruction of Government Property; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of KY; Sentenced to 30 days incarceration and $500 restitution
Short narrative: "On Jan. 10, Kurt Peterson alllegedly posted a lengthy message on Facebook indicating that he had been inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6. The message, detailed in court documents, begins: "To my family and friends who are able to see this, I am writing it with a voice recognition program while driving. I feel the need to keep moving and trying to keep my phone wrapped such that it can’t be traced most of the time." He then described the pro-Trump rally as peaceful and loving, but added "When there are huge crowds and there are people that are inciting violence, the crowds will many times be pulled in to this action." In the post, Peterson reportedly stated that he was with three military veterans and that he was not there to hurt anybody or damage anything, but was there as a "show of solidarity to right the wrongs of the past election." According to court documents, Peterson indicated that he was there when a woman, presumably Ashli Babbitt, was fatally shot by police. Peterson reportedly added that "Nonlethal force could have been used without the lethal shot that was made by this bodyguard in the speaker's lobby" and that he offered to provide first aid but was denied. Phone records obtained from Samsung reportedly place Peterson in the Capitol that day as well. He also appeared in police body camera footage and in at least two publicly posted videos, including one from the location where Babbitt was shot, according to court documents. In one video, Peterson can allegedly be seen using his fist to smash a window on the outside of the Capitol and shouting, “This is our house. Let us in. Our house.” (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Governmental Reports and Releases

Name of case: United States of America v. Savannah Danielle McDonald, Nolan Harold Kidd
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Wearing Trump hat; Photographed holding a handwritten sign reading "If the dead can vote just wait and see what the living can do"; Indicted by Bill of Information; Sentenced 5/10/22 to 21 days in jail, $500 in restitution
Short narrative: "Savannah McDonald and Nolan Kidd allegedly traveled together to Washington, D.C., the day before the assault on the U.S. Capitol. According to court documents, they can be seen in many of the most familiar photos of Jan. 6 -- near the man who became known as the “QAnon Shaman.” On Jan. 14, the FBI received a tip that McDonald had been inside the Capitol building and then interviewed her at her home days later. Court documents say that when she was shown a picture from the riot, McDonald acknowledged that the person circled in it was her. A photo returned from a search of Kidd’s phone shows pictures of the two smiling for the camera. In a video posted by the Young Patriot Society and credited to Kidd, McDonald allegedly can be seen with Kidd, confirming they were “part of the first 100 people to enter the Capitol.” Agents also reviewed video footage of Kidd and McDonald heading to the Upper West Terrace of the Capitol, with McDonald holding a sign above her head reading, “If the dead can vote just wait and see what the living can do,” court documents say. Kidd and McDonald, along with a group of rioters, allegedly pushed through a line of law enforcement and headed into the building through a fire door. A search warrant for a Snapchat account McDonald claimed was hers returned images of a group video chat in which McDonald reportedly says, “I’m the only girl that made it into the Senate.”" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Releases

Name of case: United States of America v. Savannah Danielle McDonald, Nolan Harold Kidd
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Wearing MAGA hat; Indicted by Bill of Information; Sentenced 5/9/22 to 45 days in jail, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: "Nolan Kidd and Savannah McDonald allegedly traveled together to Washington, D.C., the day before the assault on the U.S. Capitol. According to court documents, they can be seen in many of the most familiar photos of Jan. 6 -- near the man who became known as the “QAnon Shaman.” On Jan. 11, the FBI received a tip that Kidd had been inside of the Capitol building, which included a screenshot of an account believed to be his, showing an album of pictures of the day captioned, “Just made it home, I have tons of photos and videos to share with you guys.” Federal prosecutors say that agents interviewed Kidd at his home days later, and he said that “the doors to the U.S. Capitol were wide open.” A photo returned from a search of Kidd’s phone shows pictures of him and McDonald smiling for the camera, and Kidd showing a “thumbs up.” Kidd can also reportedly be seen in a video posted by the Young Patriot Society and credited to himself, alongside McDonald saying, “[W]e got in from the back.” Agents also reviewed video footage of Kidd and McDonald allegedly heading to the Upper West Terrace of the Capitol with a group of rioters that pushed through a line of law enforcement and headed into the building through a fire door. A search warrant for a Snapchat account McDonald claimed was hers returned images of a group chat in which a user believed to be Kidd reportedly says, “Me and Savannah are F***ING STORMTROOPERS.”" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Releases

Name of case: United States of America v. Michael Adams
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of VA; Indicted by Bill of Information; Defendant was arrested 4/22/21 and released on personal recognizance - information filed 6/24/21 and arraignment dates set for 7/8/21 and 7/16/21 where defendant failed to appear; Considered a fugitive according to the DOJ as of 06/22/22
Short narrative: "Adams carried a longboard skateboard with orange wheels and a large blue flag with him to the Capitol, the FBI stated in court documents. He was seen inside the Capitol in video footage at 2:46, 2:49 and 2:59 p.m., according to the FBI, and again in body-worn camera video on the steps at 4:21 p.m. The FBI also used a geofence with cell phone data to determine that Adams was within the Capitol grounds from 2:45 to 4:59 p.m. A witness reported him to the FBI, which identified him by a drivers license photo and a booking photo taken on Jan. 5 for something unrelated to the Capitol charges." (USA Today)
Source description: Charging Documents, Governmental Reports and Releases

Name of case: District of Columbia v. Alexander Samuel Kimmich
Charges: 24:2203.4DCMR Violation of Emergency Order or Regulation - Curfew
Additional details: Resident of MD
Short narrative: Alexander Kimmich, 21, of MD, was arrested in DC and is facing a charge of curfew violation as recorded in MPD "Unrest-Related Arrest Data as of January 7 2021". His case is still pending.
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, Local news articles, Other (MPD arrest data)

Name of case: District of Columbia v. Daniel Cleene
Charges: 24 DCMR 2203.4 Curfew Violation; 24 DCMR 2100.3Crossing Police Line
Additional details: Resisent of Wisconsin
Short narrative: Daniel Cleene, 60, of Wisconsin, was arrested for violating curfew as well as crossing police lines, both misdemeanors. Cleene was charged accordingly with Violation of emergency order or regulation - curfew, and Crossing police lines, entering police area.
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, Local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Trevor Brown
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of MI
Short narrative: "At least three people contacted the FBI after seeing posts on Trevor Brown's Facebook and Instagram accounts indicating he participated in the Jan. 6 riot at the U.S. Capitol, including breaching the building, according to court documents. Brown is allegedly seen in multiple videos from the day, including one where he is yelling through a bullhorn as rioters attempt to breach a tunnel going into the building, court documents indicate. Shortly after that video was taken, police apprehended Brown and placed him in handcuffs, but he was later released without any charges being filed. On Jan. 7, Brown allegedly posted on Facebook, "People should be storming that Brothel we call the Capitol everyday for what goes on in there. ... Today thise [sic] elitist creeps are getting the same thing we live with everyday, fear for their own safety." In another post, he reportedly wrote, "I made it into the Capitol. I almost died getting in but I made it.” Since at least November, Brown had posted content on social media that questioned the legitimacy of the presidential election, court documents indicate." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Samuel Christopher Fox
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Indicted by a Bill of Information; Sentenced 4/5/22 to 36 months of probation, including 60 days home detention, $2,500 fine, $500 restitution
Short narrative: Samuel Christopher Fox, 32 from Pennsylvania, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building and was sentenced to 36 months of probation for his role in the Capitol Raid. He posted pictures and videos of himself inside the Capitol and bragged about being one of the first ones inside. He has since deleted these posts and videos. He allegedly admitted to stealing paperwork as well.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Mark Grods
Charges: 18:371 - Conspiracy; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting;
Additional details: Indicted by Bill of Information; Coordinated with Oath Keepers via Signal and provided firearms to be stored in a VA hotel
Short narrative: "Federal prosecutors allege that Mark Grods coordinated with members of the extremist anti-government militia known as the Oath Keepers to interfere with the certification of the Electoral College vote on Jan. 6. Ahead of the Capitol riot, court documents state, Grods joined a group chat named on the encrypted messaging app Signal called "DC OP: Jan 6 21." Grods "brought firearms to Washington, D.C., and eventually provided them to another individual to store in a Virginia hotel," while Grods stayed with other members of the group at the Mayflower Hotel in D.C., prosecutors say. While the Capitol riot was ongoing, Grods allegedly rode in a golf cart with others members of the Oath Keepers to the Capitol, then breached the building while carrying what prosecutors describe as a "large stick." Soon after, Grods exited the building as law enforcement used pepper balls to try to force people out of the Capitol, the court documents state. Later, he allegedly met with other members of the Oath Keepers outside the Capitol building, and, in the days after the riot, said he had deleted his messages on Signal. As part of a plea agreement, Grods has agreed to testify in court and sit for interviews with investigators." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Zvonimir Joseph Jurlina
Charges: 18:1362, 2 - Destruction of property in special maritime and territorial jurisdiction and aiding and abetting; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Descibed as "white supremecist streamer" by anti-fascist researchers; Particiapted in attacks on media stationed at Capitol; Resident of NY
Short narrative: "The charges brought against Zvonimir Jurlina center on events that happened in the late afternoon of Jan. 6 at the media staging area outside the northeast corner of the U.S. Capitol. An individual, identified by the FBI as Jurlina and seen in photographs posted on the FBI's website, participated in an assault on the area where the media had gathered. Jurlina allegedly incited "violent acts," along with others in the crowd, that forced members of the media to disperse and abandon their equipment. The photos show him allegedly kicking and stomping on equipment belonging to media outlets and assisting in an attempt to set fire to some of the equipment. In a 12-part video series livestreamed on YouTube, Jurlina documents the incidents cited in the charging documents, including a moment where Jurlina says, “This is reporter Zykotik coming to you live. We are, haha. This is the real news media network. We have taken over. This is mother f**king America first."" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Lesperance, Cusick & Cusick
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of FL; Indicted by a Bill of Information
Short narrative: On June 29, 2021, James "Jim" Varnell Cusick Jr., 72, and his son Casey Cusick, 35, who lead the Global Outreach Ministries church in Melbourne, were indicted on charges of 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. David Lesperance, 69, a member of their church, was with them at the Capitol and was arrested on similar charges. Plea and sentencing data is pending for James Varnell Cusick Jr.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Ariticles

Name of case: United States of America v. Lesperance, Cusick & Cusick
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of FL; Indicted by Bill of Information; Remains on personal recognizance
Short narrative: On June 29, 2021, Casey Cusick, 35, and his father James "Jim" Varnell Cusick Jr., 72, who lead the Global Outreach Ministries church in Melbourne, were indicted on charges of 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. David Lesperance, 69, a member of their church, was with them at the Capitol and was arrested on similar charges. Casey Cusick plead not guilty, and sentencing data is pending.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Ariticles

Name of case: United States of America v. Lesperance, Cusick & Cusick
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of FL; Interviewed by JTTF; Indicted by Bill of Information; Remains on personal recognizance
Short narrative: On June 29, 2021, David Lesperence was charged with 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building, following his involvement in the January 6th, 2021 Capitol riot. Lesperance, 69, was allegedly accompanying James "Jim" Varnell Cusick Jr., 72, and his son Casey Cusick, 35, at the Capitol. Lesperence has plead not guilty to the charges and sentencing data is pending.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Ariticles

Name of case: United States of America v. Andrew Alan Hernandez
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(B) Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Expressed support for QAnon; Signed up as an Oath Keepers in 2012; "A review of the accounts suggests that Hernandez adheres to multiple ideologies including: Q-Anon, health and science related conspiracies, financial conspiracies, and various conspiracies associated to US political figures" (Statement of Facts); "Sentenced 1/30/23 to 18 months in prison, 36 months of supervised release and $2,000 restitution"
Short narrative: "The Evansville, Indiana Courier Press reported in January that Vinson was fired from her job as a nurse at Ascension St. Vincent hospital in Evansville on Jan. 8, after her employers found out she was one of the Capitol rioters. Vinson told the newspaper that she and her husband, Thomas, went to Washington D.C. for the Stop the Steal rally and the big plan was to leave from there and walk to the Capitol building. The newspaper reported Vinson and her husband spent about 35 minutes inside the Capitol and she felt she didn't do anything wrong. She said: "No one told us to leave, even the police. The police were, I don’t even want to say there was a police presence. They were interacting with people. People were still coming in the doors as we were there. Cops were standing at different doors, none of them saying, 'You can’t come in here."" (USA Today)
Source description: Charging documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Brian Mock
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; 18:1752(a)(1),(2) Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 18:231(a)(3) Obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorders; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in any of the Capitol buildings or grounds
Short narrative: Brian Mock, 42, is charged in Washington D.C. with assaulting a federal officer; unlawful entry on restricted buildings or grounds; and acts of physical violence on Capitol grounds.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Jonathan Davis Laurens
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(A) - Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of GA; Indicted by a Bill of Information; took a plea deal 2/2/22; Sentenced 6/10/22 to 60 days of home detention, 12 months of probation, 60 hours of community service, $742 fine, $500 in restitution.
Short narrative: "According to court documents, the FBI received at least seven tips that Jonathan Laurens was inside the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6. Federal prosecutors allege he wore a bright orange winter hat, a black face mask and a “Trump 2020: No More Bulls***” flag as a cape. Court documents include a number of images that seem to show Laurens inside the Capitol. Documents also show that Laurens posted to his Facebook page about the riot, saying, “we got into the capitol (sic), walked around, chanted some slogans and stuff. A few bad apples were trying to break windows and kick on doors, but most of us put that s**t to bed real fast. We weren’t there to tear s**t up, just disrupt the system. All in all, I had fun! Lol.” Prosecutors say Laurens’ account was public when they reviewed it in April and posts related to the riot were still visible. The FBI also served Facebook with a search warrant for Laurens’ account. A review of the account turned up a selfie Laurens took with the Lansdowne portrait of George Washington in what appears to be the Rayburn Reception Room inside the Capitol, court documents indicate." (NPR) After speaking with Laurens Co worker, police found that his co-worker John Gould also attended the protests.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Suzanna Ianni
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Indicted by a Bill of Information; Member of Super Happy Fun America and organizer of the Boston 'Straight Pride' parade; Resident of Natick, Massachusets; Sentenced 12/2 to 15 days of incarceration, 30 months of probation, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: Suzanne Ianni, 59, of Natick, Massachusetts pled guilty to Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building. Ianni is a senior member of of Super Happy Fun America (formerly ResistMarxism), a group that advocates for the "straight community". Ianni was pictured on a chartered bus with members of SHFA on the night on January 5th. On January 6th she was seen entering the Capitol building. Ianni and Sahady are involved in Super Happy Fun America together and coordinated their joint trip to the Capitol riot. She was sentenced on 12/2/2022 to 15 days of incarceration, 30 months of probation, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution. [NOTE: Sahady and Ianni are not charged together]
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Kenneth John Reda
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering or Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of FL; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Sentenced 3/30/22 to three years or probation, including 60 days of home detention and 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution
Short narrative: Kenneth John Reda, 54 of Florida, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building and was sentenced to three years of probation in connection with the Capitol Riot. He used Parler to communicate his success in entering the Capitol building. He is a physical education teacher at Viera High School in Florida. On Parler, he wrote "We have got to get to DC on January 6th it is IMPERATIVE every single person that VOTED for Trump has to flood DC." His presence in the Capitol was corroboated by CCTV footage inside the building and Gmail account data.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Anthony Michael Puma
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of Brownstown Township, MI; "Anthony Puma sentenced 3/21/23 in the District of Columbia to nine months in prison for obstruction of an official proceeding, two years of supervised release, a $500 fine, and restitution of $2,000."
Short narrative: Anthony Michael Puma, 49, of Brownstown Township, MI, was charged with Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; in relation to his role in the January 6th riot. An anonymous tip was submitted to the FBI Puma's involvement. The FBI was then able to locate publically available photos on Puma's Facbook of his participation in the riot. Puma was wearing a GoPro during his participation and live streamed his participation to his Facebook. Federal agents accused Puma of scaling a wall outside the Capitol, breaking in through a window and encouraging others involved in the insurrection, according to an FBI statement obtained by The Detroit News. This case is currently pending.
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, Local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Jackman, et al.
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder
Additional details: Was a police officer at the time of event; Resident of FL; Father also arrested; Released on personal recognizance
Short narrative: Nathaniel Tuck, 29, has been arrested and faces several charges following his participation in the Capitol riots on 6 January 2021. Tuck, a member of the Proud Boys and former officer with the Apopka Police Department, allegedly joined the group after watching hours of antifa videos on YouTube. Tuck has pled not guilty to all charges, and is currently released on personal recognizance.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Jackman, et al.
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(B) - Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:641, 2 - Theft of government property
Additional details: Resident of FL; Remains on personal recognizance
Short narrative: Arthur Jackman, 30, and four others face several charges following their participation in the U.S. Capitol riots on 6 January 2021. Jackman, who at one point reportedly served as vice president of the Central Florida Proud Boys, was seen in news footage taking a selfie inside the Senate chamber, and texted a selfie to a childhood friend who messaged him to ask if he was involved in the riot. The accompanying text from Jackman read, “We stormed and took over,” according to a screenshot in the report. Jackman allegedly also stole an American flag and a flagpole of less than $1,000 in value. The defendant has pleaded not guilty to all charges, and is currently released on personal recognizance.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Jackman, et al.
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of FL; Remains on personal recognizance
Short narrative: Paul Rae, 38, and four others face several charges following their participation in the U.S. Capitol riots on 6 January 2021. Rae, who a prosecutor described as an "associate" to the Proud Boys, allegedly entered the Capitol building seconds after another Proud Boys member smashed a window. Rae has pleaded not guilty to all charges, and is currently released on personal recognizance while he awaits sentencing. Rae has since been charged with a BUI, boating under the influence while back in Florida, this charge has been noted that it could have a bearing on his pending federal case and release status connected with the Capitol charges.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Jackman, et al.
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(B) - Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:641, 2 - Theft of government property;
Additional details: Resident of FL; Remains on personal recognizance
Short narrative: Edward George Jr., 33, and four others face several charges following their participation in the U.S. Capitol riots on 6 January 2021.
