Name of case: United States of America v. Jackman, et al.
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(B) - Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Was a police officer at the time of event; Resident of FL; Son was also arrested and charged; Remains on personal recognizance
Short narrative: Kevin A. Tuck, 51, has been charged with Obstruction of an official proceeding, aiding and abetting, Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, Entering and remaining in the gallery of Congress, Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, and Parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building following his participation in the Capitol riots on 6 January 2021. Tuck, a member of the Proud Boys and former officer for the Windermere Police Department, posted a Youtube video after his arrest in which he called for conservatives to “rise up,” raging against Republicans and what he considers “alternative lifestyles.” “The Republican Party is weak,” Kevin Tuck said. “We need to rise up and be conservative again. Do you remember what conservative means, Republicans? Hear me out: We are embracing the homosexual lifestyle as if this is normal.” Tuck has pleaded non guilty to all charges, and is currently released on personal recognizance.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Reed Knox Christensen
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of OR
Short narrative: "Reed Knox Christensen, 62, of Hillsboro, is charged with federal offenses that include forcibly assaulting, resisting, impeding or interfering with law enforcement; engaging in an act of physical violence in a Capitol building; and entering or remaining on restricted grounds without lawful authority, among other charges. According to court documents, Christensen was on the Lower West Terrace of the Capitol grounds where U.S. Capitol Police (USCP) were protecting the building from rioters. Surveillance and body worn camera (BWC) footage shows Christensen striking and pushing officers and initiating the aggressive removal of metal bike rack barriers. At approximately 2:20 p.m., Christensen tried to breach the barrier when a Metropolitan Police Department Officer (MPD) sprayed him with a chemical irritant. Despite the spray to his face, Christensen charged through the perimeter, away from officers, and struck a USCP officer with his fists." -DOJ
Source description: Governmental Reports and Release, Local News, Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Sean Michael McHugh
Charges: 18:111(a)(1), 2 - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers, Aiding and Abetting; 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of CA
Short narrative: On May 27, 2021, Sean Michael McHugh, 34, from Auburn, California was charged with federal offenses that include assault on law enforcement with a deadly or dangerous weapon, obstruction of justice, and physical violence on Capitol grounds, among other charges in connection with the U.S. Capitol riot on January 6, 2020. He was seen on Metropolitan Police Department body cameras assaulting US Capitol Police officers, including him spraying them with an unknown, yellow chemical spray.
Source description: Charging Documents, Governmental Reports and Release, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Anthony Joseph Scirica
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of Winston-Salem, NC; Indicted by Bill of Information; "as to Count 4, that the Defendant is sentenced to 15 days on incarceration (7 intermittent weekends), with credit for time served (1 day). The Defendant is furthered ordered to pay a $500 fine and $500 in restitution. Government's oral motion to dismiss the remaining counts of the information is hereby GRANTED. Counts 1-4 are dismissed."
Short narrative: Anthony Joseph Scirica, 25, of NC, was charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for his role in the January 6th Capitol riot.  Scirica was identified to law enforcement by at least two former co-workers as having been inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6. An additional tipster provided Scirica's Snapchat stories of his participation in the riot. Capitol security footage and location records obtained from Verizon also place Scirica in the Capitol that day. Scirica accepted a plea deal, pleading guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Scirica was sentenced to 15 days of incarceration, $500 fine, $500 restitution.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental reports and release (DOJ), News article

Name of case: United States of America v. Brian E. Stenz
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Indicted by a Bill of Information; Stenz pleaded guilty in January in Montgomery County Magisterial District Court to providing false statements while attempting to purchase a pistol in 2018 from a ; Sentenced 2/17/22 to 36 months of probation, including 14 consecutive days of incarceration and two months of home detention, $2,500 fine, $500 restitution.West Norriton Township gun store. Though he had pleaded guilty in 2007 to stalking, he answered “No” on his firearms forms when asked about previous convictions. He was sentenced to one year of probation.
Short narrative: Brian E. Stenz, 51, from Norristown PA, has been arrested and charged for his role in the Capitol protests.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Andrew William Griswold
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of justice/congress; 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Knowingly engaging in disorderly or disruptive conduct in restricted building; 40:5104(e)(2)(B) Entering and remaining in the gallery of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Resident of FL; "Sentenced 7/13/22 to 75 days in jail, two years of supervised release, $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative: Andrew William Griswold, 28, of Niceville, Florida turned himself in to authorities on charges relating to the Capitol protests on January 6, 2021. He faces charges of knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; obstruction of justice/Congress; and knowingly engaging in disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Richard T. Crosby, Jr.
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(A) Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

Crosby Jr. was charged with obstruction of justice, specifically of Congress; knowing, entering and remaining in a restricted grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted grounds; entering and or remaining on the floor of Congress; parading, demonstrating or picketing at the Capitol.

Name of case: United States of America v. Caleb Berry
Charges: 18:371 - Conspiracy; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting
Additional details: Resident of FL, Member of Oath Keeper
Short narrative: Caleb Berry, 20, from Tampa, Florida, an Oath Keeper affliate pleaded guilty to conspiracy and breaching the US Capitol on January 6, 2021. He plead guilty to one count of conspiracy and one count of obstruction of an official proceeding.
Source description: Charging Documents, Governmental Reports and Releases, News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Devlyn Thompson
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:111(b) - Assault on a Federal Officer;
Additional details: Resident of WA; Attorneys said in a court filing that he has autism spectrum disorder.
Short narrative: "Devlyn Thompson, 28, of Seattle, Washington, was among a crowd of individuals on the lower west terrace who were pushing against and assaulting MPD and U.S. Capitol Police (USCP) officers in the tunnel leading into the U.S. Capitol. Thompson admitted that he and others in the tunnel yelled obscenities at police and encouraged the continued assault. According to his plea, Thompson was part of a group that threw objects and projectiles at the officers, including flag poles, and grabbed and stole the officers’ riot shields to prevent them from defending themselves against the violence. Thompson personally observed police order rioters to stop, physically push the crowd back and deploy pepper spray in an effort to try to stop the ongoing assault. Later, Thompson picked up a metal baton from the floor of the tunnel and swung it overhead and downward against the police line in an apparent effort to knock a can of pepper spray from an officer’s hand and stop the officer from pepper-spraying the rioters. After more pepper spray was deployed by the rioters and the officers, Thompson retreated from the archway area...Thompson pleaded guilty to a criminal information charging him with assaulting, resisting or impeding officers while using a dangerous weapon. He is scheduled to be sentenced on Sept. 27 at 2 p.m. He faces up to 20 years in prison, as well as three years of supervised release and a $250,000 fine." (DOJ press release)
Source description: Charging Documents, Governmental Reports and Releases

Name of case: United States of America v. Brittiany Angelina Dillon
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds
Additional details: Resident of MD; Indicted by Bill of Information; 60 days home detention, 3 years probation, $500 restitution
Short narrative: Brittiany Angelina Dillon, 35 of California, pled guilty to Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building and Grounds and was sentenced to three years of probation. "Dillon texted back and forth with accused rioter Bryan Betancur in the days leading up to the riot and on Jan. 6, according to federal charging documents. The pair had been texting back and forth about election fraud and plans to attend the rally in the days leading up to the siege at the Capitol. "I was there. I got pepper sprayed at the door of the capital and tear gassed 3 times making my way up to it," she stated in one text on Jan. 6. "I fought hard .. I fell in the door and they tried to beat me with batons so I backed off and they pepper sprayed my eyes." Video footage from the Capitol shows her pushing through the crowd trying to get into the Capitol, and at one point she fell over the threshold, an FBI agent stated in the documents. She pushed forward against law enforcement again but was eventually repelled by an officer with a baton." (USA Today)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Munn, et al.
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of TX; Family of 5 charged; picture of family trailer from Tom Munn's Facebook page appeared to show him hauling a trailer with a QAnon sign posted on the back; "Sentenced 10/12/22 to 36 months of probation, including 90 days of home confinement, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution"
Short narrative: On January 9, 2021, the FBI received information from a tipster that Kristi Munn entered the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021. During a follow-up interview, the tipster reported that Kristi Munn and other members of her family traveled from Texas to Washington, D.C. for the rally that occurred on January 6, 2021.One of the Facebook screenshots provided by the tipster was a post of a photograph of Kristi Munn and five additional individuals who were “tagged” in the post as Facebook users Tom Munn, Dawn Munn, Kayli Munn, Minor Child 1, and Josh Munn. For her participation in the U.S. Capitol riot on January 6, 2021, Kristi was charged with knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a U.S. Capitol building and parading, demonstrating or picketing in a U.S. Capitol building.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local news

Additional details: Resident of TX; Family of 5 charged; picture of family trailer from Tom Munn's Facebook page appeared to show him hauling a trailer with a QAnon sign posted on the back; "Sentenced 10/12/22 to 36 months of probation, including 14 days of intermittent incarceration to be served in two 7-day periods, 90 days of home confinement, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution"
Short narrative: On January 9, 2021, the FBI received information from a tipster that Kristi Munn entered the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021. During a follow-up interview, the tipster reported that Kristi Munn and other members of her family traveled from Texas to Washington, D.C. for the rally that occurred on January 6, 2021.One of the Facebook screenshots provided by the tipster was a post of a photograph of Kristi Munn and five additional individuals who were “tagged” in the post as Facebook users Tom Munn, Dawn Munn, Kayli Munn, Minor Child 1, and Josh Munn.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local news

Name of case: United States of America v. Erik Rau
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of OH; Sentenced to 45 days incarceration and a $500 restitution
Short narrative: "In February, Erik Rau’s friend Derek Jancart was arrested in connection with the Jan. 6 insurrection, court documents show. Jancart told prosecutors he entered the U.S. Capitol with Rau, and the FBI says Jancart identified Rau in photos from the Capitol. On the same day of Jancart's arrest, Rau called the U.S. Marshals Service in Columbus, Ohio, asking to turn himself in, according to court documents. Both Jancart and Rau gave the FBI Rau’s phone number, according to prosecutors. The FBI says that it served a search warrant on Google, and that a mobile device associated with Rau’s number was determined to be in the Capitol for 39 minutes on Jan. 6." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Jon Mott
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of AK
Short narrative: "Mott is seen on body-worn camera video telling a Metropolitan Police Department officer: "Don't touch me," and "If you don't touch me, I won't touch you," before pushing against the officer's baton, the FBI stated in court documents. Mott was identified by a tattoo on his left ring finger and three witnesses, based in part on Facebook posts from an unidentified individual who traveled with him to Washington D.C., the FBI stated. A screenshot provided to the agency shows that unnamed individual thanked people for helping sponsor their trip. The FBI provided a screenshot of Mott's wife's Facebook page where she posted a link to a Go Fund Me page. Documents show the FBI obtained a cached version of the Go Fund Me page, indicating the unnamed individual, who lives in El Reno, Oklahoma, had organized the page." (USA Today)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Michael Leon Brock
Charges: 18:111(a) and (b) (Felony) - Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings; 18:231(a)(3) Obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder
Additional details: Resident of Mississippi
Short narrative: Michael Leon Brock, 54, or Walls Mississippi was arrested for his crimes related to the breach og the US Capitol on Jan 6. He is charged with federal offenses that include assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers and obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder, among other charges. He charged at law enforcement officers while holding what appeared to be a four-foot-long rod as the officers attempted to control the crowd. Michael Brock also has no known relationship with Larry Brock, another Capitol riot defendant from Texas.
Source description: Governmental Reports and Release, Local News, Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Lois Lynn McNicoll
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Wore Trump hat and California flag as cape; Resident of CA; "Sentenced 9/6/22 to 24 months of probation, 80 hours of community service, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Lois Lynn McNicoll, 69, of San Clemente, was arrested on federal charges of knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority and violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds. She travelled from California to DC in order to watch President Trump's speech and later join the protests happening at the Capitol building.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Shane Jason Woods
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:113(a)(4) - Assault in Special Maritime and Territorial Jurisdiction; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 18:113(a)(5) - Simple Assault within the Territorial Jurisdiction;
Additional details: Resident of IL
Short narrative: Shane Jason Woods, 43, resident of IL, has been arrested and charged for his role in the January 2021 Capitol protests. He was charged with assault on a law enforcement officer, assault in special maritime and territorial jurisdiction, obstructing, impeding or interfering with law enforcement during civil disorder, being in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds, violent entry or disorderly conduct and act of physical violence on grounds. He was the first to be arrested for assault on members of news media during the U.S. Capitol riot on January 6, 2021.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Edward Francisco Rodriguez
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Identified by Reddit investigators as #SUITMACER
Short narrative: "Reddit users dubbed Edward Francisco Rodriguez “#SUITMACER” based on a video in which he sprays a chemical irritant at law enforcement officers while dressed in a suit, federal prosecutors say. Videos on Reddit and Twitter also showed Rodriguez giving interviews to reporters, according to court documents. In one video, the FBI says Rodriguez said, “Here in America, we fight back. We will never surrender to dictatorship, corruption, communism or socialism. We the people will never put up with their bullshit.” Court documents show that tipsters identified Rodriguez based on his Century 21 Real Estate profile. The FBI says two former co-workers were also able to confirm Rodriguez’s identity in the videos." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Kerry Wayne Persick
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of TX; Indicted by Bill of Information; "Sentenced 7/14/22 to 36 months of probation, including 90 days of home detention, $5,000 fine, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: "On the very day of the Capitol riot, a tipster sent a note to the FBI identifying Kerry Wayne Persick, who was wearing a red Make America Great Again ballcap in the crowd, the agency stated in charging documents. The FBI was able to identify Persick in surveillance video inside the Capitol, and then obtained a search warrant for phone records that place him at the Capitol, documents show. Persick was arrested in Fort Worth, Texas." (USA Today)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Noah S. Bacon
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(B) - Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting;
Additional details: Resident of MA; Wore 'I love Trump shirt'; "Noah Bacon found guilty on 3/3/23 on all charges by unanimous jury"
Short narrative: "Noah Bacon was reported to the FBI after he allegedly appeared in a video published by The New Yorker. In the video, prosecutors say, Bacon can be seen opening a door to the balcony area of the U.S. Senate Chamber inside the Capitol for himself and others. Bacon allegedly spent about 10 minutes in the chamber, sitting in the back row in an "I ♥ Trump" t-shirt, fist-bumping others. Verizon phone records obtained by the FBI also place Bacon in the Capitol that day, as does security camera footage, court documents indicate. On Instagram the day before the riot, Bacon allegedly posted about his plans to go to "Trump's special Jan 6th event" and that "we are on the precipice of something beautiful."" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Jamie N. Buteau, Jennifer Peck Buteau
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of FL; Wife also arrested
Short narrative: "Footage inside the U.S. Capitol building allegedly shows Jamie Buteau throwing a chair at two U.S. Capitol Police officers as they are retreating from the crowd, hitting one of the officers. Multiple tipsters, including a family member, contacted the FBI identifying both Jamie Buteau and his wife, Jennifer Peck Buteau, as having been inside the building on Jan. 6, based on live videos they posted on Facebook that were later deleted, according to court documents. Other footage also allegedly shows Jamie Buteau dragging a second chair after the first incident, which he ends up leaving in one of the hallways. An additional tipster alerted the FBI that both Buteaus appeared in HBO’s Vice News Tonight report from August 2018 on QAnon believers. The FBI later confirmed that the video indeed featured the husband and wife." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Jamie N. Buteau, Jennifer Peck Buteau
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of FL; Husband also arrested
Short narrative: "Jennifer Peck Buteau entered the U.S. Capitol building, alongside her husband, through a broken door on Jan. 6, according to court documents. Her husband is allegedly seen on footage from inside the Capitol assaulting two police officers by throwing a chair at them, and hitting one, as they were trying to move away from the rioters. Multiple tipsters, including a family member, contacted the FBI and reported that Buteau had posted live Facebook videos from within the building that she later deleted. “Antifa was infiltrating Trump supporters for the cameras, to cause Chaos,” Buteau allegedly wrote on Facebook. An additional tipster alerted the FBI that both Buteaus appeared in HBO’s Vice News Tonight report from August 2018 on QAnon believers. The FBI later confirmed that the video indeed featured the couple." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Nicholas L. Kennedy
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of MO
Short narrative: "Few details have been released about Nicholas Kennedy's role in the insurrection at the U.S. Capitol. Kennedy, also known as "Nick," was arrested on July 28 and made his first appearance in federal court on Aug. 5." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Ryan Seth Suleski
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of VA; "Sentenced 10/14/22 to 60 days of incarceration,  60 hours community service, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Suleski says that he was in the initial wave of people that forced their way into the Capitol building.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. William Michael Sywak, William Jason Sywak
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Son also arrested; Indicted by Bill of Information; Sentenced 6/9/22 to 24 months of probation, including four months of home detention, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution
Short narrative: "In an interview with the FBI, William Michael Sywak said he and his son traveled to Washington, D.C., together to "see the protests" on Jan. 6, but he denied going inside the U.S. Capitol building. However, law enforcement later placed Sywak inside the Capitol that day through surveillance footage, a YouTube video and Google location records, court documents indicate. During the interview, FBI agents showed Sywak a photo of himself on the U.S. Capitol grounds and he confirmed to the agents that it was him, saying he was surprised his hair looked so neat, since he had been wearing a beanie." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Jeremy Grace
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly conduct in a restricted building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in the Capitol building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Resident of WA; Sentenced 7/8/22 to 21 days in jail,  12 months of  supervised release, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: Jeremy Grace, 37 of Washington, and his father, Jeffrey Grace, were arrested and charged for their role in the Capitol riot. Jeremy Grace pled guilty to Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds and was sentenced to 21 days in prison. They were among the first people to enter the Capitol and took selfies.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. William Michael Sywak, William Jason Sywak
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Father also arrested; Indicted by Bill of Information
Short narrative: "William Jason Sywak traveled to Washington, D.C., from New York to "see the protests" on Jan. 6, according to an FBI interview with his father, who traveled with him. Law enforcement also identified the younger Sywak in surveillance footage and police body camera footage from inside and outside the U.S. Capitol that day, court documents indicate." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. William Rogan Reid
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1361 - Destruction of Government Property; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:1512(c)(1) - Tampering with Documents or Proceedings; 18:1512(c)(1) - Corruptly Altering, Destroying, Mutilating, or Concealing a Record, Document, or Other Object;
Additional details: "William Reid Found guilty by Court on 8/23/22 of obstruction of an official proceeding and corruptly altering, destroying, mutilating, or concealing a record, document, or other objects, both felonies, as well as five related misdemeanor offenses. Misdemeanors include entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; destruction of government property; disorderly and dispruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol Building, Defendant agreed to a stipulated set of facts."; "Sentenced 12/8/22 to an aggregate term of thirty-seven (37) months of incarceration, thirty-six (36) months of supervised release, $2,443 in restitution and $295 special assessment."
Short narrative: ""The 6th was our Boston Tea Party," Reid said in a March 11, 2021 post on Instagram, according to court records. He followed up with a post on March 13, saying "I rushed the Capitol," the FBI stated. The agency's search of AT&T records show Reid's phone was in the Capitol on Jan. 6. Agents also said they located Reid in publicly available video inside the Capitol." (USA Today)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Anthony Antonio
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1361, 2 - Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(C) - Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of DE; Case transferred to D.C.
Short narrative: Anthony Antonio, 27, of Delaware, surrendered to police and was charged with knowingly entering or remaining on restriected grounds, violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds, obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder, obstruction of an official proceeding, and destruction of government property for his role in the Capitol riot. [NOTE: Article was found the day after Antonio surrendered to police. Searched on RECAP, PACER, Delaware Court, and D.C. Court, but could not find any additional information. Possibly still sealed?]
Source description: Local News Article; Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Dale Jeremiah Shalvey, et. al.
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:661 - Theft in a Federal Enclave; 18:1001(a)(2) - False Statement or Representation to an Agency of the United States; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(A) - Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Short narrative: Following her participation in the raids at the United States Capitol on 6 January 2021, Katharine Morrison faces 11 charges from his indictment related to the Capitol protests.
Source description: Criminal Complaint, National News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Dale Jeremiah Shalvey, et. al.
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:661 - Theft in a Federal Enclave; 18:1001(a)(2) - False Statement or Representation to an Agency of the United States; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(A) - Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of NC
Short narrative: "Tara Aileen Stottlemyer, who the FBI allege willfully and knowingly entered the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, was arrested on Sept. 14. Her partner, Dale Shalvey, has already been indicted in this matter, charged with multiple offenses, including assaulting law enforcement. According to court documents, the couple married and moved to North Carolina after the incident. According to local media, the couple started a small business raising animals in early 2020 in Fredericktown, Pa. Prior to that, Stottlemyer worked as a flight attendant." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Daniel Gray
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of GA/FL
Short narrative: "In the days after the riot, Gray posted a 4-minute video to Instagram, discussing his role in the riot, stating he was one of the first inside the Capitol. He also stated a female officer "stole" his cell phone outside the Capitol and that he said "I'm like you know what, we're doing this and so we literally pushed them from the front steps of the Capitol all the way back." He detailed storming Nancy Pelosi's office and then coming upon the female officer with the Metropolitan Police Department he had earlier encountered and stated she "started crying, took off her vest, and ran down the stairs." He also talks about the group arriving at a staircase and pushing the police down the staircase. After viewing bodyworn camera video, the FBI concluded Gray confronted officers and shoved an officer using his baton to push him back. In other video, the FBI stated Gray was one of the first people trying to break through a police line, and that an MPD officer staggered backward, apparently affected by a chemical irritant that had been deployed. When she raised her hand to protect herself, the FBI stated, Gray appeared to reach out and grab her baton and push backwards. Court records state the officer lost her balance and fell down the western Rotunda stairs for several seconds, and was visibly injured and carried away by fellow officers. By obtaining a search warrant for his social media accounts, the FBI found that Gray had posted messages saying the election was the "biggest scandal" of his lifetime and messaged someone that he had just joined the militia. In one message, he asked another person: "Are you gonna be in DC on the 6th like Trump asked us to be?"" (USA Today)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Mark Sami Ibrahim
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(d) - Injuries to Property; 40:5104(e)(1)(A)(i) - Firearm and Dangerous Weapons on Capitol Grounds; 18:1001(a)(2) - False Statement and Representations;
Additional details: Resident of CA; DEA agent
Short narrative: Mark Sami Ibrahim, 33, from Orange County, California, is charged with federal crimes in relation to his participation in the January 6, 2021. He is a former Drug Enforcemeent Administration agent who entered Capitol grounds with a gun and his badge. He climbed the Peace Memorial andlater lied to the feds about why he was there. According to the DOJ, "On January 6, 2021, IBRAHIM was a Special Agent with the Drug Enforcement Administration and at all times relevant to the below chronology, was carrying his DEA-issued firearm. IBRAHIM was a probationary employee of the DEA and had, several weeks prior to the events of January 6, 2021, given notice to the DEA of his intention to resign. On January 6, 2021, IBRAHIM was on personal leave from the DEA. He was not on duty for the DEA and had no role as a law enforcement officer on the Capitol Grounds."
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Daniel Lyons Scott
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) and (a)(2) Knowingly entering and disorderly conduct in any restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Knowingly engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) and (e)(2)(F) Disorderly conduct and act of physical violence on Capitol grounds; 18:231(a)(3) Obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder; 18:1512(c)(2) - Obstruction of justice/Congress; 18:111(a)(1) Assault on a federal officer with physical contact and intent to commit another felony
Additional details: Resident of FL
Short narrative: "On Jan. 6, Daniel Lyons Scott wore a black ballistic vest, goggles and a carabiner on his vest, according to court documents. Scott, who goes by the nickname “Milkshake,” is a known member of the Proud Boys and has a tattoo of the organization on his left arm, according to the FBI. In a Wall Street Journal video from Jan. 6, Scott is seen walking alongside known members of the Proud Boys in Washington, D.C. On the same video, a man is heard screaming: “Let’s take the f***ing Capitol.” Another individual then answers: “Let’s not f***ing yell that, all right?” Ethan Nordean, one of the most powerful leaders in the organization, then responds: “It was Milkshake, man, you know … idiot.” Later at the Capitol, additional footage from various sources shows Scott pushing two police officers backward up the steps. Scott appears to be one of the first people to initiate contact with law enforcement and is seen later pulling officers into the crowd." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Governmental reports and Releases

Name of case: United States of America v. Daniel Christmann
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of NY; former state Senate candidate, plumber
Short narrative: Daniel Christmann, 38, from Brooklyn, NY, who formerly ran for NY State Senate, has been charged with crimes in relation to the January 6, 2021 Capitol raid. He was one of the many to enter into the Capitol building.
Source description: Charging Documents, News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Glenn Allen Brooks
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of CA; Indicted by Bill of Information
Short narrative: "Glenn Brooks “boasted” about his role at the Jan. 6 riot and sent selfies from inside the U.S. Capitol to members of his church prayer group, according to a criminal complaint. A member of that text message group chat forwarded them to the FBI in January. The FBI says surveillance footage shows Brooks climbing through a broken window near the Senate wing and taking pictures inside, wearing plaid scarf and a hat with the word "Trump" emblazoned on it. Court documents show Brooks was arrested on July 29. According to his LinkedIn profile, the 60-year-old Brooks owns a home-remodeling firm called Brooks Works Corp. in Huntington Beach, Calif. Court documents say that surveillance conducted on Brooks by the FBI shows him exiting a vehicle with the name of the company on the side." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Andrew C. Ericson
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of OK; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Sentenced 12/10 to 24 months probation which includes 20 days of jail to be served on consecutive weekends, and $500 restitution.
Short narrative: Andrew Craig Ericson, 23, of Muskogee, OK, was arrested 1/22/21 and charged with unlawful entry on restricted buildings or grounds and violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds. After arrest, he was held at the Muskogee County jail. Ericson was charged after discovering Snapchat photographs showing Ericson at the Capitol. FBI investigation showed Ericson used his cell phone to photograph himself and live streamed himself entering the Capitol. The pictures on Ericson’s Snapchat story included his full name.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local news

Name of case: United States of America v. Isaac Samuel Yoder
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of MO; Indicted by a Bill of Information
Short narrative: "Twenty days after the riots at the U.S. Capitol, an anonymous tipster wrote to the FBI: “I was made aware that an individual that works at Yoder locksmith in Nevada, Missouri was involved in the storming of the Capitol on Jan 6th. I am unsure of the gentleman’s first name but know the day of the event he was inside the Capitol and was dressed as George Washington.” According to the FBI, Isaac Samuel Yoder, the owner of that business, dressed in colonial period attire, attended President Donald Trump’s rally at the mall and later entered the Capitol building, where he walked around the Rotunda taking pictures. In a Newsweek article published in March, Yoder stated he wore the George Washington costume as a nod to America’s founders. "Most of us out there are on the side of the aisle who are the gun owners … If we had collectively gone there to cause trouble there would have been piles of bodies. We could have leveled things," he told Newsweek. But Yoder also stated he did not have any altercations with the police and remained in the building for several minutes only, which was confirmed by footage analyzed by the FBI. Yoder also told Newsweek that he believed the election was stolen." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Luke Wessley Bender
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) Obsturction of an official proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(A) Entering and remaining on the floor of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disroderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Resident of VA
Short narrative: "“Patriots Its [sic] time to come together in DC. And fight for our country. Just like our President Donald Trump has done for us. It’s time we fight for him. See yall in DC Jan 6th,” posted Luke Wessley Bender on TikTok days before the storming of the Capitol, according to court documents. An anonymous tipster who identified themselves as a co-worker wrote to the FBI on Jan 13: “Luke Bender was bragging about being present during the insurrection at the US Capitol … He has photos of himself and with others inside of the US Capitol Building. Some of the people he has photos with have already been arrested for their participation in this insurrection.” Images from Jan. 6 show Bender wearing a black cowboy hat, a camouflage jacket and a big blue Trump flag on the National Mall. Footage also shows him walking around the Capitol Rotunda and, later, entering the Senate chamber, where he appeared to use his phone to photograph documents left on senators’ desks. The court documents also show images of Bender pictured on the dais on the Senate floor." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Stephanie M. Baez
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Indicted by Bill of Information
Short narrative: Stephanie M. Baez, 28, was charged with Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; and Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds following her participation in the Capitol riot. Baez posted a video of herself taken outside the US Capitol in which she explains she is looking for a Proud Boy. There are numerous photographs that show Baez inside the Capitol building.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Caldwell, et al.

Additional details: USMC veteran; Resident of Florida; Likley removed cache of firearms from home prior to arrest according to FBI comments; Pleaded agreement entered 9/15. Pleaded guilty to counts 1 and 2, (18:371 and 18:1512(c)(2),2) sentencing date TBD
Short narrative: Joseph Hackett, 51, Jason Dolan, 44, William Isaacs, 21, and Jonathan Walden, 46, were added to the Oathkeepers 4th superseding indictment. Each face multiple counts for their participation in the January 2021 Capitol protests. Specifically, Hackett is accused of conspiracy; obstruction of an official proceeding, and aiding and abetting; destruction of government property, and aiding and abetting; and illegally entering a restricted building or grounds.

Name of case: United States of America v. Caldwell, et al.
Group affiliation: Oath Keepers; Ohio State Regular Militia
Charges: 18:371 Conspiracy; 18:1512(c)(2),2 Obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; 18:1361, 2 Destruction of government property and aiding and abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds
Short narrative: "Sandra Parker, 60, and Bennie Parker, 70, both of Morrow, according to federal documents, were charged with conspiracy, destruction of government property (and aiding and abetting), obstruction of an official proceeding (and aiding and abetting) and restricted buildings or grounds. Specifically, Sandra Parker, dressed in a uniform consisting of camouflaged-combat attire, and, operating as a group with several other similarly-attired members of the Oath Keepers Militia, breached the U.S. Capitol, directly or indirectly damaged property of the Capitol and obstructed Congress’s proceedings. Bennie Parker, similarly dressed in a uniform consisting of camouflaged-combat attire, assisted Sandra Parker and other members of the Oath Keepers Militia by staying in communication with members inside the Capitol while Bennie Parker remained on the grounds of the Capitol.” (Springfield News-Sun) Sandra and Bennie are married.
Source description: Charging documents, court documents, local news articles, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Janet West Buhler
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(B) Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of UT; Sentenced 6/1/22 to 30 days in jail, 36 months of probation, $500 in restitution.
Short narrative: Janet West Buhler, 57, of UT, was charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for her participation in the January 6th Capitol riot. Buhler traveled to Washington, D.C., along with her stepson-in-law, Michael Lee Hardin. Buhler can be seen in footage taken from inside the building during the riot. Buhler pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building, and was sentenced to 30 days in jail, 36 months of probation, $500 in restitution.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental reports and release (DOJ), News article

Name of case: United States of America v. William Watson
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1361, 2 - Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: bond was revoked; "William Watson Found guilty 11/18/22 by Court after agreeing to a stipulated set of facts of obstruction of an official proceeding and entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a dangerous weapon."; "William Watson Sentenced 3/9/23 to 36 months in prison and 36 months of supervised release."
Short narrative: "The Associated Press reported that Watson was arrested in Alabama because he violated a previous bond when he traveled out of state for the Capitol riot. A CBS affiliate for eastern Alabama said authorities recognized Watson by the distinctive tattoos on his hand, and from photos of him wearing a tan or yellow sweatshirt standing next to the man with the horned hat." At the time of his arrest, he was out on $103,000 bond from a previous arrest for trafficking LSD and marijuana
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Edward McAlanis
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Indicted by a Bill of Information before Criminal Complaint released; sentenced to 2 years on probation and was ordered to do 60 hours of community service and pay $500 restitution.
Short narrative: "Edward McAlanis shared photographs of his participation in the U.S. Capitol insurrection with friends, according to court documents. The FBI says it learned of McAlanis from a tipster who has mutual friends with him. The tipster shared two photos, which are included in court documents. One of those photos allegedly shows McAlanis posing with a statue of Abraham Lincoln in the Statuary Hall at the Capitol. Prosecutors say the man in the photos can also be seen in CCTV footage from the area of the Rotunda, and that the blue sweatshirt, black vest and black and red backpack match the photos sent by the tipster. The FBI found McAlanis’ phone number and says a search warrant to AT&T led to records that placed him inside the Capitol. Other records confirmed the phone number, along with a Pennsylvania address, prosecutors say. A second tipster confirmed the address in July, according to the FBI, and said McAlanis told friends and family he broke into the Capitol." (NPR) He has been sentenced to two years on probation.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Patrick Edward McCaughey , et. al.
Charges: 18:111(a)(1), 2 - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers and Aiding and Abetting [4 counts]; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: US State Department aide with Top Secret clearence, resigned 1/19/21; "first member of the Trump administration to face criminal charges in connection with the storming of the Capitol by a pro-Trump mob" (NYT)
Short narrative: "Federal investigators believe Federico Klein, a former midlevel State Department aide, assaulted police officers with a riot shield and attempted to take items from officers in and around the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6. According to court documents, Klein held top-secret security clearance at the time. In various body camera footage, Klein is allegedly seen fighting officers and trying to breach a police line to enter the Capitol. At one point, an officer sprayed a chemical irritant that forced Klein to move away. Investigators say Klein also incited the mob. Video footage allegedly shows Klein calling on the crowd behind him to send "fresh people" to help break through the police line multiple times. Other videos from that day also place Klein at a scene right outside the Capitol building where a police officer had been dragged into the crowd. As other officers tried to recover their colleague, they urged rioters to move. Klein is allegedly seen and heard responding, "No way." Klein worked on Donald Trump's presidential campaign in 2016 and started working at the State Department shortly after Trump's inauguration in 2017, according to a financial disclosure report. A State Department spokesperson said Klein served as a special assistant in the Bureau of Western Hemisphere Affairs. A former colleague told Politico he was later transferred to the office that handles Freedom of Information Act requests. Klein resigned from the State Department on Jan. 19." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents; National News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Patrick Edward McCaughey , et. al.
Charges: 18:111(a)(1), 2 - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain officers, Aiding and Abetting; 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder [3 counts]; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon [2 counts]; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Arrested 1/19/21 in the Southern District of NY; 2 co-defendants have slightly different combination of charges; "Found guilty 9/13/22 of a total of nine offenses. They include seven felony charges: three counts of aiding or abetting or assaulting, resisting, or impeding law enforcement officers, including one involving a dangerous weapon; one count of obstruction of an official proceeding; one count of interfering with a law enforcement officer during a civil disorder; one count of disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon, and one count of engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon. The two misdemeanor charges include: disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building and committing an act of violence in the Capitol Building or grounds."
Short narrative: Patrick Edward McCaughey III was charged with assaulting D.C. Metropolitan Police Officer Hodges during the breach of the U.S. Capitol grounds on Jan. 6, 2021. He was seen crushing this officer between the doors of the Capitol.
Source description: Court Documents; Charging documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Patrick Edward McCaughey , et. al.
Charges: 18:111(a)(1), 2 - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain officers, Aiding and Abetting [3 counts]; 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder [4 counts]; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Dangerous Weapon [2 counts]; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others

They include five felony charges: four counts of aiding or abetting or assaulting, resisting, or impeding law enforcement officers, and one count of interfering with a law enforcement officer during a civil disorder. The four misdemeanor charges include: disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building, and committing an act of violence in the Capitol Building or grounds."; "Tristan Stevens Sentenced 3/10/23 to 60 months in prison, 24 months of supervised release, $2,000 restitution, and a $500 fine."
Short narrative: Tristan Chandler Stevens, 25, of Pensacola is charged with forcibly assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers or employees, knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds; and disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building.
Source description: Court Documents; Charging documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Patrick Edward McCaughey , et. al.
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) and (2) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers and aiding and abetting [2 counts]; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon; 18:1512(c)(2) and (2) Obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings

Restitution imposed in the amount of $2,000. Fine imposed in the amount of $5,691."
Short narrative: David Lee Judd, 35, of Carrollton, Texas, was charged with assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers/employees of the United States and civil disorder for his role in the January 6th riot. Judd was identified from a Youtube video and surveillance footage entering a tunnel of the Capitol building, attempting to organize protesors to form a shield wall, and throwing a firecracker at a line of law enforcemnet officers. Additionally a witness provided an advertisemen Judd posted on social media asking for a ride to to the riot.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News
