Name of case: United States of America v. Patrick Edward McCaughey , et. al.
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) and (2) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers and aiding and abetting [2 counts]; 18:2111 Robbery; 18:231(a)(3) Civil disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon [3 counts]; 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings
Additional details: Resident of PA
Short narrative: "After the FBI posted an image seeking information about him, Robert Morss was identified by at least four witnesses. Morss is allegedly seen in photos and videos from Jan. 6, wearing camouflage, a tactical vest and a "Make America Great Again" hat. In a crowd trying to push past law enforcement in the Lower West Terrace area of the U.S. Capitol grounds, Morss can be seen on police body camera footage trying to take a police baton away from an officer and later grabbing a fence held by officers and ripping it away, according to court documents. He can allegedly be heard saying to officers: "You guys are betraying us. You get paid enough to betray your people?” and “[T]ake a look around, back up, we are going to take our Capitol back.” In a YouTube video from a tunnel leading into the Capitol, he is seen pushing into and taking a riot shield away from an officer and sending it back into the crowd, where he directs them to form a "shield wall," according to court documents. Rioters then yelled, "Heave ho," as they pushed in unison against the officers guarding the doors, court documents indicate. Morss eventually left the tunnel and could later be seen climbing through a broken window into the Capitol, court documents say. According to local news reports and court documents, Morss served in the military and has been a substitute teacher in Pennsylvania. NPR was not able to confirm his military history." (NPR) He has been added through a third superseding indictment to a previous case including McCaughey, Stevens, Judd, Quaglin, and Sills.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Patrick Edward McCaughey , et. al.
Charges: 18:2111 Robbery; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon; 18:111(a)(1) and (2) Assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers and aiding and abetting [3 counts]; 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon [2 counts]; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings
Additional details: Resident of Virginia; "Geoffrey Sills Sentenced 3/21/23 to 52 months in prison for obstruction of an official proceeding, assaulting, resisting, or impeding officers with a dangerous weapon and robbery, all felonies."
Short narrative: Geoffrey William Sills, of Mechanicsville, Virginia, was arrested on 10 charges in connection with the Capitol riot, among them assaulting federal officers using a dangerous weapon, robbery, obstruction of an official proceeding and engaging in physical violence in a restricted building with a dangerous weapon. In a new superseding indictment filed last week, Sills was charged with five co-defendants for allegedly joining the mob that assaulted Capitol and D.C. police trying to hold a line in the Capitol tunnels.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Patrick Edward McCaughey , et. al.
Charges: 18:111(a)(1), 2 Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers and Aiding and Abetting; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of OH; also worked with anti-abortion groups; "Found guilty 9/13/22 of a total of four offenses. They include two felony charges: aiding and abetting in assaulting, resisting, or impeding law enforcement officers, and interfering with a law enforcement officer during a civil disorder. The two misdemeanor charges include: disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building and aiding and abetting in committing an act of violence in the Capitol Building or grounds."; Sentenced 2/24/23 to 14 months in prison, 24 months of supervised release
Short narrative: David Mehaffie, 62 of Ohio, was found guilty and sentenced to 14 months in prison and 2 years of probation for his involvement in the January 6 Capitol Raid. He charged against police officers and gained entrance into the Capitol with his other co-defendants. "According to HuffPost, Mehaffie was known by the online group Sedition Hunters as the "#TunnelCommander" over his alleged role in giving orders to rioters attacking police officers at one entrance to the Capitol building. The Sedition Hunters group seeks to help federal investigators in identifying the rioters. In the past, Mehaffie has also been a member of an anti-abortion group in Ohio that would protest outside abortion clinics, HuffPost reported." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Patrick Edward McCaughey , et. al.
Charges: 18:111(a)(1), 2 - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers and Aiding and Abetting; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:2111, 2 - Robbery and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of TX
Short narrative: "Steven Cappuccio is charged with eight others over his alleged actions in the assault on officers in a U.S. Capitol tunnel at the Jan. 6 insurrection. According to a reporter at HuffPost, Cappuccio was known by the Sedition Hunters, an online group that aims to help law enforcement identify the rioters, as #stripesguy. Among other more common charges stemming from the riot including assault, Cappuccio is facing one somewhat unusual charge: robbery, over allegedly taking a baton from a police officer, according to a criminal indictment." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Steven C. Billingsley
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds;
Additional details: Resident of OH; Indicted by a Bill of Information before Criminal Complaint released; "Sentenced - 12/6/22 to 24 months of probation, including 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution"
Short narrative: "Steven Billingsley may never have made into the U.S. Capitol building, but his words on restricted grounds were violent, prosecutors say. “We do want to hurt [House Speaker Nancy] Pelosi. I do. Yeah, I would hang her from that big -- you see that tree over there? We’d put [up] a rope and hang her. We hang her and [Senate Majority Leader Chuck] Schumer over there, they’ll all go, ‘Oh s***,' ” Billingsley said, according to court documents. Billingsley livestreamed his time on the Capitol grounds via Facebook, a tipster told the FBI. The account where the videos were posted, prosecutors say, was closed in March. Billingsley narrated the first-person videos and turned the camera to show his face at least once, according to prosecutors, who matched the image to the photo of Billingsley’s driver’s license. Those videos, court documents say, show Billingsley undoing a metal barricade and breaching it. The FBI also says Billingsley shouted at police officers saying, “We’re going through. We can do it the nice way or the hard way. … You guys turned on us.” He also repeatedly said, “This is war,” prosecutors say. Court documents include photos from outside the Capitol that the tipster told the FBI resemble Billingsley." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Jeffrey Xavier Finley
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Residnt of WV
Short narrative: Jeffrey Finley, of West Virginia, was charged with Knowingly Enter and Remain in any Restricted Building or Grounds without Lawful Authority and Engage in Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in any Restricted Buildings or Grounds; and Engage in Disorderly Conduct in any of the Capitol Buildings following his participation in the Capitol riot. Finley was identified via photos taken inside the US Capitol, and it was verified by his cell phone location.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Nicholas James Brockhoff
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangous Weapon; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of KY; Used fire extinguisher as weapon; Identified with assisgance from OSINT hosted on jan6attack.com
Short narrative: "Federal prosecutors allege that Nicholas James Brockhoff assaulted law enforcement officers outside the Capitol on Jan. 6 by spraying a fire extinguisher from a terrace above members of the Metropolitan Police Department and the Capitol Police who were trying to hold back rioters. As a result, prosecutors say, Brockhoff "caused law enforcement to disperse, and obstructed law enforcement’s ability to see." Surveillance footage allegedly shows Brockhoff then entering the Capitol through a broken window. Later, according to body camera footage described in court documents, Brockhoff was seen wearing a police officer's helmet. Brockhoff also allegedly joined rioters in "making a forced entry" into a Republican conference room inside the Capitol. Brockhoff was arrested in Tennessee on May 27." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Samuel Lazar
Charges: 18:111(a) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building orGrounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricited Building or Grounds Using a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Additional details: Resident of PA
Short narrative: Samuel Lazar, 35, of Ephrata, PA is charged with crimes in relation to his participation of the January 6, 2021 Capitol raid. He was seen dressed in "tactical gear, protectice goggles and comouflage face paint", and he approached police and discharged a chemical irritant at them while attempting to remove a bike rack.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Articles, Other

Name of case: United States of America v. Wilson & Temple
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of OH; Mother also arrested
Short narrative: "Temple has been charged with his mother, Jodi Wilson, with entering the Capitol on Jan. 6, where the FBI says they were seen on surveillance footage for about 17 minutes. Both admitted in August interviews with the FBI that they had been inside the Capitol. While inside the Capitol, Temple posted a video of himself yelling "just broke in this bitch."" (USA Today)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Wilson & Temple
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of OH; Son also arrested
Short narrative: "The FBI began investigating Wilson and her son Cole Temple in January, according to federal charging documents. Their cell phones showed up on geo-locating software the FBI has often used to place people inside the Capitol building on the 6th. Court records show that Wilson told a court-appointed guardian at litem in a custody case involving a minor child that she went into the Capitol with Temple, and said she'd been invited onto the steps by an unidentified man whom she assumed to be a Congressman. Afterwards, she stated, a police officer told her and her son that they were allowed to go in. Records show the pair was in the Capitol for at least 17 minutes. Initially, the FBI said, she denied being inside the Capitol but admitted it after the agents showed her photos of her inside the building carrying an American flag." (USA Today)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Alan William Byerly
Charges: *18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; *18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 18:113(a)(4) - Striking, Beating, or Wounding of Another Person Within the Territorial Jurisdiction; *18:113(a)(5) - Simple Assault within the Territorial Jurisdiction;
Additional details: Resident of PA; "Sentenced 10/21/22 to 34 months in prison, three years of supervised release, $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative: Alan William Byerly, 55 of Pennsylvania, pled guilty to Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers and Striking, Beating or Wounding of Another Person within the Territorial Jurisdiction at the Capitol Riot. "He assaulted a photographer for The Associated Press and also used a Taser or Taser-like device "meant to deliver a debilitating electric shock" to assault police officers protecting the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6. Byerly, court papers say, charged toward a police line in front of the West Terrace of the Capitol while activating the Taser-type device; police were able to remove the device from Byerly, but he continued to "physically strike, and push against officers," court documents say. [...] Separately, around that time, Byerly is accused of joining members of a violent mob that pushed, shoved and dragged the AP photographer outside the Capitol. After the FBI posted photos of the incident and requested tips from the public, a witness reportedly contacted investigators." (NPR) He was sentenced to prison for 34 months.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Karol J. Chwiesiuk
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(2)(2)(C)(i) Entering and remaining in a room designated for the use of a member of congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of IL; Sister also arrested (Agnieszka Chwiesiuk); Member of Chicago Police Department-- badge # 7156
Short narrative: Karol J. Chwiesiuk, 29, from Chicago, Illinois and a member of the Chicago Police Department, has been arrested and charged for his participation in the January 6, 2021 Capitol Raid. On June 2, 2021, the Chicago Police Department relieved him of his police powers. He was alledgedly inside the Capitol and bragged about his efforts, and used offense language, through text message to an associate.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Perretta & Vukich
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:641 Theft of Government Money, Property, or Records; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of PA; QAnon connection link is unsubstantiated; "Sentenced 1/5/22 to 30 days of incarceration, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Mitchell Paul Vukich, 25 of Pennsylvania, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following his participation in the Capitol riot alongside co-defendant Nicholas Perretta. The men claim to have been in the Capitol for 25 minutes where they smoked marijuana. After the riot, he tweeted, "I was one of the first 15 people in the #Capitol. Wild stuff." Vukich was identified via 7 anonymous tips provided to the FBI, numerous tweets posted by Vukich himself, and surveillance footage that placed Vukich inside the US Capitol at the time of the riot. He and Perretta were sentenced to a month in prison.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Perretta & Vukich
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:641 Theft of Government Money, Property, or Records; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of PA; "Sentenced 1/5/22 to 30 days of incarceration, $500 restitution"
Short narrative: Nicholas J. Perretta, 27 of Pennsylvania, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following his participation in the Capitol riot alongside co-defendant Michell Paul Vukich. The men claim to have been in the Capitol for 25 minutes where they smoked marijuana. When Vukich was presented with images from the Capitol's video footage, he admitted to his own involvement and positively identified Perretta as well. The men attended the earlier pro-Trump rally, before heading to the Capitol. While inside, Perretta admitted that they took “three-month-old congressional papers” and later disposed of them outside the Capitol. He was sentenced to a month in prison.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Fi Duong
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of VA; Part of self-styled militia with meetings called "Bible Study"
Short narrative: Fi Duong, 27, from Alexandria, Virginia, was arrested and charged with multiple federal crimes in relation to his participation in the Capitol raid. An undercover Metropolitan Police Department FBI agent observed and spoke with Duong for months after they met on January 6, 2021 at the Capitol. Duong appears to be a part of a "self-styled militia that referred to its meetings as "Bible study"'. At the time of his arrest he was in possession of several guns and the materials to make 50 molotov cocktails.
Source description: Charging Documents, News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Jacob Travis Clark
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of CO
Short narrative: Jacob Travis Clark, of Trinidad, was arrested and released on a $10,000 bond, according to documents filed in U.S. District Court in Denver. He is accused of unlawfully entering a restricted building, disorderly and disruptive conduct, engaging in physical violence in a restricted building, violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds, obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder, and obstruction of justice and Congress.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Jonathon Owen Shroyer
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(E) - Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings;
Additional details: Resident of TX; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Inforwars talk-show host with show "The War Room With Owen Shroyer"; Defendant violated a 2020 Deferred Prosecution Agreement begun after he disrupted a House Judiciary Committee meeting 12/9/19. He was charged with a violation of (1) 10 D.C. Code Section 503.16(b)(4) (2001 ed.), Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct on United States Capitol Grounds, and (2) 10 D.C. Code Section 503.16(b)(7) (2001 ed.), Obstructing and Impeding Passage on United States Capitol Grounds
Short narrative: "Owen Shroyer is a Texas-based talk-show host for the far-right conspiracy website Infowars. His show, The War Room With Owen Shroyer, streams daily on the Infowars platform banned.video. The criminal complaint indicates that Shroyer was on promotional materials advertising the march on the U.S. Capitol that were circulated by Infowars, reading: "Be a part of history! Fight for Trump." Shroyer also spoke to a crowd the day before the march at a rally at Freedom Plaza, saying: "Americans are ready to fight. We’re not exactly sure what that’s going to look like, perhaps in a couple of weeks if we can’t stop this certification of the fraudulent election ... we are the new revolution!" On the day of the riot, there are multiple images that allegedly show Shroyer inside the restricted area of the Capitol, including a video that reportedly zooms in on him inside the building, while a person can be heard exclaiming, "Well there’s ... Owen Shroyer up there," court documents indicate. Shroyer also allegedly introduced himself in several of the videos. Court documents also note that his involvement in the riot at the Capitol violated the terms of a deferred prosecution agreement entered after he disrupted a House Judiciary Committee meeting in December 2019." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Timothy Allen Hart
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Expressed support for QAnon; Wore Q hoodie and hat to Capitol; Smoked mariuana in Capitol; Resident of OH; Owns paintball and airsoft business
Short narrative: "Prosecutors allege that the FBI received tips from at least four people that Timothy Hart was part of the riot at the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6. One person reported that not only did Hart film the riot, but that he also filmed himself driving from Ohio to Washington, D.C. Court documents allege that Hart was among the rioters who helped to remove barricades surrounding the Capitol building and can be seen on the stairs telling others to come nearer to the building. An Instagram video posted to an account called “brotunda" allegedly appears to show Hart inside the Capitol, smoking what investigators infer was marijuana, wearing a sweatshirt bearing a large “Q." FBI agents say they were able to identify Hart via subscriber information for his YouTube channel and a linked mobile phone that was subscribed to his wife, Stephanie Hart. Hart is the owner of a paintball center in Ohio." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Michael Joseph Rusyn
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of PA; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced 1/11/22 to 24 months of probation, including 60 days of home confinement, $2,000 fine, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Michael Rusyn self-surrendered on April 9, 2021 and had his initial appearance the same afternoon. He has been charged with Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, and Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. He is a volunteer firefighter and EMT. He pleaded not guilty to all counts on 4/26. Rusyn told investigators that he was actully injured himself while there when he was trying to take weapons away from members of the crowd, such as a broom stick with hooks and nails affixed to the end of it.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Deborah Lynn Lee
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Short narrative: Deborah Lynn Lee, 55, of PA, was charged with Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following her participation in the Capitol riot. Lee was identified via photos and posts made to Lynn's Facebook account.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Carey Jon Walden
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) disorderly or disruptive conduct, at any place in the Grounds or in any of the Capitol Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) parade, demonstrate, or picket in any of the Capitol Buildings
Additional details: USMC and Nacy veteran for 12.5 years total; Resident of MO; Sentenced to 3 years of probation, $500 restitution; $10 restitution.
Short narrative: Carey Jon Walden was charged, in his criminal complaint, with Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; disorderly or disruptive conduct, at any place in the Grounds or in any of the Capitol Buildings; parade, demonstrate, or picket in any of the Capitol Buildings following his participation in the Capitol riot. However, in his information, he was only charged with parading, demonstrating, or picketing in any of the Capitol buidlings. Walden was identified via a tip provided to the FBI as well as a Facebook post from Walden himself.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Tanner Bryce Sells
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Resident of OK; "Sentenced 1/18/22 to 24 months probation, including 90 days of home detention, 50 hours of community service, $1,500 fine, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Tanner Sells was charged with willfully and knowingly parading, demonstrating, and picketing in the US Capitol bulding on January 6th, 2021 during the Capitol protests.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Pamela Anne Hemphill
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of ID; Hemphill pleaded Guilty to one charge: Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentenced to 2 months in jail, probation for three years and $500 fine.
Short narrative: "In the weeks after the riot at the U.S. Capitol, court documents say, tipsters led the FBI to the Facebook posts and social media accounts of Pam Hemphill, including one posted on Dec. 28, 2020, that reads: "It's not going to be a FUN Trump Rally that is planned for January 6th, its [sic] a WAR!" The criminal complaint also shows a post indicating her plan to travel to Washington, D.C., for the rally, featuring an image of Hemphill holding a firearm that said, "Happy New Year! On my way to Washington DC January 6th!" The FBI also found videos taken on Jan. 5 posted to a YouTube channel with Hemphill's name on it. In one, she is heard talking about Ammon Bundy and the occupation of the Idaho State Capitol by protesters of COVID-19 restrictions, saying “Let’s do this; let’s go to the Capitol. We did it in Boise.” Surveillance footage from the Capitol Police shows Hemphill with a selfie stick entering the Capitol and walking through the Rotunda. Later, she can allegedly be seen being escorted out of the building by law enforcement. The criminal complaint also shows a post from another individual identified as a friend of Hemphill's that reads: "Pam is ok!! I am on the phone with her. She was inside the Capitol and they escorted her out in one of the secure tunnels. She got lost and is walking through DC by herself. I will stay on the phone with her until she gets to her hotel. She has some awesome video from inside the capitol to download for us. Wait until you see."" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Robert Flynt Fairchild, Jr.
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; *18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; *18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(4) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of FL; "Sentenced 10/20/2022 to six months of incarceration, $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative: "Robert Fairchild Jr. was identified after law enforcement posted photos of him on the FBI website, asking tipsters to help find an individual who had allegedly assaulted a federal officer. Law enforcement subsequently asked Fairchild's brother-in-law, who worked at the Troup County, Ga., Sheriff's Office whether he knew the person in the photos, and the brother-in-law identified Fairchild. The FBI alleges that Fairchild is observed on body camera and surveillance footage pushing against security barriers protecting the U.S. Capitol, helping to remove those barriers and walking inside the building. Federal law enforcement said he appeared to be taking a video of himself with his cellphone and at one point seemed to be yelling, "Fight for Trump," while on the Senate side of the building. [...] Fairchild pleaded Guilty to one charge: Civil Disorder. Sentenced on 10/20/2022 to 6 Months of Incarceration; Special Assessment of $100; Restitution of $2,000" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Thomas John Ballard
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; *18:231(a)(2) - Civil Disorder; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of TX; Identified by a civilian using facial recognition website; Wore Infowars hat
Short narrative: "A witness contacted the FBI to report that a publicly available facial recognition software could be used to identify an individual wanted over involvement on Jan. 6, according to court documents. The software reportedly identified a YouTube Channel called “CliffCares,” which was associated with the Facebook business page of Cliff's Mobile Motorcycle Tires. That business page included a photo of one of its clients, a police officer that the FBI subsequently contacted. That officer then helped FBI agents identify the owner of the business as Thomas "Cliff" Ballard, the same man who allegedly showed up via the facial recognition software. Footage from Jan. 6 also allegedly shows Ballard sporting a hat promoting Infowars, a far-right conspiracy news outlet owned by radio host Alex Jones. In the footage, Ballard is allegedly seen confronting and assaulting police officers on multiple occasions. According to the FBI, Ballard can be seen using a black police baton assaulting officers, who are trying to defend the Lower West Terrace archway of the U.S. Capitol. He can also be seen throwing a tabletop at them, court documents indicate." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Rondon & Mooney-Rondon
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:641, 2 Theft of Government Property; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(B) Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(C) Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of NY; Mother also arrested
Short narrative: "A tipster reached out to the FBI to tell it that Rafael Rondon was at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6 with his mother, Maryann Mooney-Rondon, who is also charged, according to court documents. Surveillance footage, as well as other videos and photographs, allegedly show Rondon and his mother inside the building, including inside the Senate gallery and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's conference room, where they are allegedly seen standing nearby in a video that appears to show a laptop being stolen from the room, court records indicate. In the Senate gallery, Rondon and his mother allegedly appear in photographs carrying protective respiratory hoods, which are stored in the gallery in case of a biological or chemical attack. Later on, Rondon can reportedly be seen wearing the hood in photographs taken on the Capitol steps, court documents indicate. In an interview with the FBI, Rondon allegedly admitted to being inside the Capitol that day, telling the agents: "I think everybody was going there for about the same reason I was, just have your voice heard.” He also admitted to helping the man who took the laptop in Pelosi's conference room, saying, "I was honestly a little bit afraid, because I didn’t know if he had anything on him. So I assisted him a little bit, and that was probably stupid of me," according to court documents" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Rondon & Mooney-Rondon
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:641, 2 Theft of Government Property; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(B) Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(C) Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of NY; Son also arrested; "Maryann Mooney-Rondon Found guilty March 27, 2023 of obstruction of an official proceeding, and aiding and abetting the theft of government property."
Short narrative: "A tipster reached out to the FBI to tell it that Maryann Mooney-Rondon was at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6 with her son, Rafael Rondon, who is also charged in the riot, court documents indicate. Cellphone records, surveillance footage and other videos and photographs also allegedly show Mooney-Rondon and her son inside the building that day, including inside the Senate gallery and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's conference room. In a video taken inside Pelosi's conference room, both Mooney-Rondon and her son can be seen standing nearby as the video appears to show a laptop being stolen from the room, court records indicate. In the video, an arm, believed to be Mooney-Rondon's, reaches over toward the laptop and a female voice is heard to say, "Dude, put on gloves," before an unidentified man lifts the computer off the table. In an interview with the FBI, Mooney-Rondon admitted to entering the Capitol that day and said she provided gloves to the man who took the laptop, court documents indicate. In the interview, she reportedly said the man "scared the crap" out of her." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Other names/aliases: Uliyahu Ben'arie Hayah, Wiyaha B Hayah, Uliyahu Benarie Hayah, Lemon Raetheon Williams, Le Mon Williams
Name of case: United States of America v. Uliyahu Hayah
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Identified with aid from Sedition Hunters; Resident of VA/MD; On parole supervised by VA DOC; Arrested in 2017 on assault charges for pointing a gun at a driver on the highway
Short narrative: On September 8, 2021, Uliyahu Hayah, 45, of Silver Spring, Maryland, was indicted on several charges, including Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following his participation in the U.S. Capitol riots on January 6, 2021. Hayah allegedly entered the Capitol building with a gas mask, laid his hands on a Metropolitan police officer, and pushed him approximately 10 feet into the crowd (Newsone). Hayah is currently on supervised parole through the Virginia Department of Corrections in Fairfax County, Virginia. Hayah was previously arrested after he pointed a handgun at a woman on Interstate I-95. After a further investigation, Maryland State Police troopers also found two rifles—one was an assault rifle—along with a shotgun and ammunition in the man's vehicle. We decided not to include this as a previous similar crime as the motivation was not the same and there were no charges related to firearms with this case.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Benjamin J. Martin
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2) - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding;
Additional details: Resident of CA
Short narrative: "Benjamin Martin, a real estate agent from California, came to the attention of federal prosecutors after a tipster recognized Martin from footage of the riot at the U.S. Capitol, charging papers say. The tipster allegedly told investigators they knew Martin from high school and had seen his political posts and videos on Facebook, including videos saying he was going to Washington, D.C., on Jan. 6. Before the riot, according to court papers, Martin was part of a group chat on the encrypted messaging platform Telegram, where he discussed plans to go to Washington. He allegedly said in that group chat on Jan. 6 that “I just spoke to Peggy Hall she said we need to meet." Hall is a far-right activist from California who opposes vaccination and the use of masks to mitigate COVID-19, and who was in Washington on Jan. 6. Hall is not facing any criminal charges related to the Capitol riot. On Jan. 15, Martin gave an interview to FBI investigators, court documents say, and claimed that he was at the Capitol attempting to calm demonstrators who had gathered at the doors of the building. Subsequently, the FBI allegedly reviewed footage showing Martin inside the Capitol building as well as footage from the Capitol grounds, where Martin told law enforcement officers, "You guys are not doing your job. You swore an oath. You’re bound by your word. Move out of the way and let us in. Move out of the way and let us in.” At one point, officers allegedly deployed chemical spray toward Martin while protecting the building." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Matthew Dasilva
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Additional details: Resident of TX; Navy veteran
Short narrative: "Matthew DaSilva was identified to the FBI in February when he was recognized by somone he knows in a photo circulated by the FBI, according to court documents. The photo shows a man in a red hat, a blue and gray camouflage Navy jacket, and a black and gold scarf. The FBI said that DaSilva’s distinctive outfit can be seen in video footage of the front line of rioters and that DaSilva can be seen grabbing, pushing and pulling on shields held by law enforcement officers. Prosecutors say the tipster, as well as a second person who told the FBI about DaSilva, recognized the scarf as one DaSilva wore every day. The second tipster told the FBI that after DaSilva returned from Washington, D.C., he shaved his beard and cut his long hair. Court documents say DaSilva also stopped wearing the black and gold scarf." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. David Nicholas Dempsey
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:111(a)(1) and 2 Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) and 2 Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Additional details: Resident of CA; Identified with aid from Sedition Hunters; Was arrested 10/1919 for spraying anti-Trump protestors with bear spray.
Short narrative: "David Dempsey came to the attention of federal investigators through public tips from the Sedition Hunters -- people researching the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol. On the day of the Capitol riot, federal prosecutors allege, Dempsey wore an American flag-themed neck gaiter as well as a combat-style helmet, camouflage pants and a tactical vest. In one video described in court documents, Dempsey stood in front of a gallows erected outside the Capitol and said that Democrats in Congress "need to hang from these motherf****** [pointing to gallows]," and that "Hopefully one day soon we really have someone hanging from one of these motherf******." During the riot, Dempsey allegedly used a lacrimal agent -- such as pepper spray -- as well as a crutch and a metal pole to attack police officers guarding the Capitol building. Dempsey was arrested in Santa Monica, Calif., in 2019 over allegedly using bear spray to attack anti-Trump protesters there. Dempsey pleaded no contest to a charge stemming from that incident. The Justice Department notes in its court filings that Dempsey can be seen in multiple photos from Jan. 6 wearing a black- and yellow-colored bracelet. Black and yellow are the colors associated with the far-right extremist group known as the Proud Boys. In one photo described in court documents, Dempsey made the OK sign while standing next to people wearing Proud Boys attire. The "OK" sign, which the Proud Boys frequently use, is often associated with supporters of white supremacy, according to the Anti-Defamation League. Dempsey was arrested on Aug. 26." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Gary Wilson
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding & Abetting; 18:1752(a)(l) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(B) Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress
Additional details: Resident of Salt Lake City, Utah
Short narrative: Federal prosecutors allege that Gary Wilson breached the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021, along with two other men: Patrick Montgomery and Brady Knowlton. Wilson wore a T-shirt from the far-right conspiratorial news site Infowars depicting a Revolutionary War soldier with an automatic weapon, according to charging documents. Wilson was in close proximity to multiple violent clashes between rioters and police in and around the Capitol, prosecutors say, though they do not accuse Wilson of committing violence himself. During one confrontation with police, Wilson allegedly told officers, "We came all the way from our jobs to do your job and the freaking senators’ job.” Charging documents state that federal investigators confirmed Wilson's presence in the Capitol through flight records, cellphone records, an interview with a family member of Wilson and videos from multiple sources at the Capitol. The FBI arrested Wilson on Sept. 13, 2021. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Landon Kenneth Copeland
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of UT; born in MO; Previous charges for "Marijuana/False Statements" and "Burglary of barracks" from US Army in 2013. Other previous charges include DUI, Disorderly Conduct, Carrying firearm in vehicle, all in Montana
Short narrative: "Federal arresting documents allege Copeland entered the Capitol grounds during the Jan. 6 riot, where he assaulted law enforcement officers. Footage from YouTube and Instagram shows Copeland present with a crowd of protestors trying to breach the police line. Footage shows Copeland push an unknown person into a police officer, causing the officer to fall to the ground. He also grabbed at an officer’s jacket and pushed that officer backward, arrest records show." (USA Today)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Joshua David Dressel
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violennt Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of MO
Short narrative: Joshua Dressel, 31, resident of MO, was identifed to be one of the members who participated in the January 6th 2021 Capitol protests. He had taken videos while inside that were later discovered and used to find his identity. He is facing 4 charges including entering or remaining in a restricted building without authority, disorderly conduct in a restricted building, violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. Each of those crimes are misdemeanors.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local news articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Wilson & Wilson
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Ordered to pay $500 restitution; Resident of MO; Husband also arrested
Short narrative: Kelsey Leigh Ann Wilson was indicted on September 14, 2021 and charged alongside her husband for their involvement in the January 2021 Capitol riot. Both plead guilty to the charge of 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing data is pending. "Wilson is a first-grade teacher at Dayspring Christian School in Springfield, Mo., which has released a statement saying she had been put on administrative leave, according to news reports." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Wilson & Wilson
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Sentenced to 24 months of probation on 27 January 2022, including 45 days of home detention, 60 hours of community service and $500 restitution; Residento of MO; Wife also arrested
Short narrative: Zachary Wilson, 31, was "a strong supporter of President Trump and wanted his voice heard" he said to an FBI agent during an interview. Wilson was indicted on September 14, 2021 and charged alongside his wife for their involvement in the January 2021 Capitol riot. Both plead guilty to the charge of 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. Sentencing data is pending.
Source description: Court Documents, Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Brandon Straka
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:641 Theft of Government Money, Property, or Records; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds;
Additional details: Resident of NY; "Sentenced 1/24/22 to 36 months of probation, including three months of home detention, $5,000 fine, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Brandon Straka, 45 of New York, pled guilty to Engaging in Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in the Capitol Building or Grounds and was sentenced to 36 months probation. Straka was charged after the FBI received a tip that he had posted videos and comments on his Twitter of his participation in the Capitol riot. He is the founder of #WalkAway Campaign, a movement to discourage liberal participation as a former liberal himself. He spoke at the rally the day before the riot and also invoked the QAnon slogan "Where we go one we go all" at the Jan 6 Stop the Steal rally in D.C.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Jacob Kyle Wiedrich
Charges: *18:1752(a)(I) Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of UT; "Sentenced 1/19/22 to three years of probation, including three months of home detention, 100 hours of communitiy service, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Jacob Kyle Wiedrich, 23 of Utah, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building and was sentenced to three years of probation for his role in the Capitol riot. He posted a SnapChat video where he screams, "It's wartime!... Charge! Charge the motherf***er!....We ride for Trump, we die for Trump!" under the username of “Jacob Weed.” "Wiedrich wore a red "Make America Great Again" hat and a T-shirt with a partial picture of the space shuttle. According to the FBI, footage shows Wiedrich entering the Capitol through a broken window, and once inside, he is seen screaming and taunting a police officer. He was apparently so confrontational that another member of the mob is seen restraining him. He was arrested in Salt Late City." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Robert Ballesteros
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds;
Additional details: Resident of NY; Sentenced 4/28/22 to 36 months of probation, including 40 hours of community service, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: Robert Ballesteros, 27 of New York, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building and was sentenced to 36 months of probation for his role in the Capitol Raid. "On Jan. 6, Robert Ballesteros posted a video on his Instagram account from inside the U.S. Capitol, according to court documents. The next day, a person who had known him for years turned him into the FBI, which later recovered a conversation on his Instagram account. In the exchange, Ballesteros is asked whether he stormed the building. He replies: "Put my foot in that door" and "Made my stand."" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Sandlin & DeGrave
Charges: 18:1512(k) - Conspiracy; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:111(a)(1), 2 - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3), 2 - Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds;
Additional details: Boogaloo affiliation; Originally from Tampico, Tamaulipas, Mexico; resident of Las Vegas, Nevada; "sentenced to 63 months in prison, followed by three years of supervised release, for conspiracy to obstruct an official proceeding and assaulting, resisting, or impeding officers during the January 6, 2021 breach of the U.S. Capitol."
Short narrative: In 2021, in Washington D.C., Ronald Lawrence Sandlin, 31, of Las Vegas, Nevada, was charged with Assaulting, Resisting or Impeding Certain Officers; Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an official proceeding; Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; Impeding passage through the Capitol grounds or buildings; Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings; Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building following his particpation in the Capitol riot. Sandlin was identified via numerous photographs taken inside the Capitol and was filmed smoking marijuana in the rotunda of the Capitol building.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Article, Local News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Guy Wesley Reffitt
Group affiliation: Three Percenters (III Percenters, 3%ers); Texas Freedom Force
Charges: 18:231(a)(2) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(a)(2)(C) Obstruction of Justice – Hindering Communication Through Physical Force or Threat of Physical Force
Additional details: member of III%ers; 1st defendant convicted via trial
Short narrative: Guy Wesley Reffitt, 48, of Wylie, TX, has been charged with obstruction and knowingly entering a restricted building or grounds without lawful authority, related to siege at the US Capitol on 1/6/21...Reffitt's affidavit states hat he is a member of "a militia extremist group,"..."and allege he threatened members of his family following the attack on the Capitol....He was located in surveillance video and the FBI located his cell phone in the area at he time of the crime...He, along with his spouse, daughter and adult son were there at the time the warrant was being served, according to the affidavit...His son explained to authorities that Reffitt told him and other family members he had gone to D.C. to "protect the country" and that he had brought a gun [AR-15 and pistol] with him...He had allegedly told his son and others though, that "we stormed the Capitol," according to the document. The son said he had also recorded footage of the events on the GoPro camera he had been wearing on his helmet...Federal officials allege Reffitt tried to stop his family members from contacting law enforcement about a federal offense, an obstruction of justice, in addition to unlawfully entering Capitol grounds." (ABC News)
Source description: Charging documents, Government reports and releases, news articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Sandlin & DeGrave
Charges: 18:1512(k) - Conspiracy; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:111(a)(1), 2 - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3), 2 - Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds;
Additional details: Resident of NV; Boogaloo affiliation
Short narrative: On February 5, 2021, in Washington D.C., Nathaniel J. DeGrave, age 31, of Las Vegas, Nevada, was charged with assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers, civil disorder, obstruction of an official proceeding, entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a capitol building, impeding passage through the capitol grounds or buildings, parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a capitol building, and acts of physical violence in the capitol grounds or buildings. DeGrave entered the Capitol building during the January 6 riot and shoved a Capitol police officer while inside. His actions were motivated by his rightist: anti-government beliefs.
Source description: Court Documents, Local news articles, Charging documents, Governmental reports and release

Name of case: United States of America v. Ferrigno & Connor
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and distruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Resident of NY; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced 9/15/2022 to 12 months of probation, including two months of home confinement, $371 fine, $500 restitution, 60 hours of community service."
Short narrative: Antonio Ferrigno, 26, and his co-defendant Francis Connor who both reside in Brooklyn, New York pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol building. He was sentenced to 12 months probation. "The FBI identified Antonio Ferrigno Jr. in an Instagram photo posted by Anton Lunyk, who is also charged in the Jan. 6, 2021, insurrection. The photo shows Ferrigno posing inside the U.S. Capitol alongside Lunyk and another man charged in the riot, Francis Connor, court documents indicate. In text messages obtained by the FBI and sent by Ferrigno to Lunyk, Ferrigno denied being inside the Capitol. In one message, he claimed an earlier video he sent of Connor climbing out a Senate Wing window, was "air dropped" to him, court documents indicate. In another, he reportedly wrote: "I wasn't in the Capitol so idc." However, the FBI identified him in security camera footage from inside the building and in the background of a video shot by the far-right figure known as "Baked Alaska," according to court documents." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Ferrigno & Connor
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and distruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Resident of NY; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced 9/15/ 22 to 12 months of probation, including three months of home confinement, $371 fine, $500 restitution, 60 hours of community service."
Short narrative: Francis Connor, 23, and his co-defendant Antonio Ferrigno who both reside in Brooklyn, New York pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol building for his involvement in the Capitol riot. He was sentenced to 12 months probation. "Law enforcement identified Francis Connor in an Instagram photo posted by another person charged in the Jan. 6, 2021, riot, Anton Lunyk. The photo allegedly shows Connor, Lunyk and a third man charged, Antonio Ferrigno Jr., standing inside the U.S. Capitol. The FBI was able to link both Connor and Ferrigno to the photo based on the email addresses used to log into Instagram, court documents indicate. Connor and Ferrigno also reportedly appear in a livestreamed video shot by the far-right media personality known as "Baked Alaska." In a group message on Instagram with Lunyk and Ferrigno, Connor also allegedly wrote, "I was in the Capitol building."" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. James Douglas Rahm III
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of NJ; Father also arrested
Short narrative: On September 17, 2021, Douglas Rahm III was indicted on charges of Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; knowingly attempting to impede or disrupt the orderly conduct of government business; obstruction of Congress; violent entry and disorderly conduct following his involvement in the January 6th Capitol Riots. ..."The FBI field office in Newark, New Jersey tweeted that Rahm had been arrested on Feb. 5. No information on his charges is available, but court documents show he was released on a $100,000 bond with the stipulation that he submit to random drug testing and refrain from excessive use of alcohol." (USA Today). Rahm pleaded not guilty and sentencing information is pending. Rham's father, James Douglas Rham, Jr., was also arrested following his involvement at the Capitol on January 6th, 2021.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Amy Schubert
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;

Short narrative: John A. Schubert, 71, along with his wife Amy Schubert from Crest Hill, IL, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for his role in the Capitol raid. He was sentenced to 18 months probation. "In March of 2021, an anonymous tip to the FBI identified the couple, court documents say. A federal magistrate judge authorized a search warrant for the email of Schubert’s wife that reportedly placed them both inside the building. Schubert was released on bond." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. John A. Schubert Jr.
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;

Schubert from Crest Hill, IL, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for her role in the Capitol raid. She was sentenced to 18 months probation. "Schubert is seen on footage taken within the building, wearing a black jacket with the text "Plumbers & Pipefitters Local Union 422 Joliet IL" on the back, court documents say. A federal magistrate judge authorized a search warrant for her email account that reportedly showed she was present inside the Capitol on that day. A neighbor told a local CBS station that the Crest Hill, Ill., couple had posted Trump signs on public property multiple times." (NPR)

Name of case: United States of America v. Dawn Frankowski
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of IL; Became member of Oath Keepers in 2012; Sentenced on 11/30/2022 to 18 months of probation, $750 fine, $500 restitution and $10 special assessment; 100 hours of community service
Short narrative: Dawn Frankowski ("Dawn Maga"), 53 of Naperville, Illinois, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building during the Capitol riot. She was charged with David Wiersma after they spent 11 minutes in the Capitol, entered the private hideaway office of U.S. Sen. Jeff Merkley, D-Oregon, and entered the Senate spouses’ lounge. She sentenced to 18 months of probation, $750 fine, $500 restitution and $10 special assessment; 100 hours of community service. She is a member of III%ers
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Oliver Louis Sarko
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of OH; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Sentenced 4/29/22 to 30 days in jail and 36 months of probation, and $500 restitution.
Short narrative: Oliver Louis Sarko, 25, of OH, was initially charged with Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; and Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds via complaint, but was officially charged via Informaiton Sheet with Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;for his role in the January 6th Capitol riot. Sarko posted several videos on Jan. 6 to his Snapchat account, with videos taken from both inside and outside the U.S. Capitol building. In one, Sarko can be heard saying, "We are storming the Capitol out here," “We’re actually breaking in right now," and "Bring out Pelosi." One video has the caption, "We're in," and shows a room that appears to be inside the Capitol. Law enforcement also identified Sarko on surveillance video taken from inside the building, court documents say." (Statement of Facts). Sarko pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; and was sentenced to 30 days in jail and 36 months of probation, and $500 restitution.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental reports and release (DOJ), News article

Name of case: United States of America v. Joshua Dillon Haynes
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1), (2), and (4) Unlawful entry on restricted grounds, disorderly conduct, act of physical violence on grounds; 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding; 18:1363 Destruction of property in special maritime and territorial jurisdiction; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent entry or disorderly conduct; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical violence on grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parade, dmonstrate, or picket in any of the Capitol Buildings
Additional details: Resident of VA, "Sentenced 2/2/23 to 32 months in prison, restitution, to be determined at a future date, and 36 months of supervised release"
Short narrative: Joshua Dillion Haynes, 39 of Virginia, pled guilty to Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Destruction of Property in the Territorial Jurisdiction. He was sentenced to 32 months in prison for his role in the Capitol Raid. He was recorded on video attacking members of the media at a staging area near the Capitol, crushing their equipment and stealing their camera. According to local news reporting, Haynes was angry specifically at CNN. "Court documents also show images taken from another video that allegedly show Haynes, along with two others, attempting to pull an air conditioning unit from outside the Capitol building. Haynes was identified by a tipster who used publicly available facial recognition software to match images from photos with a post from a Parler profile, and agents subsequently pulled the subscriber records to find a phone number and email address. Search warrant records for the phone reportedly show that Haynes used it the day of the riot to take pictures inside the Capitol and at the media staging area, and to text with friends. One selfie depicted Haynes inside the office of a U.S. senator, court documents indicate. Later, texts were allegedly exchanged between Haynes and other individuals that indicated he had broken windows and crawled into the Capitol. Prosecutors say one friend texted Haynes the message “dont [sic] be like antifa tearing stuff up.” Haynes replied, “ahhhh tooooo late,” “broke lotsa stuff,” and then “lol.” Haynes reportedly indicated he was seen destroying media equipment, saying "i Kicked the fake news a**" and "I am in the video destroying stuff but I'm wearing a mask." FBI agents went to Haynes' house and interviewed him at length. Haynes allegedly said he believed riot suspects were being treated badly in contrast to people who had participated in Black Lives Matter protests and that he respected those who used force against law enforcement to "stop the election from being stolen." Haynes attended a Proud Boys meeting in late 2020, court documents indicate, but denied he was a member of the far-right extremist group, saying he "would have joined the chapter, but it was too far away and there were no members of the Proud Boys in his local area."" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Krzywicki & Lavin
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

Short narrative: Jean Lavin, 56, and daughter Carla Krzywicki, 19, were arrested on several charges following their participation in the breaching of the U.S. Capitol on 6 January 2021. Both women can allegedly be seen on video wearing pro-Trump clothing and walking throughout the Capitol, while Lavin allegedly carried a sign with the message "Trump Won" and "Don't allow seven states of cheaters to hijack our election." Both women have pled guilty to the single charge of parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building. As they await sentencing, they have been ordered to $500.00 in restitution for damage to the Captiol building.

Name of case: United States of America v. David Antionio Ticas
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of CA; USMC veteran; "Sentenced 7/15/22 to 14 days of incarceration, 24 months of probation, 60 hours community service, and $500 restitution."
Short narrative: David Antonia Ticas, 40 of Georgia, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building and was sentenced to 14 days of incarceration and 24 months of probation for his role in the Capitol Raid. "According to court documents, Ticas appears in the Crypt of the U.S. Capitol giving a thumbs up, with the caption, "Storm the Capital [sic]! #StopTheSteal #DemocratsAreCriminals..." The witness identified Ticas as a veteran of the U.S. Marine Corps from their prior service together. The day after the riot, Ticas allegedly posted a picture of the outside of the Capitol that was removed as a community guidelines violation. He added later, "I guess only the clowns of BLM & Antifa can post their peaceful protests." Later messages on his Instagram page allegedly record Ticas saying: "These politicians are straight up criminals. There is a reason for this non-pandemic to continue, it’s the nwo trying to get rid of Trump.” Google location data places Ticas at and inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, court documents indicate. In addition, surveilliance footage also allegedly shows him entering the building, walking through the Crypt, and exiting the building. Additional body camera footage captures him yelling "God damn politicians, don’t f***ing touch me" on his way out, according to court documents." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Article
