Additional details: Resident of TN; Former county sheriff employee (Wiliamson County, GA) and deputy sheriff (Cherokee county, GA)
Short narrative: "Logan James Barnhart, 40, of Lansing, Michigan, and Ronald Colton McAbee, 27, of Unionville, Tennessee, are charged with federal offenses that include assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon (Barnhart) and inflicting bodily injury (McAbee) and aiding and abetting, among other charges. This afternoon, Barnhart made his initial court appearance in the Western District of Michigan and McAbee made his initial court appearance in the Middle District of Tennessee...The second superseding indictment unsealed today also adds charges for three of five previously indicted defendants: Jeffrey Sabol, Michael Lopatic Sr. and Jack Wade Whitton. Sabol, arrested January 2021, and Lopatic, arrested February 2021, were both initially charged with assault on law enforcement and entering or remaining on restricted grounds, among other allegations. Sabol is further charged with obstruction of an official proceeding, civil disorder and two additional counts of assaulting or impeding officers. Lopatic is additionally charged with obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting, and theft in a federal enclave. Jack Wade Whitton, arrested in April 2021, is charged with an additional count of assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers. Sabol and Whitton remain detained." (DIJ press release)
Source description: Charging documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Philip James Weisbecker
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of CA; claimed to CBP that damage to the buiulding from from "Antifa"; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced 6/27/22 to 24 months of probation with 30 days of intermittent incarceration on weekends, $2000 fine, $500 restitution"
Short narrative: Phillip James Weisbecker, 50, was part of the crowd that entered and paraded about the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021.  The FBI was notified of his participation by two anonymous tips, including photo evidence of Weisbecker in the U.S. Capitol.  The FBI received records proving that Weisbecker had taken a plane to Washington, D.C. on January 5.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Nathan Wayne Entrekin
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(C)(i) - Disruption of Official Business; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of AZ; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Sentenced 5/6/22 to 45 days in jail, 36 months of probation, including 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: Nathan Wayne Entrekin was one of the many who paraded about the Capitol on January 6.  While there, he was dressed as Captain Moroni, a character from the Book of Mormon.  In photos of the defendant on the day of the event, he is carrying a wooden dowel with a piece of white cloth attached. The cloth appears to have the following text handwritten on it: IN MEMORY OF OUR GOD, OUR RELIGION, AND FREEDOM, AND OUR PEACE, OUR WIVES, AND OUR CHILDREN. ALMA 46:12. This is a message taken from the Book of Mormon, attributed to Captain Moroni.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Mark Kulas, Jr.
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: No complaint or affidavit located; Sentenced 4/26/22 to six months supervised probation, including 60 days home detention, $500 restitution
Short narrative: On January 6, 2021, Mark Kulas Jr. was present at President Trump's rally with his brother before heading over to the U.S. Capitol.  He entered the Capitol building and paraded around the interior.  No evidence has shown that Kulas participated in any violence or damaged the building in any way.  He was charged with parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Fassell & Fassell
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of FL; USAF veteran; Wife also arrested; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced - 12/9/22 to 24 months probation, 7 days intermittent incarceration, $500 restitution"
Short narrative: "Fassell, a disabled Air Force veteran and former postal worker, according to the Tampa Bay Times, drove with his wife Marilyn from Florida to participate in the rally in Washington D.C. to support President Trump. A relative of one of his co-workers tipped the FBI to the Fassell's identities after he showed pvideos of himself and his wife inside the Capitol." (USA Today)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Fassell & Fassell
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of FL; Husband also arrested; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced - 12/9/22 to 30 days incarceration, 36  months supervised release, $500 restitution"
Short narrative: "Fassell and her husband Thomas Fassell turned themselves in to federal authorities in Florida, after being interviewed by the FBI, which found videos taken inside the Capitol on her husband's phone. Fassell frequently posts on Facebook in support of President Trump, and a variety of conspiracy theories. In one video on the phone, the FBI reported that she said "We busted in the Capitol" and in another: "This is my house, we pay taxes for this." Court documents state she posed for a selfie-style photo in the Capitol, smoking a cigarette." (USA Today)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Thomas Patrick Hamner
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) and (b), 2 - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:231(a)(3), 2 - Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of CO; Pleaded guilty 5/17/21 to Count 2 of the indictment (civil disorder); "Sentenced 9/23/22 on Count 2 to 30 months in prison, 36 months of supervised release, $2,000 restitution; all other charges remain pending."
Short narrative: Thomas Hamner, 48, from Colorado was arrested for crimes related to the breach of the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, which disrupted a joint session of the U.S. Congress that was in the process of ascertaining and counting the electoral votes related to the presidential election. He is charged with engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds, civil disorder, and assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers with a dangerous weapon, among other charges. He was arrested in Colorado Springs.
Source description: Charging Documents, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Philip Sean Grillo
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of Glen Oaks, New York
Short narrative: 2021, in Washington, DC, Philip Grillo, 46, of Glen Oaks, NY, Republican district leader climbed into the Capitol through a broken window and taken into custody on a felony charge. He's a state committee member for Assembly District 24 and calls himself the "Republican Messiah". He is also a member of the Catholic fraternal organization 'Knights of Columbus, St. Anne's Council". Grillo was charged with unlawful entry on restricted buildings or grounds, violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds, and obstruction of justice/Congress.
Source description: Local News Articles, Charging Documents

Name of case: United State of America v. Christian Manley
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assualting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
Additional details: Resident of AL
Short narrative: "Federal prosecutors allege that Christian Manley was captured on video approaching the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6 while "holding what appears to be a container of pepper spray" and wearing military-style clothing and a backpack. Manley, court documents state, then sprayed pepper spray at a group of police officers guarding an entry by the lower west terrace of the Capitol. After that canister appeared to be empty, Manley allegedly threw it at the officers and discharged a second can of pepper spray at police. Prosecutors allege that Manley then received a metal rod from other rioters and threw it at police. According to an arrest warrant filed in court, the FBI arrested Manley in Anchorage, Alaska, on Oct. 15." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Daniel Charles Rhine
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted builidng or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Resident of WA
Short narrative: "David Rhine came to the attention of the FBI just days after the riot at the U.S. Capitol, and court documents point to two tipsters who said they knew that he had been in the Capitol during the riot. The FBI identified him from information provided by the tipsters, and a review of records obtained by search warrant indicate that a cellphone number Rhine subscribed to was associated with location data in and around the Capitol on Jan 6. The first tipster allegedly saw a screenshot of a post by Rhine's wife. That post stated that Rhine had been at the rally that day and entered the Capitol, and went on to say she was proud of her husband's actions, according to charging documents. When the tipster texted both Rhine and his wife to encourage him to share information he had, presumably with law enfrorcement, Rhine allegedly replied "I witenessd ZERO violence. I saw no 'proud boys'. Capitol police removed barriers and let people in." Later the tipster identified an image from inside the Capitol building as David Rhine, and more images of that day indicate that the man identified as Rhine was detained by an officer who searched him and found two knives and pepper spray, court documents state. Rhine appears to have been escorted down to the Rotunda, where he left the building." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Timothy J. Desjardins
Charges: 18:111(a) Assaulting a Federal Officer; 18:111(b) Assault on a Federal Officer; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of RI
Short narrative: Prosecutors allege that Timothy Desjardins arrived at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, carrying a backpack with three axes in it, assaulted police with a broken table leg, and later tried to breach chains near FBI headquarters. Desjardins' alleged assault of law enforcement took place during the infamous struggle in the tunnel of the lower west terrace, where he was allegedly seen in YouTube videos striking officers over and over again with “a significant amount of force.” Another tip from an FBI officer reported that Desjardins was caught the day after the riot in the early morning hours at FBI headquarters, trying to go over chains behind the building. When he was approached by officers, he reportedly showed his driver’s license, and officers noticed he had a couple of hatchets on the side of his backpack, which he claimed he was “good with." Desjardins was allowed to leave after it was determined there were no outstanding warrants for him. Court records state that Desjardins was later confirmed to be at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, by agents who compared the video from that day with both his driver’s license and mugshots from an arrest months earlier in which he allegedly fired a shot in a Providence Walgreens parking lot. Two weeks before his arrest on charges related to the Capitol riot, Desjardins was arrested in an armed standoff with police in Providence on unrelated charges. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Brandon Prenzlin
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parade, Demonstrate, or Picket in any of the Capitol Buildings
Additional details: Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced 6/28/22 to 10 months of probation, $2500 fine, $500 restitution, 120 hours of community service."
Short narrative: Brandon Prezlin, 26, was charged with four federal offenses relating to entering the Capitol on Jan 6 2020 after being identified in CCTV and police body camera images taken inside the building. He pled guilty to the fourth count of Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building in exchange for all other charges being dropped.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Rafael Valadez Jr.
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and remaining in a restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of CA; Indicted by a Bill of Information
Short narrative: Rafael Valadez Jr. is accused by federal law enforcement of livestreaming his participation in the U.S. Capitol riots on Jan. 6, 2021. The video, which the FBI alleges was taken by Valadez, allegedly shows him entering the U.S. Capitol. Further review of surveillance camera footage from inside the Capitol shows a man that the FBI identifies as Valadez, and video from Facebook obtained through a search warrant shows the videos that were apparently livestreamed, court documents indicate. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Michael Aaron Carico
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Indicted by a Bill of Informationl; Wore Navy hat but FBI claims no history of military service; Sentenced 3/11/22 to 24 months of probation, including 60 days of home detention; $500 restitution; $500 fine; 60 hours of community service
Short narrative: "A confidential source, who was present at the U.S. Capitol grounds on Jan. 6, provided video to the FBI that allegedly shows Michael Aaron Carico wearing a camouflage shirt and a green hat backward with the word “NAVY” printed on it. According to the FBI, however, Carico did not serve in any of the branches of the U.S. military. According to court documents, a search warrant was issued for Carico’s Gmail account through which the FBI obtained a 30-second video that allegedly shows him singing the last lines of the national anthem and then looking directly into the camera and saying: “Hey Nancy, go f*** yourself,” referring to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi. Later, additional closed circuit TV footage shows him alongside another individual walking around the Capitol Rotunda, court documents indicate." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Paul Scott Westover
Charges: 40:5104 (e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building (misdemeanor)
Additional details: Sentenced 4/11/22 to 45 days in jail, $500 restitution; indicted via Information; Plead guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building, in violation of Title 40, United States Code, Section 5104(e)(2)(G). Sentenced 4/11/22 to 45 days in jail, $500 restitution
Short narrative: Paul Scott Westover, 52, of St. Louis, MO, was charged with Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building for his role in the January 6th riot. Westover was identified via numerous tips provided to the FBI as well as photographs taken inside the Capitol. Westover pled guilty, and was sentenced to 45 days in jail, $500 restitution.
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, Local news article, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Marcos Gleffe
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of IL; Indicted by a Bill of Information
Short narrative: A longtime friend of Marcos Gleffe's contacted the FBI after seeing a Facebook post from Gleffe that indicated he had been at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, according to a criminal complaint. The FBI was then able to trace Gleffe's cellphone location that day and confirmed that the device had been inside the building, court documents indicate. Gleffe is also allegedly in security camera footage inside the building, where he can be seen holding a flag that reads, "TRUMP 2020 MAKE AMERICA GREAT AGAIN." In a May 3, 2021, interview with the FBI, Gleffe reportedly admitted to being inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, and said he decided to do so after he overheard people at the pro-Trump rally saying they were going to storm the building. He told the FBI he had made the "biggest mistake going through the door" and would take it back if he could, according to court documents. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Jeremy Daniel Groseclose
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Released on a $20,000 bond
Short narrative: Jeremy Daniel Groseclose, 38, of VA, was charged with Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for his particiaption in the January 6th riot. Groseclose's location and participation was confirmed via the Google estiamted location of his cellphone during the riot and tipster accounts of his particiaption. Groseclose has pled not guilty and the case is currently pending.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Matthew Council
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil DIsorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Riverview, FL; Released on personal recognizance bond; Banned from Washington D.C.; "Matthew Council Sentencing held on 12/12/2022 as to MATTHEW COUNCIL. Defendant's motion for downward departure, granted. Counts 1s, 2s, 3s, 4s, 5s, 6s: Defendant sentenced to a term of Sixty (60) Months Probation, on each count, all counts to run concurrently, including 180 days of Home Incarceration with Location Monitoring. Special assessment of $100, as to each of Counts 1s and 2s; $25 as to each of Counts 3s and 4s, and $10, as to each of Counts 5s and 6s, for a total of $270. Restitution in the amount of $2000. Defendant shall complete 100 hours of community service as approved by the Probation Office."
Short narrative: Matthew Ross Council, 49, of Riverview, FL, was charged on Jan. 7, 2021, with Civil DIsorder; Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. While being apprehended inside the Capitol, Council pushed and pepper sprayed officers. Ross pled not guilty. Ross was released on personal recognizance bond, and was banned from Washington D.C.. This case is currently pending. [Note: Status conference is set for 08/27/21]
Source description: Charging documents, Cours documents, Governmental reports and releases (DOJ), News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Timothy Earl O'Malley
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of FL; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Wore batting helmet and stated that "his biggest fear was Antifa throwing rocks" as they had "sacks of concrete rocks" according to FBI affadavit; Sentenced 4/12/22 to 24 months’ probation, including 20 hours community service, and $500 restitution
Short narrative: "Prosecutors allege that at least two people called the FBI to report that Timothy Earl O'Malley had been at the Jan. 6 riot at the U.S. Capitol and that one of those tipsters said O'Malley has previously identified himself as a Proud Boy. In an interview with the FBI, O'Malley said that he drove to Washington, D.C., from Florida to attend the pro-Trump rally. According to court documents, O'Malley wore a red softball batting helmet with a "Trump is my president" bumper sticker on the side, because he said he had heard that antifa followers had sacks of rocks they were planning to throw. In his interview, O'Malley described the scene at the Capitol as "mayhem" and admitted to entering the building, where he can allegedly also be seen on security camera footage. The FBI also obtained videos from O'Malley's cellphone through a warrant. In one video, O'Malley allegedly yells, "WE FOUGHT OUR WAY, ALL THE WAY IN THERE. AND WE FOUGHT OUR WAY BACK OUT ... WE SWARMED THE CAPITOL, THOUGH. HOT DAMN."" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Ricky C. Willden
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of CA; "Sentenced 8/5/22 to two years in prison, three years of supervised release, $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative: "Publicly available videos show Ricky Christopher Willden cheering at the Capitol building on Jan. 6 near the east door around 2:30 in the afternoon, wearing a dark jacket, beanie cap and gloves, according to court documents. About10 minutes later, he can be seen raising his hand and spraying an unknown substance from a green can toward police officers standing guard. According to the FBI, Willden is a self-proclaimed member of the far right-extremist group The Proud Boys, whose members describe themselves as "Western Chauvinists."" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Howard Berton Adams
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Indicted by Bill of Information
Short narrative: On December 10, 2021, the U.S. DOJ issued a superseding indictment against Howard Berton Adams, 57, following his involvement in the January 2021 U.S. Capitol riots. Adams, whose presence at the Capitol was confirmed in images taken inside the building, pled not guilty to all counts. He remains on personal recognizance.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Knowlton & Montgomery
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(B) Entering and remaining in the gallery of congress; 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting
Additional details: Resident of CO
Short narrative: On April 16, 2021, Brady Knowlton, age 40, of Utah; and Patrick Montgomery, age 48, of Colorado, were charged with entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building; entering and remaining in the Gallery of Congress; and obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting. Montgomery was additionally charged with assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; civil disorder; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; and an act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings. Knowlton and Montgomery both entered the Senate Chambers during the January 6 riot and at some point during the riot, Montgomery wrestled a Metropolitan Police Officer to the ground in a fight for the officer’s baton and kicked the officer in the chest. The two men were motivated by their rightist: anti-government ideology.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News, News articles, Governmental reports and release

Name of case: United States of America v. Knowlton & Montgomery
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(B) Entering and remaining in the gallery of congress; 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting
Additional details: Resident of UT
Short narrative: On April 16, 2021, Brady Knowlton, age 40, of Utah; and Patrick Montgomery, age 48, of Colorado, were charged with entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building; entering and remaining in the Gallery of Congress; and obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting. Montgomery was additionally charged with assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; civil disorder; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; and an act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings. Knowlton and Montgomery both entered the Senate Chambers during the January 6 riot and at some point during the riot, Montgomery wrestled a Metropolitan Police Officer to the ground in a fight for the officer’s baton and kicked the officer in the chest. The two men were motivated by their rightist: anti-government ideology.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News, News articles, Governmental reports and release

Name of case: United States of America v. Klein & Klein
Charges: 18:371 Conspiracy; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:231(a)(3), 2 Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1361, 2 Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds
Additional details: Resident of OR; Brother also arrested
Short narrative: On March 23rd, 2021, Jonathanpeter Klein and his brother Matthew Leland Klein, both self-proclaimed members of the Proud Boys, were indicted on charges of 18:371 Conspiracy; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:231(a)(3), 2 Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1361, 2 Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; and 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds. Both pleaded not guilty to the charges, and their sentencing is pending. The Kleins came to the attention of law enforcement in fall 2020 when they attended Proud Boys rallies in Oregon. According to court records, Jonathanpeter Klein was seen at rallies in body armor and carrying a paintbull gun, and was photographed shooting the paintball gun at "an unknown target." On Jan. 6, federal prosecutors allege, Matthew and Jonathanpeter Klein joined with the mob and other members of the Proud Boys to breach the Capitol. Once inside, prosecutors said, Jonathanpeter Klein was seen engaging in a "celebratory exchange" with another Proud Boys member and displayed a Proud Boys hand signal. After the initial breach, the men allegedly exited the building and then "joined together to wrench open a secure door on the Capitol’s north side," allowing more rioters to enter the building "as part of a second or third wave of attacks."
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United State of America v. Julio Chang
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of FL; Indicted by a Bill of Information; previously employed by Broward County Sheriff's Office (Statement of Facts) and USMC for 20 years deploted in Afghanistan
Short narrative: "An anonymous tipster contacted the FBI and said Julio Cesar Chang had posted photos from the Jan. 6 riot on Facebook, according to a statement of facts filed in federal court. Chang allegedly posted photos of himself wearing a pro-Trump hat by the U.S. Capitol, along with the caption: "The deplorables have taken back our country." In another post cited in court documents, Chang captioned a video from near the Washington Monument, "The beginning of our Second American Revolution." Prosecutors allege that celphone records and surveillance footage show that Chang breached the Capitol building during the riot and made it inside the Rotunda. Chang previously worked for the Broward County Sheriff's Office in Florida, the court documents state, and one of his former co-workers provided information to the FBI during its investigation into Chang. The Broward County Sheriff's Office confirmed to NPR that Chang worked there from 1991 to 2005 and said he retired at the rank of lieutenant. A spokesperson for the U.S. Marine Corps also confirmed that Chang served on active duty for nearly two decades, reaching the rank of gunnery sergeant. In 2003, he deployed to Afghanistan as part of Operation Enduring Freedom." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Baquero & Valentin
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of FL; roommate also arrested
Short narrative: "Julio Baquero came to the attention of law enforcement through a tip to the FBI about a week after the events of Jan. 6, court documents indicate. Baquero allegedly traveled to Washington, D.C., with his friend and roommate Louis Valentin, and allegedly told law enforcment in an interview that he had entered the U.S. Capitol building during the insurrection. According to a federal filing, video footage from inside the Capitol shows Baquero entering the Capitol Rotunda and, in one instance, grabbing the hand of a police officer as law enforcement attempted to clear the building. At another point, Baquero is allegedly seen on camera shouding at officers, "You're a traitor!"" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Baquero & Valentin
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of FL; roommate also arrested
Short narrative: "Law enforcement was first alerted about Louis Valentin approximately one week after Jan. 6, according to court documents. Prosecutors say he had gone to Washington, D.C., with his friend and roommate Julio Baquero, and in a March 2021 interview, he allegedly acknowledged being inside the U.S. Capitol on the day of the insurrection. According to a federal filing, Valentin can be observed on camera footage entering the Capitol wearing a red hat and flag mask. While law enforcement asserts that Baquero physically and verbally confronted officers attempting to clear the Capitol, they make no similar claim about Valentin." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Christopher Warnagiris
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disroderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(2)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Virginia; USMC major currently (October 2021) under review for possible discharge
Short narrative: "Major Christopher Warnagiris, 40, of Woodbridge, is charged with federal offenses that include assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder; and obstruction of justice, among other charges. According to court documents and security camera footage, Warnagiris violently entered the Capitol on Jan. 6, after pushing through a line of police officers guarding the East Rotunda doors. Once inside, Warnagiris positioned himself in the corner of the doorway, using his body to keep the door open and pull others inside. When a U.S. Capitol Police (USCP) officer tried to pull the doors shut, Warnagiris refused and continued pushing it open. Warnagiris can be seen pushing the officer in an effort to maintain his position in the open door in security camera footage. "- DOJ Warnagiris, whose 18-year tenure in the Marines includes deployments to Iraq and Afghanistan, faces a maximum possible sentence of 20 years in prison if convicted of the charges, which will be prosecuted in federal court in Washington.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Daniel Dink Phipps
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers and Physical Contact; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Indicted by Bill of Information first, now has an indictment
Short narrative: Daniel Phipps from Ft. Worth Texas, has been charged with unlawful entry and violent entry in connection to the January 6th Capitol protests.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. John Douglas Wright
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2),2 Obstruction of an official proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in the Capitol grounds or buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building; 18:1001 False statement to Federal agent
Additional details: Resident of OH; "Sentenced 3/6/23 to 49 months in prison, 36 months of supervised release and $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative: "A person reported a tip to the FBI that Wright admitted to them that he was detained inside the Capitol rotunda during the Jan. 6 riot. Wright said he was sprayed with a chemical agent and forced to the ground. According to arrest reports, the claims are backed by photos and video evidence." (USA Today)
Source description: Charging Documents

Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Source description: Charging Documents

Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 18:111(a) Assaulting a Federal Officer;
Additional details: Resident of SD
Short narrative: Federal prosecutors allege that James Haffner took part in the U.S. Capitol riot along with another man from the Seattle area named Ronald Loehrke. According to documents filed in federal court, Loehrke communicated in December 2020 with Ethan Nordean, a leader of the extremist group the Proud Boys who is facing conspiracy charges connected to the Jan. 6, 2021, attack. Nordean allegedly told Loehrke that he wanted Loehrke "on the front line" with him on Jan. 6, 2021. Loehrke allegedly agreed and said he was bringing three "Bad mother f******" with him to Washington, D.C. On the day of the attack, prosecutors say, Haffner and Loehrke marched with members and associates of the Proud Boys toward the Capitol. They then allegedly dismantled barriers protecting the outside of the Capitol building, and, at one point, Haffner allegedly used an aerosol spray against an officer with the U.S. Capitol Police guarding an outer door. Soon after, prosecutors say, Haffner, Loehrke and other rioters were able to breach the building through that door and can be seen in video footage taken inside the building. Haffner was arrested in Rapid City, S.D., on Dec. 1, 2021. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of WA
Short narrative: Federal prosecutors allege that Ronald Loehrke took part in the U.S. Capitol riot along with another man from the Seattle area named James Haffner. According to documents filed in federal court, Loehrke communicated in December 2020 with Ethan Nordean, a leader of the extremist group the Proud Boys who is facing conspiracy charges connected to the Jan. 6, 2021, attack. Nordean allegedly told Loehrke that he wanted Loehrke "on the front line" with him on Jan. 6, 2021. Loehrke allegedly agreed and said he was bringing three "Bad mother f******" with him to Washington, D.C. On the day of the attack, prosecutors say, Loehrke and Haffner marched with members and associates of the Proud Boys toward the Capitol. They then allegedly dismantled barriers protecting the outside of the Capitol building. When a line of police protecting the outside of the Capitol stopped people from advancing farther, Loehrke allegedly said, "Don't back down, patriots! The whole f****** world is watching. Stand the f*** up today!" At one point, Haffner allegedly used an aerosol spray against an officer with the U.S. Capitol Police guarding an outer door. Soon after, prosecutors say, Haffner, Loehrke and other rioters were able to breach the building through that door and can be seen in video footage taken inside the building. Ronald Loehrke was arrested in Cumming, Ga., on Dec. 3, 2021. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Michael G. McCormick
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of CA; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced - 12/20/2022 to 14 days incarceration, $1,000 fine, $500 restitution"
Short narrative: Phone records show Michael G. McCormick’s mobile phone remained within the restricted zone around the U.S. Capitol for nearly three hours on Jan. 6, 2021, according to an FBI statement of facts. Surveillance footage allegedly shows McCormick entering the Senate wing at about 2:55 p.m., hand held aloft filming a video on his cellphone. The FBI obtained photos and videos from McCormick’s phone that appear to have been taken inside the Capitol, including an 11-minute clip of his alleged entry into the building and his walk through the Crypt and Hall of Columns. Court records show McCormick was arrested Nov. 18, 2021, in Orange, Calif., and he was ordered to remove firearms from his home by Nov. 20, 2021. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Jia Liu
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of NY; INdicted by a Bill of Information; USMC reserves assigned to Direct Support Company, 6th Communication Battalion, Marine Forces Reserve.
Short narrative: Jia Liu, 26, corporal in the U.S. Marine Corps Reserve was arrested by federal agents and charged with four misdemeanor counts for his alleged participation in the Jan. 6 Capitol riot. Jia Liu, who lives in Queens, New York, became a Marine in 2014 and is a cyber network operator assigned to a communications battalion in Brooklyn. Liu was twice caught on security cameras entering the Capitol by climbing through an open window, according to a criminal complaint filed in Washington, D.C., federal court. He was also spotted on police body cam video during the Capitol siege—his identity was allegedly confirmed by a Marine Corps officer familiar with him—and Liu’s mobile device was located inside the building while the rampage was happening. In February 2022, Liu was accused of conspiring with a nurse (Steven Rodriguez) to defraud the USDHHS by selling fake Covid-19 vaccine cards to USMC reservists. Liu is being charged buy US District Court in Brooklyn, NY for the fraud.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Leo Christopher Kelly
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of Justice/Congress; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(A) Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(C) Disruption of Official Business; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: From Cedar Rapids, Iowa
Short narrative: In 2021, in Washington D.C., Leo Christopher Kelly, 35, of Cedar Rapids, IA, was charged with Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds without Lawful Authority, and Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds. Kelly was identified via a video of an interview with Kelly in which he describes his experience at the Capitol during the riots. Kelly also admits he was a part of the riots in other interviews.
Source description: Charging documents, Court Documents, Local News Article

Name of case: United States of America v. Brent John Holdridge
Group affiliation: Three Percenters (III Percenters, 3%ers), Patriot Boyd of North Texas (PBONT)
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of Justice/Congress; 18:1512(k) Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) and (a)(1)(B) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds resulting in significant bodily injury; 18:1752(a)(2) and (a)(1)(B) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds resulting in significant bodily injury; 18:1752(a)(4) and (a)(1)(B) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(C) Disruption of Official Business; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of TX
Short narrative: Donald Hazard has been charged with engaging in physical violence and assaulting police officers on Jan. 6, 2021, according to court documents. On the day of the riot, Hazard allegedly wore a tan tactical vest, as well as a black helmet with the Confederate flag printed on it. Footage reportedly depicts Hazard grappling with officers as he fell down a set of stairs under a scaffolding erected on the west side of the U.S. Capitol. According to the FBI, Hazard fought with an officer, which resulted in both of them falling. The officer was knocked unconscious and sustained multiple injuries, court records indicate. Prior to Jan. 6, 2021, Hazard allegedly helped recruit members to a self-proclaimed militia group called the Patriot Boys of North Texas, where he served as sergeant of arms. Hazard has been detained, pending further proceedings. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Robert Lee Petrosh
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) and (2) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parding, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Resident of NJ; Charged by Bill of Information; Sentenced 3/30/22 to three years or probation, including 60 days of home detention and 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: Robert Lee Petrosh of Mays Landing, NJ was charged with disorderly conduct in a restricted building and other offenses. A comment by his mother is what may have led to him being charged for his role in the Janaury 2021 Capitol protests.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Howard Charles Richardson
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: ; "Sentenced 8/26/22 to 46 months in prison, three years of probation, $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative: Howard Charles Richardson is alleged to have assaulted a law enforcment officer with a flagpole during the U.S. Capitol insurrection, which was captured on police body cameras. Cameras worn by at least four police officers captured Richardson taking a metal flagpole with a blue Trump flag on it and attacking the officers "unprovoked," a federal filing claimed. "Here it comes," Richardson is allegedly heard yelling before striking an officer three times. The FBI said that Richardson "only stopped swinging after the flagpole broke in his hands." Photos and videos of that act were later used to identify Richardson as the assailant. Richardson was also known to local police in his community due to a separate act in which he allegedly assaulted a motorcyclist outside his residence. In an interview with FBI agents after his arrest for that unrelated act, he acknowledged that he was at the Capitol on the day of the insurrection. He allegedly told the FBI that he had been tear gassed as rioters attempted to breach the perimeter of the Capitol and acknowledged that he was the individual in the body camera videos. "I'm not saying this is the best behavior I could have done here," he said. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Ballnger & Price
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of MD; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Cynthia Ballenger and Christopher Price Found guilty 3/21/23 on counts 1s-4s."
Short narrative: "Cynthia Ballenger didn’t want to share much information regarding her alleged involvement in the Jan. 6 riot at the U.S. Capitol when the FBI interviewed her, court records show. The FBI says Ballenger told investigators they should already know or figure out how she got to Washington, D.C. She reportedly said she planned to meet friends at a cafe but wouldn’t share the names of the friends or the location of the cafe. After an anonymous tip, court documents show the FBI constructed its case against Ballenger through a series of records and video. Ballenger is charged alongside her husband, Christopher Price. Investigators say Facebook records led them to an email and phone number belonging to Ballenger. A search warrant to Google showed a device associated with Ballenger’s email in or near the Capitol, the FBI says. Bank records for Ballenger and Price’s joint credit card show charges the FBI believes to be consistent with the couple traveling by public transit to Union Station in Washington. The FBI also says Ballenger can be seen in surveillance footage from inside the Capitol and the restricted grounds outside. According to court documents, Ballenger was likely inside the Capitol building for seven minutes. Price sent photos of Ballenger to a friend and reportedly noted, “Cynthia smiling but she’s freezing.” In her interview with the FBI, Ballenger said there were different categories of people at the Capitol and that she and her husband were on the “low-end of the spectrum,” according to court documents." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Ballnger & Price
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of MD; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Cynthia Ballenger and Christopher Price Found guilty 3/21/23 on counts 1s-4s."
Short narrative: "Christopher Price would only discuss his presence at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6 in hypothetical terms with the FBI, court documents show. But after an anonymous tip, the FBI was able to construct a trail of records and video that reportedly show Price, along with his wife, Cynthia Ballenger, who is also charged, traveling to Washington, D.C., and entering the Capitol building. Investigators say Facebook records show Price posted about traveling to Union Station in Washington. Someone replied to the post, asking if Price had received “a free tour of the Capitol building today?" Price reportedly replied with a thumbs-up emoji. Facebook records led to an email belonging to Price, which in turn led to a phone number, the FBI says. A search warrant to Google showed a device associated with Price’s email in or near the Capitol, the FBI says. Bank records for Price and Ballenger’s joint credit card show charges the FBI believes to be consistent with the couple traveling by Metro to Union Station. The FBI also says Price can be seen in surveillance footage from inside the Capitol and the restricted grounds outside. Price was likely inside the Capitol building for seven minutes, court records indicate. Phone records showed Price receiving a call from a friend with whom he co-owned a business, investigators say. That friend allegedly showed the FBI texts from Price that included “Worth fighting for Trump” and pictures of people inside the Capitol, according to court documents. The FBI says while Price wouldn’t talk about specifics, he said whatever the consequences of Jan. 6, “it was all in God’s hands now.”" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Ezekiel Kurt Stecher
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; *18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; *40:5104(e)(2)(E) Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; *18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of Justice/Congress;
Additional details: Resident of NJ
Short narrative: "Ezekiel Stecher, of Sewell in Mantua Township, [NJ] is charged with five crimes related to the Jan. 6 riot, including assault on a federal officer and violently entering the Capitol. He made his first appearance in federal court on Tuesday, in Camden...The FBI learned of Stecher’s alleged involvement in the Capitol attack from a video that was uploaded to an FBI tip line on Jan. 18, authorities said. Someone asks a man, “What is your name? Where are you from?” and he replies, “Zeke Stecher from New Jersey,” according to the complaint. The FBI searched New Jersey’s motor vehicle records and found an Ezekiel K. Stecher with an address in Sewell, and found his driver’s license photo looked like the man in the video, an agent wrote in the complaint. Agents then conducted an in-person interview with a local Sewell farmer who purchased produce from Stecher who said they’d known him for over 10 years. An agent showed the person still images from the video and the person identified Stecher as the man they know as “Zeke,” the FBI says in the complaint. In all, the FBI described three videos from the attack in which they say Stecher appears. In one, he allegedly appears against the wall of the lower west terrace of the Capitol, pushing the crowd forward, toward Washington D.C. police officers and into the doors of the U.S. Capitol. Stecher is also allegedly seen in a video in which riot shields are taken from officers and passed back by members of the crowd and Stecher is yelling in the direction of the police. In other videos, the FBI says, Stecher is seen multiple times pushing against police as the rioters squeeze and push through a narrow tunnel. At one point, he is sprayed with a chemical irritant but pushes forward, before eventually retreating from the building. He then pours water on his face." (NJ.com)
Source description: Charging Documents, Local news articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Landon Bryce Mitchell
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) - Obstruction of Justice/Congress; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(1)(A) - Unlawful Possession of a Dangerous Weapon on Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of TX
Short narrative: "Landon Mitchell told friends on Facebook that he was “one of the very first in” during the Jan. 6 U.S. Capitol riot, adding that he is “invincible” and “not too worried” about getting arrested because he was “masked up the whole time,” according to subpoenaed Facebook messages included in an FBI statement of facts. Mitchell attached photos and videos of himself posing on the dais at the front of the Senate chamber. Additionally, surveillance footage shows Mitchell entering the Senate chamber and leafing through documents left on a desk when senators abandoned the room, according to the statement of facts. The court documents also include posts from Mitchell’s Facebook page including the statements, “If we don’t fight now, there is no point in ever voting again” and “when they invalidated my vote with all their chasing, they invalidated my consent to be governed by them!” Luke Bender, a man arrested in July on charges stemming from the riot at the Capitol, also told FBI agents that he and Mitchell, his former co-worker, remained inside the Senate chamber for about five minutes, according to the statement of facts. Mitchell was arrested Oct. 20 in Arlington, Va., and ordered to wear a GPS monitor upon his release. He will appear in court on Dec. 21." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Giddings, et. al.
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of PA
Short narrative: Court documents indicate that Freedom Vy was identified as a person involved in the Jan. 6, 2021, riot after law enforcement obtained and searched the phone records of Zachary Rehl, who is also charged and is the president of the Philadelphia chapter of the Proud Boys, a far-right group. Vy is charged with Brian Healion and Isaiah Giddings, who were all allegedly part of a Telegram message with Rehl and one other unidentified person who was not in Washington, D.C., on Jan. 6, 2021. The group members coordinated their travel from Philadelphia to D.C., including sharing contact information and blood types, and Giddings, Healion and Vy stayed together at The Darcy hotel in D.C. on Jan. 5, 2021, according to court records. On the morning of Jan. 6, 2021, Vy and Healion took a selfie together at the Washington Monument. They both flashed the "OK" hand sign, which is associated with the Proud Boys, according to court documents. The four men then allegedly entered the west side of the Capitol, near the Senate, and appear there in photos and videos. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Giddings, et. al.
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of PA
Short narrative: Law enforcement allegedly identified Isaiah Giddings as a person who participated in the Jan. 6, 2021, riot after searching the phone records of another person charged, Zachary Rehl, who is the president of the Philadelphia chapter of the Proud Boys, a far-right group. Giddings is charged with two other men, Brian Healion and Freedom Vy, who were allegedly part of a Telegram message group with Rehl and another person who was not in Washington, D.C., on the day of the insurrection. The group coordinated travel from Philadelphia to D.C. ahead of Jan. 6, 2021, and Giddings, Healion and Vy stayed together at The Darcy hotel in D.C. on the night before the riot, according to court records. On the day of the riot, Giddings allegedly appeared in a photograph outside the U.S. Capitol with Rehl and others, all flashing the "OK" hand symbol, a gesture associated with the Proud Boys. The four men then allegedly entered the Capitol building, where the four of them appear in several photos and videos. In a reply to a text the next day asking how they were doing, Giddings allegedly wrote: “Yes we have everything and everyone all accounted for ... none of our Philly guys had any PB gear the entire event just plain trump supporters from beginning to end." According to news reports, the Proud Boys were directed not to wear their signature black and yellow on the day of the riot, aiming to blend in with other Trump supporters. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Giddings, et. al.
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of PA
Short narrative: The FBI zeroed in on Brian Healion as a person who entered the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, after the bureau obtained the phone records of another man charged, Zachary Rehl, who is the president of the Philadelphia chapter of the far-right group the Proud Boys, court documents indicate. Healion is charged alongside two others, Isaiah Giddings and Freedom Vy. They were allegedly part of a Telegram message with Rehl and one other unidentified person, who does not appear to be charged. The group members planned their travel together from Philadelphia to D.C., including sharing contact information and blood types, on the day before the riot. Giddings, Healion and Vy then stayed together at The Darcy hotel in D.C., court records say, on the night before the riot. On the morning of Jan. 6, 2021, Vy and Healion took a selfie together at the Washington Monument, each flashing the "OK" hand gesture, which is associated with the Proud Boys, court records indicate. The four men then allegedly entered the west side of the Capitol, near the Senate, where they can be seen in various photos and videos. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. John M. Cameron
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of WA; MAGA hat; "Sentenced 8/15/22 to 36 months of probation, including 30 days of intermittent confinement, $1,000 fine, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: On Jan. 6, 2021, John M. Cameron allegedly posted a video of himself in what appeared to be a Washington, D.C., metro train station, describing his experience at the U.S. Capitol: "Was it pretty? No. Did it make a statement? Yes." According to court documents, he also posted: “The least safe I felt was when walking back to catch train I was told to FU by a little anti fa BLMer on a Vespa who was traveling the opposite direction.” Cameron first came to the attention of the FBI when a tipster provided a link of Cameron’s Facebook account, which allegedly showed him attending President’s Trump “Stop the Steal” rally and his participation in the riot. According to court records, surveillance footage shows him wearing a baseball cap with white "Make America Great Again" lettering and a black hooded sweatshirt covered by a white T-shirt bearing the words "COUNT ALL LEGAL VOTES.” Cameron was also allegedly seen entering the Capitol through the Senate wing door and exiting 22 minutes later through a broken window. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Evan Neumann
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:115(a)(1)(B) Influencing, Impeding, or Retaliating Against a Federal Official; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Fled to Belarus to avoid prosecution; Wore MAGA hat, gas mask, and scarf commemorating the Ukranian Orange Revolution; Expressed support for QAnon-like beliefs; Resident of CA
Short narrative: "Evan Neumann, prosecutors allege, is one of the rioters who engaged law enforcement in a prolonged struggle near a bike rack barricade in front of the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6. Body camera footage allegedly shows Neumann wearing a red “Make America Great Again” hat and wearing a gas mask for some of the time, and yelling at one officer a common QAnon conspiracy theory that the officer is “defending the people who are going to kill your f**king children ... they are gonna kill your f**king children, they are gonna rape them, they are gonna imprison them, and you’re defending the people that are going to do this to your children.” According to court documents, Neumann refused orders by police to move back, and later, after a violent back and forth over the barricade along with other rioters, wrested it from the officers’ hands and used it as a battering ram to break the police line." NPR UPDATE: A US Capitol riot suspect who fled the United States has been granted refugee status in Belarus, according to Belarusian state-owned television BelTA. The California man, Evan Neumann, went to Europe after being charged in connection with the January 6, 2021, attack on the US Capitol. Neumann initially settled in Ukraine, he said in an interview in November, but he claims he traveled to Belarus on foot after noticing that Ukrainian authorities were following him.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Josiah Kenyon
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:1361 Destruction of Government Property; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of NV
Short narrative: Josiah Kenyon allegedly stormed the U.S. Capitol building in costume. The criminal complaint details images of him dressed as Jack Skellington, from the film *The Nightmare before Christmas* -- with the addition of a red Make America Great Again hat. Court documents allege that Kenyon attempted to break a Capitol window with a flagstaff and assaulted law enforcement officers with several objects, including a broken table leg with a nail protruding from it. The FBI had asked for help identifying Kenyon from footage of the riot, and ultimately, it was the Jack Skellington costume that led several witnesses to say that they had seen him on the grounds of the Capitol; on the Washington, D.C., Metro; and at a motel in Springfield, Va., on or around Jan. 6, 2021, court documents indicate. According to court records, two more witnesses, including one relative, positively identified Kenyon from a photograph, and the criminal complaint alleges that FBI agents ultimately confirmed that his bank records and fare purchases at the Metro were consistent with his travel to the site of the Jan. 6, 2021, riot. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Brent John Holdridge
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of CA
Short narrative: Before the U.S. Capitol riot on Jan. 6, 2021, Brent Holdridge was wanted by law enforcement for failing to report to jail in Humboldt County, Calif., to begin serving a four-month sentence for possession of a controlled substance, according to an FBI statement of facts. Holdridge was arrested in February for that offense and, according to the statement of facts, he later showed photos from his trip to Washington, D.C., to his probation officer, although he claimed he stayed outside the Capitol on the day of the riot. However, the probation officer reportedly identified Holdridge in surveillance footage as a man carrying a rolled-up flag through the Capitol, appearing to record video on a cellphone. Additionally, cellphone records appear to show Holdridge's mobile device as having been present in the building during the riot, according to the statement of facts. When interviewed by FBI agents in September, Holdridge allegedly confirmed his presence at the “Stop the Steal” rally, but he refused to answer whether he entered the Capitol, adding that he “did not steal anything, touch or assault anyone, or damage any property.” He surrendered on Dec. 2, 2021, at the Santa Rita Jail in Dublin, Calif. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Danean Kimberly Macandrew
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Mission Viejo, CA
Short narrative: Danean Kimberly Macandrew, of CA, was charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following her participation in the Capitol riot. Macandrew was identified via cell phone location, a video Macandrew posted to her Gab account, and Capitol CCTV footage. The case is currently pending.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Lawrence Ligas
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of IL; Ligas pleaded Not Guilty to all charges
Short narrative: Lawrence Ligas was charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following his participation in the Capitol riot. Ligas was identified via a tip provided to the FBI about his name being in an NPR article, cell phone location inofrmation, and numerous photographs and surveillance footage. The case is currently pending.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Lawrence Dropkin Jr.
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of NJ; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Pled guilty 7/12/22; "Sentenced 10/7/22 to 30 days of incarceration, one year of supervised release, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Lawrence Dropkin Jr., 45, of NJ, was charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for his role in the January 6th Capitol riot. CCTV and screenshots of Facetime footage from a tipster confirms Dropkin's particiption in the riot. Dropkin pled guilty to the charges and was sentenced to 30 days of incarceration, one year of supervised release, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution.
