Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental reports and release (DOJ), News article

Name of case: United States of America v. Jeremy K. Baouche
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of CT; Employed by a DOD contractor with securiry clearence and used a 'secure' computer to conduct pre-operational activities
Short narrative: Jeremy K. Baouche, of CT, was charged with Entering and remaining in a restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following his participation in the Capitol riot. Baouche was identified via a tip provided to the FBI, cell phone location, and a video taken from inside the Capitol at the time of the riot. Baouche's employer provided his internet search history which included topics such as the inauguration, the U.S. Capitol building layout, guns, rifle scopes, lasers, Trump protests, FBI Capitol, and searches for jobs in the western U.S. (Statement of Facts). The case is still pending.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Mark Andrew Mazza
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(1) Unlawful Possession of a Firearm on Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 22 DC Code 4504(a) Carrying a Pistol Without a License Outside Home or Place of Business;7 DC Code 2502.01 Possession of Unregistered Firearm; 7 DC Code 2506.01(a)(3) Possession of Unregistered Ammunition; 22 DC Code 3211, 3212(b) Second Degree Theft;
Additional details: Resident of Indiana; Has federal and DC/city charges; "Sentenced 10/21/22 to 60 months in prison, three years of supervised release, $2,150 in restitution."
Short narrative: Mark Mazza, resident of Indiana man, was arrested for carrying a loaded gun onto U.S. Capitol grounds and assaulting law enforcement officers during the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.Mazza actively swung a baton at police and participated in "heave-ho" efforts to apply significant physical force and pressure on the officers.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Jeffrey William Hubbard
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of OR
Short narrative: Federal law enforcement identified Jeffrey Hubbard among the rioters inside the U.S. Capitol building, in part, through what court documents describe as his "distinct bald head." At one point, prosecutors say, footage shows Hubbard chanting "break it down" inside the Capitol. Local law enforcement allegedly spoke to Hubbard's mother around the time of the riot, and court documents state that she told officers that Hubbard was in Washington, D.C., for the pro-Trump rally. Subsequent searches of cellphone records allegedly corroborate the video footage and other evidence suggesting Hubbard breached the Capitol. Hubbard was arrested Dec. 8, 2021. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. James Robert Elliot
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a deadly or dangerous weapon; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(a) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(a) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or building
Additional details: Resident of IL.
Short narrative: James Elliot has been arrested and charged for his role in the Capitol protests. Elliott is charged with civil disorder; assault of a federal officer; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; disorderly conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; and carrying out an act of violence in the Capitol building or grounds.
Source description: Charging documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Jonas Buxton
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Phone found to contain Three Percenter material; Resident of MO; Buxton Sentenced 12/2/22 to 18 months of probation, including 40 hours of community service, $500 fine, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: Jonus Buxton, 26 of St. Charles, Missouri, pled guilty for Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. The defendant wore tactical gear with a "Trump" patch in the center. After defendants began getting indicted, he quit his job and went into hiding. He was sentenced to 18 months of probation, including 40 hours of community service, $500 fine, $500 restitution.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Michael Oliveras
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of NJ; Indicted by a Bill of Information
Short narrative: Two days after the U.S. Capitol riot, at least three people contacted the FBI to alert them to a concerning Parler user operating under the account @Craftmetal. One wrote: "This individual has been talking about overthrowing the government for weeks in public chat rooms pushing disinformation and talking about hanging and executing people repetitively ... He claims to have been in the Capitol Building on the 6th of January and has posted multiple disturbing videos which would seem to substantiate this statement." The tipster including a screenshot of the Parler account, which appeared to show Michael Oliveras' name and phone number, which the FBI then verified and located as having been near the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, court records indicate. The FBI then reviewed Oliveras' Parler account, where they allegedly found video taken inside and around the Capitol on the day of the riot. In one video, Oliveras allegedly shows a pile of news media equipment strewn on the ground outside and says "“That’s what happens when the f***ing fake news shows up at a Patriot rally." In another video showing a mob of people inside the building, Oliveras allegedly says: “Where are the f***ing traitors? Drag them out by the f***ing hair!" (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Johnson & Johnson
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder [felony]; *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; 1*8:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Son also charged; Resident of IA; Indicted by a Bill of Information; https://www.facebook.com/daryl.johnson.39904181/about_life_events; Sentenced 6/1/22 to 30 days in jail, one year of supervised release, $2,000 fine, $2,000 restitution
Short narrative: Daryl Johnson, father of Daniel Johnson, from Saint Ansgar, Iowa has been arrested and charged with several crimes in connection to the Capitol raid. He was inside the Capitol building during the protests with his son, who posted on Facebook claiming: "I was one of the first ones inside the capitol building.".
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Matthew Jay Webler
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of GA; Wore QAnon flag; Indicted by Bill of Information; Sentenced 5/3/22 to 45 days in prison (time served) and $500 in restitution.
Short narrative: Matthew Jay Webler posted multiple videos to Facebook in which he showed footage from inside the U.S. Capitol during the riot on Jan. 6, 2021, and also discussed breaching the building himself, federal prosecutors allege. In one video taken from inside the building, Webler allegedly shouted "1776!" Surveillance footage cited by prosecutors allegedly shows Webler entering the Capitol through a broken window, while wearing a large flag with the letter "Q" on it -- a popular piece of imagery with the the pro-Trump conspiracy theory known as QAnon. Webler also posted to Facebook that he believed the crowd inside the Capitol was peaceful and that he was "proud of myself for not getting caught up to [sic] much and having the sense to stand up to someone trying to vandalize the place," according to court documents. Webler was arrested on Dec. 3, 2021, in Decatur, Ga. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Johnson & Johnson
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder [felony]; *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; 1*8:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Father also charged; Resident of IA; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Sentenced 6/1/22 to 4 months in jail, one year of supervised release, $2,000 restitution.
Short narrative: Daniel Johnson, 29, has been arrested and charged for his role in the Capitol protests. He published several social media posts stating that he was at the Capitol on January 6 and he can be seen in numerous surveillance photos included in the affidavit.The affidavit against Johnson also states that the FBI received a tip from a witness that included a Facebook comment written by Johnson that said, "I was one of the first ones inside the capitol building."
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Thomas Paul Conover
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of TX; Sentenced 4/22/22 to 36 months’ probation, including 30 days at a residential reentry center, 60 hours of community service, $2,500 fine, $500 restitution
Short narrative: Thomas Paul Conover spent much of the day on Jan. 6, 2021, carrying a can of Coors Light beer, which he brought with him as he breached the U.S. Capitol building, federal prosecutors allege. During that time, court documents state, Conover also filmed videos of himself, including one in which he said, "I don't always storm the Capitol of the United States of America. But when I do, I prefer Coors Light." Prosecutors allege that Conover posted on Facebook about his activity on Jan. 6, stating, "GREETINGS FROM WASHINGTON DC" and "WE TOOK THE CAPITAL [sic]." Surveillance and police bodycam footage also allegedly shows Conover inside the building during the riot. Later, court documents state, the FBI received a tip from someone who saw Conover's Facebook posts and turned over screenshots to law enforcement. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Burress & Pettit
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of OH; Partner also arrested; Indicted by a Bill of Information
Short narrative: "A little after 3 p.m. on Jan. 6, Gabriel Burress was allegedly captured on security camera footage from inside the U.S. Capitol. Court documents indicate that Burress is seen in the footage with his girlfriend, Madison Pettit, who is also charged in the riot. While the pair are walking inside the Capitol, Burress can be seen walking behind Pettit with his hands around her hips, court documents indicate. In an interview with the FBI, Burress said he followed the crowd to the Capitol and pushed inside the building." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Burress & Pettit
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of OH; Partner also arrested; Indicted by a Bill of Information
Short narrative: "Sometime in January, the FBI received a tip that Madison Pettit had been inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, along with her boyfriend, Gabriel Burress, who is also charged in the insurrection. According to court documents, the FBI traced Pettit's cellphone to an area that included the inside of the Capitol that day, and the bureau was also able to locate Pettit and Burress in security camera footage, where they are seen walking closely together. Pettit allegedly admitted to entering the building and said that once inside, she had felt pepper spray in her lungs." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Emily Hernandez
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly Conduct which impedes the conduct of government business; *18:641 Steal, sell, convey or dispose of any thing of value of the United States; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disruptive conduct in the Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in the Capitol Building;
Additional details: Indicted by a Bill of Information; must remain in the eastern district of Missouri, which includes her home in Sullivan, for the immediate future. She is also forbidden from traveling to D.C., except ; Sentenced 4/11/22 to 30 days in jail, and one year of supervised release, including 80 hours of community service, and $500 in restitution.for her future court date.
Short narrative: Emily Hernandez, 21, of Sullivan, Missouri, woman seen inside the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6 has been arrested after she turned herself into the local FBI agents.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. William Merry
Charges: 18:641 Theft of Government Property; *18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly Conduct Which Impedes the Conduct of Government Business; *40:5104(e)(2) Disruptive Conduct in the Capitol Buildings
Additional details: Indicted by a Bill of Information; Sentenced 4/11/22 to 45 days in jail, nine months of supervised release, including 80 hours community service, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: "Merry is the uncle of Emily Hernandez, who was arrested in January, on charges related to the Capitol riot, according to the FBI, which received the information from tipsters. In a video inside the Capitol, the FBI reported Merry, with a red Trump cap and a red bandanna around his neck, can be seen holding a piece of the wooden sign that had previously been above a doorway to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's office. Hernandez also is seen in photos from that day holding a piece of the sign. (USA Today)"
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Dan Shaw
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of CA; Indicted by a Bill of Information
Short narrative: Daniel Shaw was identified by law enforcement as having been involved in the Jan. 6, 2021, U.S. Capitol riot when another person charged, Kenneth Reda, allegedly mentioned that he had stayed in Shaw's hotel room while in Washington, D.C., and identified Shaw in security camera footage from inside the building. Law enforcement also obtained a search warrant from Verizon and allegedly confirmed that Shaw's cellphone pinged on a cell site that serves the area inside the Capitol on the day of the riot. According to court records, security camera footage from inside the building also appear to show Shaw's son, whose name has been redacted, with him. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Thomas Uberto
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of NY; MAGA hat; Indicted by a Bill of Information
Short narrative: Thomas Uberto, wearing what appeared to be a “Stop the Steal" T-shirt, can be seen on surveillance footage entering the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, through the Senate wing door, court records indicate. The FBI was also allegedly able to verify through a search warrant served on Google that an account associated with Uberto was present inside the building that day. According to the FBI, Uberto can be seen walking through the Capitol's Small House Rotunda and the Hall of Columns before exiting the building in under 10 minutes. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Avery Carter MacCracken
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of CO; Utilized data from Sedition Hunters
Short narrative: Federal prosecutors allege that Avery MacCracken assaulted police officers guarding the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. MacCracken allegedly punched one officer "with his closed fist in the right cheek, causing a cut to the face under his right eye" and pushed and shoved another officer. Both incidents were allegedly captured by police body cameras. Court documents state that MacCracken is "considered a transient with no permanent place of residence" but is generally known in the Telluride, Colo., area. A tipster from Colorado recognized MacCracken in photos of the Capitol siege circulated by the online open-source investigative community known as the Sedition Hunters, prosecutors now allege. That tipster then contacted local law enforcement -- namely, San Miguel County Sheriff Bill Masters -- who reportedly recognized MacCracken as well as the outfit he wore on Jan. 6, 2021, court documents state. MacCracken was arrested on Dec. 11, 2021. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental reports and releases (DOJ)

Other names/aliases: James T. Justis (stage name); James Delisco Beeks (stage name as Michael Jackson impersonator); jdmoonwalker (YouTube)
Name of case: United States of America v. Caldwell, et al.
Charges: 18:1512(k) Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:372 Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; 18:1361 2, Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:231(a)(3) 2, Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting;
Additional details: Resident of FL; Identified through comparison of defendant's ear
Short narrative: James Beeks was allegedly part of a group of Oath Keepers members and affiliates that marched on the U.S Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. Prosecutors say that he was already on the radar of law enforcement after a rioter who pleaded guilty identified him as one of the people who lined up with the Oath Keepers the day of the riot. The criminal complaint alleges that he was part of the group that entered into a formation — called a “stack” — in order to force its way into the Capitol. Court documents enumerate many records obtained that show Beeks traveled to Washington, D.C., on the day of the riot, including records from a personal finance app and a rental car agency, as well as cellphone records. Beeks was not wearing the typical camouflage favored by the far-right extremist group, according to court documents, but instead appears in images from that day in a black jacket with the word “Bad” on it in red letters, from Michael Jackson's 1987 world tour. It is that jacket that helped lead law enforcement to him; agents found photographs on Instagram of a person who appears to be Beeks wearing the jacket while posing in front of a sign for the musical play Jesus Christ Superstar. Beeks is an actor who performs as Judas — under the stage name James T. Justis — in the traveling production of the play, and the criminal complaint notes he was observed performing the role in both San Francisco and Los Angeles. In addition, he has also performed as a Michael Jackson impersonator. Prosecutors claim that Beeks changed his phone and phone number the day after an indictment naming co-conspirators was filed and registered his new phone under his stage name. After Beeks was charged, he appeared in court and claimed that the U.S. government had no authority over him — which a U.S. District judge called “gobbledygook.” The production of Jesus Christ Superstar has since replaced him in the role of Judas. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Rhodes et. al.
Charges: 18:2384 Seditious Conspiracy; 18:1512(K) Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:372 Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; 18:1512(c)(1) Tampering with Documents or Proceedings;
Additional details: Navy veteran; "retired from the armed forces Caldwell served as an FBI section chief from 2009-2010 and has held a top-secret security clearance since 1979. The court filing also indicates Caldwell formed and operated a consulting firm that has done business for the Drug Enforcement Administration, the Department of Housing and Urban Development, the Coast Guard and the Army Personnel Command. ." (NPR); "Thomas Caldwell: Found guilty by jury on 11/29/22 of obstruction of an official proceeding, and tampering with documents or proceedings."
Short narrative: Thomas Caldwell, Donovan Crowl and Jessica Watkins are accused of coordinating the Oath Keepers militia in a criminal conspiracy. Thomas Caldwell, 65, a leader of the Oath Keepers, is accused of helping to organize at least eight rioters wearing military-stye gear who attacked the Capitol building on 1/6/21. He was arrested 1/19/21 in Virginia. He is charged with conspiracy amongst other crimes. The Complaint alleges that the individuals Caldwell coordinated moved "in an organized and practices fashion and force[d] their way to the ground of the crowd gathered around a door to the U.S. Capitol."
Source description: Charging Documents, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Rhodes et. al.
Charges: 18:2384 Seditious Conspiracy; 18:1512(K) Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:372 Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; 18:1361 2, Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1512(c)(1) Tampering with Documents or Proceedings;
Additional details: Resident of FL; Added to Oath Keepers case late in August 2021
Short narrative: "On Jan. 6, David Moerschel and nine other members of the far-right extremist group the Oath Keepers moved in a tactical military formation used by infantryman up the stairs to the U.S. Capitol, according to court documents. Footage reportedly shows Moerschel wearing a long-sleeved black jacket and backward green baseball cap with Oath Keepers insignia. The group has been known to target and recruit active-duty members of the military and veterans, in part for their specialized skills. According to the FBI, the Oath Keepers believe a cabal of elites has co-opted the federal government by actively trying to strip Americans of their rights. Credit card transactions and intercepted messaging platforms reportedly show group members coordinated their actions ahead of the Jan. 6 rally, allegedly bringing weapons with them. According to court documents, they stored firearms at a northern Virginia hotel they referred to as “QRF,” or Quick Reaction Force. The FBI says the government obtained surveillance video from the Comfort Inn Ballston on Jan. 7, showing three individuals wheeling a concierge cart with at least one long gun case onto an elevator. Moerschel reportedly appears to be one of the individuals. The government was able to gain access to a Signal group messaging account used by members of the Oath Keepers, including Moerschel, who wrote under the name "Hatsy." A search warrant executed on the number used by that user connected the FBI to Moerschel, court documents say." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Rhodes et. al.
Charges: 18:2384 Seditious Conspiracy; 18:1512(K) Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:372 Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; 18:1512(c)(1) Tampering with Documents or Proceedings;
Additional details: Resident of GA; Added to Oath Keepers case late in August 2021
Short narrative: "Federal prosecutors allege that Brian Ulrich conspired with members of the extremist anti-government militia group known as the Oath Keepers to disrupt Congress on Jan. 6. Ulrich has been indicted along with several members of the group. According to the indictment, Ulrich goes by the moniker "Molon Labe" and allegedly participated in conversations on the encrypted messaging service Signal in a group message labeled "DC OP: Jan 6 21." On Dec. 31, Ulrich reportedly wrote the following message on the chat: "The more patriots the merrier 'gonna be wild." Later he allegedly wrote, "Someone can tell me if I'm crazy but I'm planning on having a backpack for regular use and then a separate backpack with my ammo load out with some basics that I can [just] switch too is [sic] s**t truly the fan blades. ..." According to court documents, Ulrich also asked another member on Signal: "Hey we told to bring guns and maybe stage them in VA ...?" On Jan. 4. Ulrich traveled with others to Washington, D.C., from Alabama and Georgia, and stayed at the Mayflower Hotel, court documents say. On the day of the riot, he headed for the U.S. Capitol in a golf cart along with others named in the indictment. He continued on foot and ultimately pushed his way inside through the Rotunda doors, and then, according to court documents, left the same way he came in." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Rhodes et. al.
Charges: 18:2384 Seditious Conspiracy; 18:1512(K) Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:372 Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; 18:1512(c)(1) Tampering with Documents or Proceedings;
Additional details: Founder of the Oath Keepers; "Rhodes Found guilty by jury on 11/29/22 of seditious conspiracy, obstruction of an official proceeding, and tampering with documents and proceedings."
Short narrative: Shortly after the election in November 2020, prosecutors say, Rhodes and others began planning travel to Washingto D.C. and training for action there. As the crowd gathered outside the U.S. Capitol on 1/6/2021, about 2 p.m., federal prosecutors say Rhodes entered the restricted area of the Capitol grounds and directed his followers to meet him at the Capitol. Court records say two groups of Oath Keepers, many in paramilitary clothing bearing Oath Keepers patches and insignia, then formed military-style "stack" formations and invaded the Capitol.
Source description: Charging documents, court documents, local news articles, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Rhodes et. al.
Charges: 18:2384 Seditious Conspiracy; 18:1512(K) Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:372 Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties;
Additional details: Vallejo was one of the leaders of the Oath Keepers' "quick reaction force" in Washington D.C. on Jan. 6
Short narrative: Arizona Oath Keeper, Edward Vallejo is accused of coordinating an armed backup team outside of D.C. on January 6, 2021. Vallejo was one of two Oath Keepers tasked with preparing the militia’s “quick reaction force,” which was staged with weapons, ammunition and equipment at the Ballston Comfort Inn just across the river from D.C.
Source description: Charging Documents; Local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Rhodes et. al.
Charges: 18:2384 Seditious Conspiracy; 18:1512(K) Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:372 Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; 18:1361 2, Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1512(c)(1) Tampering with Documents or Proceedings;
Additional details: Leader of FL Oath Keepers; "Kelly Meggs Found guilty by jury on 11/29/22 of seditious conspiracy, conspiracy to obstruct an official proceeding, obstruction of an official proceeding, conspiracy to prevent an officer from discharging duties, and tampering with documents or proceedings.."
Short narrative: Kelly and Connie are married. "According to the superseding indictment, Kelly Meggs is the self-described leader of the Florida chapter of the Oath Keepers, of which Connie Meggs, Young, and Steele also are alleged to be members." "CALDWELL, CROWL, WATKINS, SANDRA PARKER, BENNIE PARKER, YOUNG, STEELE, KELLY MEGGS, and CONNIE MEGGS, planned with each other, and with others known and unknown, to forcibly enter the Capitol on January 6, 2021, and to stop, delay, and hinder the Congressional proceeding occurring that day.
Source description: Charging documents, court documents, local news articles, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Rhodes et. al.
Charges: 18:2384 Seditious Conspiracy; 18:1512(K) Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:372 Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; 18:1361 2, Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1512(c)(1) Tampering with Documents or Proceedings;
Additional details: Resident of FL; "Kenneth Harrelson Found guilty by jury on 11/29/22 of obstruction of an official proceeding, conspiracy to prevent an officer from discharging duties, and tampering with documents or proceedings."
Short narrative: Kenneth Harrelson has been identified as an Army veteran and a member of the far-right militiant Oath Keepers organization. He is out on $25,000 bond and faces charges of entering and remaining in a restricted building and violent and disorderly conduct. "The affidavit says an individual using a mobile device with the same IP address as Harrelson's phone organized a meeting titled "dc planning call" on Jan. 3, 2021. In addition to that, the same user organized some 30 meetings affiliated with the Oath Keepers between Sept. 30, 2020, and Jan. 3, 2021." He was indicted alone first, but he has now been added to the second superseding indictment including 9 other members of the oathkeepers.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Articles, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Rhodes et. al.
Charges: 18:2384 Seditious Conspiracy; 18:1512(K) Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:372 Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; 18:231(a)(3) 2, Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1512(c)(1) 2, Tampering with Documents or Proceedings and Aiding and Abetting;
Additional details: Resident of Arab, AL
Short narrative: (service in Iraq) Joshua James, 33, was arrested in his home state of Alabama. He has provided security to longtime Donald Trump adviser, Roger Stone, and is a member of the Oath Keepers militia.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News articles, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Rhodes et. al.
Charges: 18:2384 Seditious Conspiracy; 18:1512(K) Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:372 Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; 18:1512(c)(1) Tampering with Documents or Proceedings;
Additional details: Resident of NJ; helped provide security for Roger Stone on 1/6, and had provided it in the past for Michael Flynn and Alex Jones; bail set at $150,000 and must surrender all firearms; Arrested March 10
Short narrative: "Roberto Minuta is the owner of a tattoo shop in New York called Casa di Dolore. Federal prosecutors say that when Minuta refused to comply with public health orders to close his shop during the COVID-19 pandemic, he was named a "lifetime" member of the anti-government extremist group known as the Oath Keepers. The court documents cite an interview with Minuta about his shop by Stewart Rhodes, the founder of the Oath Keepers. Multiple media outlets, including The New York Times, reported that Minuta was among a group of Oath Keepers who provided protection for Roger Stone, the former adviser to former President Donald Trump, in the hours leading up to the insurrection. The New York Times' report is now cited in the Justice Department's case against Minuta. Minuta allegedly appeared alongside other members of the militia in Washington, wearing tactical gear, including "ballistic goggles," and may have also carried bear spray. Minuta "aggressively taunted and berated law enforcement officers guarding the Capitol," the government alleges, before eventually breaching the Capitol himself. About a week after the Capitol riot, Minuta deleted his Facebook account." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Rhodes et. al.
Charges: 18:2384 Seditious Conspiracy; 18:1512(K) Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:372 Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; 18:1361 2, Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting;
Additional details: Resident of FL
Short narrative: Joseph Hackett, 51, Jason Dolan, 44, William Isaacs, 21, and Jonathan Walden, 46, were added to the Oathkeepers 4th superseding indictment. Each face multiple counts for their participation in the January 2021 Capitol protests. Specifically, Hackett is accused of conspiracy; obstruction of an official proceeding, and aiding and abetting; destruction of government property, and aiding and abetting; and illegally entering a restricted building or grounds.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Caldwell, et al.
Group affiliation: Oath Keepers; Ohio State Regular Militia
Charges: 18:371 Conspiracy; 18:1512(c)(2),2 Obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; 18:1361, 2 Destruction of government property and aiding and abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds
Additional details: USMC veteran; Arrested 1/18/21 in the Southern District of Ohio
Short narrative: Thomas Caldwell, Donovan Crowl and Jessica Watkins are accused of coordinating the Oath Keepers militia in a criminal conspiracy. Donovan Ray Crowl, 50, of Champaign County has been charged with being part of the 1/6/21 attack on the US Capitol and linked to militia activity. According to court documents, he is a member of the Ohio State Regular Militia, a dues-paying subset of the Oath Keepers...[and was seen] wearing a helmet, reinforced vest and clothing with Oath Keeper paraphernalia on it.
Source description: Charging Documents, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Rhodes et. al.
Group affiliation: Oath Keepers; Ohio State Regular Militia
Charges: 18:2384 Seditious Conspiracy; 18:1512(K) Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:372 Conspiracy to Prevent an Officer from Discharging Any Duties; 18:1361 2, Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; 18:231(a)(3) 2, Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting;
Additional details: Founder and Commanding Officer of Ohio State Regular Militia in 2019, member of Oath Keepers, US Army veteran; defense motion calls her "transgender female"; "Jessica Watkins Found guilty by jury on 11/29/22 of obstruction of an official proceeding, interfering with law enforcement officers during a civil disorder, conspiracy to prevent an officer from discharging duties, and tampering with documents or proceedings."
Short narrative: Thomas Caldwell, Donovan Crowl and Jessica Watkins are accused of coordinating the Oath Keepers militia in a criminal conspiracy. Jessica Marie Watkins, 38, of Champaign County has been charged with being part of the 1/6/21 attack on the US Capitol and linked to militia activity. According to court documents, she is a member of the Ohio State Regular Militia, a dues-paying subset of the Oath Keepers. Watkins’ profile on the app Parler also alleges that she is a Commanding Officer of the Ohio State Regular Militia. Authorities said Watkins posted a video to her Parler account with the message: “Yeah. We stormed the Capitol today. Tear Gassed, the whole, 9. Pushed our way into the Rotunda. Made it into the Senate even. The news is lying (even Fox) about the Historical Events we created today.”...[Watkins was seen] wearing a helmet, reinforced vest and clothing with Oath Keeper paraphernalia on it.
Source description: Charging Documents, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. James Wayne Brooks
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of TN; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Carried USMC flag and OP Iraqi Freedom veteran hat, he completed 2 combat tours in Iraq; "Sentenced 11/3/22 to 12 months of probation, 60 hours community service, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Court papers say James Wayne Brooks was in and around the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021 with “a communications radio attached to the left side of his military-style vest.” The defendant’s sister told the FBI that her older brother (not the defendant) indicated to her that the Brooks was at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. The sister said images taken from the Capitol complex on Jan. 6 appeared to show her brother James.
Source description: Charging Documents, News article

Name of case: United States of America v. Andrew Galloway
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of WY; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced 10/12/22 to 30 days of incarceration."
Short narrative: “Yeah, that was us today; no that wasn’t Antifa,” Andrew James Galloway allegedly said on a TikTok video that was submitted to the FBI as a tip concerning his alleged participation in the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol. The FBI later confirmed using cellphone records and footage take inside the building that Galloway entered the Capitol through a breached window and after about 10 minutes exited through another breached window, court documents indicate. According to court documents, the FBI interviewed Galloway at his home in Wyoming, where he allegedly confirmed the TikTok video but denied having entered the building. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Bustos & Bustos
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parade, Demonstrate, or Picket in any of the Capitol Buildings
Additional details: Resident of Long Beach, CA; Brother also arrested; Indicted by a Bill of Information
Short narrative: Alexis Ivan Bustos-Ocampo and his brother Bryan Emmanuel Bustos, both of CA, were charged with Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; Parade, Demonstrate, or Picket in any of the Capitol Buildings following their participation in the Capitol riot. The Bustos brothers were identified via numerous photos and a video Bryan posted to his Instagram account which depict both himself and Alexis illegally inside the Capitol building.

Name of case: United States of America v. Bustos & Bustos

Name of case: United States of America v. Samsel, et. al.
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) 2, Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; 18:111(a)(1) and (b), 2 Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers [2 counts]; 18:1752(a)(1) and (a)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds resulting in significant bodily injury; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4), (b)(1)(A), (b)(1)(B), 2 Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Causing Significant Bodily Injury; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F), 2 Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers;
Short narrative: Ryan Stephen Samsel, 37, of Bristol, Pennsylvania, was charged for his role in the Jan. 6th Capitol rios after helping dismantle barricades at the Capitol building and knocking over a U.S. Capitol Police Officer, who then suffered a concussion. Samsel was charged with one count of forcible assault/opposition or interference with a federal agent engaged in official duties, one count of committing or attempt to commit any act to obstruct, impede, or interfere with any firearm or law enforcement officer engaged in official duty, and one count of obstruction/impeding or attempt to, an official proceeding.
Source description: Court Documents, Local News Articles, Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Samsel, et. al.
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) 2, Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; 18:111(a)(1) and (b), 2 Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers [2 counts]; 18:1752(a)(1) and (a)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds resulting in significant bodily injury; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4), (b)(1)(A), (b)(1)(B), 2 Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Causing Significant Bodily Injury; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F), 2 Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 40:5104(e)(2)(C) Disruption of Official Business; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of NC
Short narrative: James Tate Grant was charged with Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon or inflicting bodily injury; Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an official proceeding; Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings; Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building following his participation in the Capitol riot. Grant was identified via an Instagram video, a YouTube video, and Capitol surveillance footage that shows Grant pushing past a barricade clearly labeled 'DO NOT ENTER' and illegally entering the Capitol.

Name of case: United States of America v. Samsel, et. al.
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) 2, Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; 18:111(a)(1) and (b), 2 Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers [2 counts]; 18:1752(a)(1) and (a)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds resulting in significant bodily injury; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4), (b)(1)(A), (b)(1)(B), 2 Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Causing Significant Bodily Injury; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F), 2 Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting;
Additional details: Resident of VA
Short narrative: "Paul Russell Johnson, 35, of Lanexa, Virginia, [was charged with] inflicting bodily injury on certain officers, among other charges. Johnson was arrested pursuant to a complaint in the District of Columbia and made his initial appearance in court on April 14. The complaint charges Johnson with inflicting bodily injury on certain officers; obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder; obstruction of justice and Congress; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; and acts of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings. According to court documents, Johnson was at the Capitol on Jan. 6 where he was captured on video assaulting a U.S. Capitol Police (USCP) officer and engaging in disorderly conduct. As depicted in open-source video footage reviewed by the FBI, Johnson was part of a crowd of people seen walking over and around the first line of barricades just off the roadway of Peace Circle. As the crowd approached a second line of barricades, guarded by uniformed USCP officers, Johnson can be seen on video holding a megaphone and shouting profanities toward the police, including, “Let’s go! F*** this s***! We pay your bills, you back the f*** off.” As alleged, Johnson became confrontational with USCP officers as he approached the second line of barricades. He can be seen forcibly pushing and pulling on the metal barricades which caused a USCP officer to fall and hit her head on the stairs before losing consciousness. Hours later, the officer blacked out and collapsed while arresting a rioter and had to be transported to the emergency room where she was assessed to have suffered a concussion. After dismantling and knocking over the line of metal barricades, Johnson can be seen running up the steps and further onto restricted grounds. Later in the evening of Jan. 6, a YouTube user posted a video in which Johnson recounted the events that took place outside the Capitol earlier that day. Throughout the video, Johnson described how he personally broke through the barricades, stating, “There’s three sets of gates before you get to the stairs of the Capitol. Alright? We get to the next gate. There’s probably . . . there’s a s*** load of cops up there then. Second wing, we breached, pulled up, start throwing s***. I mean we’re fu-, we’re fighting cops and s***. I have video where I’m slinging one around . . .”" (DOJ Press release)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Samsel, et. al.
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) 2, Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; 18:111(a)(1) and (b), 2 Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers [2 counts]; 18:1752(a)(1) and (a)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds resulting in significant bodily injury; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4), (b)(1)(A), (b)(1)(B), 2 Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Causing Significant Bodily Injury; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F), 2 Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting;

Named in a superseding indictment along with five others, Blythe is accused of participating in the attacks against two Capitol police officers, in which a metal crowd control barrier was used against the officers. One of the officers was injured in the attack. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Robert Gieswein
Group affiliation: Three Percenters (III Percenters, 3%ers); Woodland Wild Dogs
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:231(a)(3), 2 Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon [3 counts]; 18:1361, 2 Destruction of Government Property; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon
Additional details: appears to have ties to the Proud Boys/Three Percenters/Oath Keepers; from Woodland, Colorado
Short narrative: Robert Gieswein, 24, of Woodland Park, CO was charged with Obstruction of an official proceeding; Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers using a dangerous easpon [3 counts]; Destruction of Government property; and Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon following his participation in the Capitol riot. Gieswein was identified via footage taken at the riot and can be clearly seen illegally entering the US capitol in paramilitary gear carrying a baseball bat and weilding an unidentified spray bottle which he used to spray at Capitol police officers. Gieswein appears to be affiliated with the domestic group the Three Percenters which is related to the Oath Keepers. Additionally, Gieswein runs a private paramilitary group in Colorado called the Woodland Wild Dogs. In an interview, Gieswein offers up anti-semitic conspiracy theories as part of his reasoning for his actions.
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, News article

Name of case: United States of America v. Purdy, Purdy, and Turner
Charges: 18:231(a)(3), 2 - Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1), 2 - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Father and uncle also arrested
Short narrative: Federal prosecutors allege that Gregory Purdy took part in the U.S. Capitol riot along with his father, Gregory Purdy-Schwartz, who does not appear to have been charged; a man identified as his brother, Matthew Purdy; and another a man identified as his uncle, Robert Turner. Gregory Purdy allegedly documented many of his actions that day on Instagram. Purdy allegedly recorded a video from the chaos outside the Capitol, in which he said, "Right now, we're on the top of the Capitol. Everybody stormed through. We're the second wave coming in." Gregory Purdy can allegedly be heard on police body camera footage telling officers, "Are you guys going to let us in, or are we gonna have to push in?" He later pushed through a police line outside the building before being restrained by officers, charging documents state. In another post, he allegedly stated, "Peep my war cry at the end as we push through this riot team." Purdy then breached the Capitol building and continued to record videos and post them to social media, court documents state. In one social media post, Purdy allegedly added a caption about how he "got out of it with NO CHARGES and nothing on my record" along with an emoji of applying nail polish. Purdy also allegedly recorded videos after the riot, in which he described how "I bumrushed" police officers and said, "It's our job to uphold the constitution and do a f***ing rebellion." Gregory Purdy surrendered to the FBI on Nov. 10, 2021. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental press and release (DOJ)

Name of case: United States of America v. Purdy, Purdy, and Turner
Charges: 18:231(a)(3), 2 - Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1), 2 - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Brother also arrested
Short narrative: Federal prosecutors allege that Matthew Purdy took part in the U.S. Capitol riot along with his father, Gregory Purdy-Schwartz, who does not appear to have been charged; a man identified as his brother, Gregory Purdy; and another a man identified as his uncle, Robert Turner. Police body camera footage allegedly shows Matthew Purdy with a crowd of people pushing against police officers guarding the outside of the Capitol building. Gregory Purdy also allegedly documented their actions that day on his phone and uploaded more than a dozen videos to Instagram. Prosecutors allege that Matthew Purdy could be seen in footage breaching the inside of the Capitol building. Matthew Purdy surrendered to the FBI on Nov. 10, 2021. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental press and release (DOJ)

Name of case: United States of America v. Purdy, Purdy, and Turner
Charges: 18:231(a)(3), 2 - Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1), 2 - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of NT; Nephew also arrested
Short narrative: Federal prosecutors allege that Robert Turner took part in the U.S. Capitol riot along with his nephews, Gregory and Matthew Purdy, as well as their father, Gregory Purdy-Schwartz, who does not appear to have been charged. Gregory Purdy allegedly documented their actions that day on his phone and uploaded more than a dozen videos to Instagram describing or depicting the men pushing against police on guard at the Capitol and actually breaching the building. Police body camera footage also allegedly shows Turner yelling at police. At another point, Turner allegedly told officers, "Stop taking orders. We're not here - we're not here to kill or hurt anybody, we're making our voice heard." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental press and release (DOJ)

Name of case: United States of America v. Tim Levon Boughner
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of Justice/Congress; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(E) Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings;
Additional details: Resident of MI; Evidence used from Sedition Hunters
Short narrative: “I’m on my way to Washington DC. To make sure Biden’s doesn’t become president,” Tim Levon Boughner allegedly posted on social media on Jan. 5, 2021, the day that phone records reportedly indicate he traveled from Michigan to Washington, D.C. For weeks prior, Boughner wrote multiple social media entries questioning the legitimacy of the presidential election and calling Joe Biden “stupid,” according to court records. Boughner first came to the attention of the FBI in the spring of 2021 when FBI agents reviewed police body-worn camera footage that allegedly shows Boughner assaulting an officer with a chemical spray. Subsequently, the FBI issued a BOLO alert for the then-unidentified Boughner. In addition, the volunteer group Sedition Hunters assigned a moniker to the person who federal prosecutors say is Boughner: “#blackpufferwhitescarf." According to the FBI, Boughner was identified by a tattoo of a five-point star below a dragon on the inside of his left wrist. At the end of July 2021, a search warrant was issued to a Facebook account that matched Boughner. The subscriber data provided by Facebook allegedly confirmed he was indeed at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. On the day of the riot, he allegedly posted: “I grabbed a can from them and started spraying. I got it on video lol …That was wild. We made it to the senate floor till National guard started fight back.” (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental reports and release (DOJ)

Name of case: United States of America v. Robertson & Fracker
Charges: 18:1512(c), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:231(a)(3) 2, Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of VA; USMC rifleman 2010-2014 and deployed to Afghanistan twice; joined VA National Guard (infantryman, 116th Infantry Brigade Combat Team, 29th Infantry Division); worked as a VA police officer in Rocky Mount, Va.' but was fired after arrest; After March 2022 guilty plea Fracker was "removed from the service component" of his National Guardman role., "Sentenced 8/16/22 to 12 months of probation, the first 59 days on home detention, 120 hours of community service, $2,000 restitution."
Veteran status: Former active duty and current reserve components
Short narrative: On January 29, 2021, in Washington D.C., Jacob Fracker, age 29; and Thomas Robertson, age 47; both of Rocky Mountain, Virginia, were charged with obstruction of an official proceeding, aiding and abetting, entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, and violent entry and disorderly conduct in a capitol building. The two men, both members of the Rocky Mountain police department, entered the Capitol Building during the January 6 riot. Their actions were motivated by their rightist: anti-government beliefs.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental reports and release, Local news articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Robertson & Fracker
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction and Aiding and Abetting; 18:231(a)(3) 2, Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 18:1512(c)(1) Tampering with Document or Proceedings
Additional details: 2nd jury trial of Capitol cases; Resident of VA; Off duty Rocky Mountain VA police officer who was fired after arrest; US Army Reserve police officer; also served as a corporal in VA National Guard 2006-2009; free on a $15,000 unsecured release bond and are barred from either going to Washington or taking part in any demonstration or protest as their criminal case continues.; "Sentenced 8/11/22 to 87 months in prison, 36 months supervised release, restitution of $2,000."
Short narrative: On January 29, 2021, in Washington D.C., Jacob Fracker, age 29; and Thomas Robertson, age 47; both of Rocky Mountain, Virginia, were charged with obstruction of an official proceeding, aiding and abetting, entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, and violent entry and disorderly conduct in a capitol building. The two men, both members of the Rocky Mountain police department, entered the Capitol Building during the January 6 riot. Their actions were motivated by their rightist: anti-government beliefs. THomas Robertson was the second Capitol defendant to have a jury trial. After a three-day trial, jurors deliberated a day and a half before convicting Robertson, now 49, on six counts. Found guilty 4/11/22 of a total of six charges, including five felonies: obstruction of an official proceeding, civil disorder, entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds while carrying a dangerous weapon, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building while carrying a dangerous weapon, and tampering with a document or proceedings. Also found guilty of the misdemeanor offense of disorderly conduct in a Capitol building.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental reports and release, Local news articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Niemela & Chiguer
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of MA; Girlfriend also arrested
Short narrative: Stefanie Nicole Chiguer came to the attention of the FBI when a witness identified her as the girlfriend of Kirstyn Niemela, who is also alleged to have entered the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021, and is charged in relation to the riot. The witness identified Chiguer only as “Stefanie” but told the FBI she lived in Dracut, Mass. A driver’s license photo for Chiguer matches Facebook photos from Jan. 6, court documents say. Those photos allegedly show Chiguer wearing a sweatshirt that says “We the People ARE PISSED OFF,” which matched a sweatshirt worn by Niemela. Prosecutors claim Chiguer can also be seen in surveillance photos from inside the Capitol, and data from Verizon is allegedly consistent with Chiguer’s phone being inside the Capitol as well.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Niemela & Chiguer
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of NH. Girlfriend also arrested
Short narrative: Two witnesses told the FBI that Kirstyn Niemela, then 35 from Hudson, NH Niemela claimed to be a member of the Proud Boys and that she had allegedly showed one witness a video of her breaking a window in the U.S. Capitol building on 1/6/21. A second witness, who said they were related to Niemela, as well as an anonymous text tipster, told the FBI that Niemela had also posted to Facebook near the Capitol. Prosecutors allege that other Facebook posts show “a woman believed to be Niemela” dressed in a sweatshirt reading “We the People ARE PISSED OFF,” as well as wearing sunglasses and an American flag cape. The FBI says a woman wearing the same outfit can be seen in surveillance footage from inside the Capitol. Court documents also allege that data from search warrants to Google and Facebook back up the assertion that Niemela entered the U.S. Capitol building.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Nicholas John Lattanzi
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: "Sentenced - 12/9/22 to 14 days incarceration, $500 fine, $500 restitution"
Short narrative: The FBI has been monitoring Nicholas Lattanzi since he reportedly asked his TikTok followers: “Who wants to commit war crimes in Bosnia with me?” in December 2020, according to an FBI affidavit. On the day of the U.S. Capitol riot, an FBI agent spotted photos on Lattanzi’s TikTok account showing him near the U.S. Capitol wearing a paper Burger King crown, cowboy hat and a white flag wrapped around his shoulders as a cape, court documents indicate. Lattanzi originally denied entering the Capitol, according to the affidavit, telling agents he came to Washington, D.C., to “support my President.” Two weeks later, Lattanzi allegedly told agents he did, in fact, go inside the building and provided photos from the incident. The FBI claims he walked through the Capitol for about five minutes. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Tyler John Tew
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of ID; Indicted by a Bill of Information
Short narrative: Shortly after the U.S. Capitol riot, a tipster approached the FBI with the information that Tyler Tew had posted on Facebook that he was at the Capitol during the insurrection, court documents indicate. A search warrant served on Google showed that a mobile device associated with Tew was at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, and surveillance camera footage inside the Capitol shows an individual that the bureau has identified as Tew entering the building through the Senate parliamentarian's door, according to court documents. Shortly after this footage, pepper balls were fired in his direction. Messages from his cellphone, obtained through a search warrant, reportedly showed Tew bragging that he "was inside" the Capitol and got "pepper sprayed in the face for my country." Two days after the riot, Tew allegedly wrote his spouse, "I stormed the capital [sic] building FOR YOU!!!!" In the days following, Tew messaged multiple individuals and seemingly acknowledged that he had been inside the Capitol during the riot, according to a federal filing. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, News article

Name of case: United States of America v. Robert Thomas Snow
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of AK; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced 7/7/22 to 12 months of probation, 60 hours community service, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Robert Snow has been charged for his role in connection with the Capitol 6 protests. Snow is facing four charges, including disorderly conduct, entering a restricted space, and demonstrating inside the Capitol building. He took a plea deal, pleading to the fourth charge in exchange for the other 3 to be dropped. He is the first in Arkansas defendant to plead guilty to charges arising from the protest. Snow faces up to six months in prison, a fine of up to $5,000 and five years' probation. He agreed to pay $500 in restitution. A sentencing date was set for July 7.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Billy Knutson
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of NC who moved to SD in 2021; Indicted by a Bill of Information.; "Sentenced 8/26/22 to six months of incarceration, one year of supervised release, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: On January 24, 2022, Billy Knutson was indicted for his involvement in the US Capitol raid. He was seen on surveillance footage from inside the U.S. Capitol. Verification of social media posts confirmed that Knutson was in the videos, and that he was in the Capitol for several minutes, recording videos and taking photos on a cell phone before he left the building. He pled guilty and was sentenced for Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Blas Santillan
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of GA; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced 9/23/22 to 45 days of incarceration, 36 months of probation, and $500 restitution. "
Short narrative: "A tipster contacted the FBI after hearing from another person that Blas Santillan had allegedly posted videos on his Snapchat account from inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6. That other person confirmed to law enforcement that Santillan had posted up to 15 videos that day, court documents indicate. In one, Santillan reportedly pans around the Capitol Rotunda saying, "Look at this. All this stuff.” In another, he allegedly is seen walking down the street with a chair and a pole strapped to his back and says: “I got a chair, a pole, and a book.” In a cellphone video taken just outside the Capitol doors, Santillan can reportedly be heard shouting at rioters: "It seems like you’re that weak, because I’m the only one that was willing to do something! I’m the only one that was willing to kick that door! Who else is willing to storm in there? ... You are lazy Americans! That is what you are! You are used to sitting on your couch, and watching your Netflix, and listening to your shows, and watching YouTube! You do not know what freedom is. ... Freedom is doing what you want!" Santillan also appears in security camera footage from inside the building, court documents indicate." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental press and release (DOJ)

Name of case: United States of America v. Neefe & Smith
Charges: 18:1512(k) Conspiracy to Obstruct Official Proceeding; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) and 2 Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(3) and (b)(1)(A) Impeding Ingress and Egress in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) and 2 Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(E), 2 Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Shippensburg, PA; "Sentenced 9/23/22 to 41 months in prison, three years of supervised release, $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative: "According to court documents, Neefe and Smith communicated with each other and others on Facebook in the weeks preceding Jan. 6. For example, on Nov. 4, 2020, a day after Election Day, Neefe wrote to Smith, 'Im getting ready to storm D.C.' The two subsequently shared their intentions and plans to travel to Washington on Jan. 6. In one such communication, Neefe wrote, 'We goin? ...Cause hot damn son I really wanna crack some commie skulls.'" (DOJ)
Source description: Charging Documents, Governmental reports and release (DOJ)
