Name of case: United States of America v. Matthew Thomas Krol
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Additional details: Executive officer of Genesee County Volunteer Militia; Resident of MI
Short narrative: On January 26, 2022, government prosecutors filed a formal complaint against Matthew Thomas Krol, 63, for his role in the U.S. Capitol riots on January 6, 2021. Krol, a self-professed leader within the Genesee County Volunteer Militia, was seen numerous times on body-cam, CCTV, and cell phone video violently assaulting police officers with flagpoles, debris, and a stolen baton. Krol was later seen inside the Capitol buildling, mainly in the Rotunda and around the Senate wing. While no formal charges had been filed against him prior to this incident, Krol admitted to law enforcement that he is affiliated with the men accused of plotting to kidnap Michigan Governor Gretchen Whitmer, and that he has previously participated in riots in possession of a firearm. Krol has not yet submitted a plea to the charges, and all further updates related to his case are pending.
Source description: Charging Documents, local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Westbury, James & Westbury
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of MN
Short narrative: Isaac Westbury, 19, his father, Robert Westbury, 62, and Aaron James, 35, have been indicted for their role in the January 6th, 2021 Capitol protests. In addition to charges related to their illegal entry on restricted Capitol grounds, the younger Westbury and James face up to 20 years in prison for using a police shield to attack Capitol police officers. Last month, in an interview with the far-right website Red Voice Media, the older Westbury's wife, Rosemarie, called the arrest of her husband and sons an act of tyranny, and said the family went to the Capitol to exercise their First Amendment rights and support Trump. All three men have pled non-guilty to the charges.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Ariticles

Name of case: United States of America v. Aiden Henry Bilyard
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 18:1361, 2 - Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of NC; Attended USAF basic training but quit; "Bilyard Sentenced 3/17/23 to 40 months in prison, 36 months of supervised release, and $3,500 in restitution."
Short narrative: Aiden Bilyard, 19, has been arrested and charged for his role in the Capitol protests. His charges include civil disorder, assaulting law enforcement, destruction of government property, engaging in physical violence in a restricted building with a dangerous weapon and other offenses.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Government reports and release (DOJ)

Name of case: United States of America v. Kenneth Joseph Owen Thomas
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder; 18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of an Official Preceding; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging physicall violence in restricted building or on restricted grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Engage in physical violence on Capitol grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of Ohio
Short narrative: Kenneth Thomas, 38, was caught on mutiple social media account and law enfrocement body cam videos leading to his arrest for his participation in the January 2021 Capitol protests. He was seen punching and striking the officers with his fist and forearm. He has been charged with assaulting an officer, obstruction of law enforcement, knowingly entering a restricted building, disorderly condyct, and engaging in physical violence on Capitol grounds. He is also accused of having organized a 35-vehicle MAGA caravan. He was released on conditions. He was wearing a "verterans for Trump' hat.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News, Governmental Reports and Release (DOJ)

Name of case: United States of America v. Victoria Charity White
Charges: 18:231(a)(3), 2 Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building or grounds
Additional details: Resident of MN
Short narrative: "On Jan. 7, Victoria White posted on Facebook that a friend had told her to delete posts, court records show. She replied: "I stated I’m not scared i was in the capitol DETAINED and they took my social security # name address they are coming for me. I am not afraid of them or anyone!!" Video footage showed White arguing at one point with rioters who were trying to break glass in a Capitol window, and at another point, she cheered on rioters who were fighting police officers on the lower west terrace, the FBI stated. She was apprehended shortly afterward, placed in zip-tie handcuffs at about 4:11 p.m. and taken through the Capitol to a police vehicle, then to a police station. Court records show she was released later that evening without any charges being filed. She's heard in a recording and seen in a video in the days after the riot discussing her experiences in the building." (USA Today)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Jolene Eicher
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of VA; Indicted by a Bill of Information
Short narrative: Jolene Eicher has been arrested and charged for her connection to the January 6, 2021 Capitol protests.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Dale Jeremiah Shalvey, et. al.
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:661 - Theft in a Federal Enclave; 18:1001(a)(2) - False Statement or Representation to an Agency of the United States; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(A) - Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of NY
Short narrative: Following his participation in the raids at the United States Capitol on 6 January 2021, Dale Shalvey faces 11 charges from his indictment related to the Capitol protests. Arrested on 10 March 2021, Shalvey can be seen in a viral video misunderstanding Cruz’s objection to the electoral certification of Joe Biden’s presidential win.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, News articles

Other names/aliases: Sandra Suzanne Pomeroy, Sandy Pomeroy Weyer
Name of case: United States of America v. Sandra S. Weyer
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Particiapted in attacks on media stationed at Capitol; Wore 'Trump 2020' hoodie; Resident of PA
Short narrative: "“Did u see the woman that got shot,” someone texted Sandra Pomeroy Weyer the day after the siege on the U.S. Capitol. “Hope you guys had nothing to do with the riots they were all hoodlums And traitors,” the person wrote, according to an FBI criminal complaint. “I seen no riots,” Weyer allegedly responded. “I saw Patriots sick of being lied to and the election being stolen from us! I saw no violence from Patriots!” That, according to a criminal complaint filed against Weyer, may not be exactly true. According to court papers, Weyer looked on as a handful of men accosted a New York Times photographer inside the Capitol that day and then stole her camera. Weyer allegedly recorded the assault on a Facebook live feed, and court papers say that on the recording, Weyer can be heard yelling, “Get her out, mace her,” as the photographer tries to get her camera back. In another video recorded from outside the Capitol that day, Weyer is allegedly shown joining the crowd chanting “let us in” and “break that door.” (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Seymour & Seymour
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of Hamilton, OH; Father also arrested; Charged via Information sheet; Sentenced 11/4/22 to 12 months of probation, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: On February 3, 2022, Paul Lee Seymour, Jr., 33, and his father Paul Lee Seymour, Sr. of OH, were charged via complaint with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following their participation in the Capitol riot. The Seymours were identified via several anonymous tips provided to the FBI as well as numerous photos and video taken by Capitol police which depict both the Seymours illegally inside the Capitol building. He pled guilty to the parading charge and was sentenced 11/4/22 to 12 months of probation, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, News article, Local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Seymour & Seymour

The Seymours were identified via several anonymous tips provided to the FBI as well as numerous photos and video taken by Capitol police which depict both the Seymours illegally inside the Capitol building. He pled guilty to the parading charge and sentenced 11/4/22 to 12 months of probation, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, News article, Local news article

Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of CA; released on $10,000 bond
Short narrative: Kenneth Scott Armstrong III was arrested and charged by the U.S. Attorney's Office in Washington with entering a restricted building, disorderly and disruptive conduct, and parading or demonstrating in the Capitol. Armstrong is the owner of Ouroboros Farms in Half Moon Bay, a company specializing in "aquaponics," in which fish waste is used to grow plants in water.

Name of case: United States of America v. Joshua Lee Hernandez
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(B) Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

Name of case: United States of America v. Johnson, et al.
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) 2, Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; 18:111(a)(1) and (b), 2 Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A), 2 Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) 2, Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) 2, Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;

The indictment is light on details, but it states that Johnson carried pepper spray and sprayed an officer with it. Johnson is also alleged to have carried a sledgehammer
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Kastner, et. al.
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;

Name of case: United States of America v. Peter Schwartz, et. al.
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and aiding and abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of CA; Participated in a J6-themed telegram group called "The California Patriots - DC Brigade"; Wore Infowars tshirt
Short narrative: "Jeffrey Scott Brown was allegedly part of a group chat on the encrypted messaging service Telegram that the FBI obtained in the aftermath of Jan. 6. The chat's "about" section reportedly read: “This group will serve as the Comms for able bodied individuals that are going to DC on Jan 6. Many of us have not met before and we are all ready and willing to fight. We will come together for this moment that we are called upon.” According to court documents, Brown posted a selfie to the group on Jan. 5 with the caption "Boarding LAX," and it was later confirmed he took a flight from Los Angeles that day to Washington, D.C. In security camera footage from a tunnel leading into the U.S. Capitol, Brown can allegedly be seen spraying what the FBI believes to be pepper spray at police officers. In a YouTube video, Brown appears inside the tunnel pushing against officers trying to protect the door to the Capitol's Lower West Terrace, court documents indicate. In the video, one officer has his gas mask ripped off by another person, and blood can be seen in his mouth, according to court documents." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental reports and releases (DOJ)

Name of case: United States of America v. Peter Schwartz, et. al.
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of KY; "Pleaded guilty 8/24/22 to indictment. The charges include five felonies."
Short narrative: Shelly Stallings, 42, of Morganfield, was arrested and charged with offenses "in connection with the violence at the U.S. Capitol" on Jan. 6, 2021, in Washington, D.C. Stallings and Markus Maly, 47, of Fincastle, Virginia, were named as additional defendants in a superseding indictment that previously included Stallings' husband, Peter Schwartz, and a Santa Ana, California man, Jeffrey Brown. All four defendants are accused of spraying a chemical irritant, pepper spray, at a line of police officers attempting to secure the area of the Lower West Terrace of the Capitol Building."
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental reports and releases (DOJ)

Name of case: United States of America v. Peter Schwartz, et. al.

Additional details: A court memo claimed that Maly has an extensive criminal histry and was once a member of a rascist skinhead groups.
Short narrative: Markus Maly, 47, of Fincastle, Virginia, is charged in a criminal complaint with assaulting, resisting, or impeding officers using a dangerous weapon or inflicting bodily injury, civil disorder, engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds, and related offenses.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental reports and releases (DOJ)

Name of case: United States of America v. Peter Schwartz, et. al.
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon [3 counts]; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and aiding and abetting; 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of PA
Short narrative: Peter Schwartz, of Kentucky, was arrested and charged with Forcibly Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers or Employees; Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; and Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds. Schwartz was identified as participating in the Capitol riot via footage taken at the event. Schwartz was seen spraying "an orange substance from a black canister" (affidavit) which is thought to be pepper spray. A tipster also called in to the FBI and reported that Schwartz is a felon who was released from prison due to the pandemic and is supposed to be residing at a rehabilitation facility.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental reports and releases (DOJ)

Name of case: United States of America v. Johnson, et al.
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) 2, Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; 18:111(a)(1) and (b), 2 Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A), 2 Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) 2, Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) 2, Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Aiding and Abetting; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of FL
Short narrative: According to an affidavit and criminal complaint, Alan Fischer III marched to the Capitol on 1/6/2022 with members of the Proud Boys. Once there, he moved to the vicinity of the terrace on the west side of the Capitol, where he joined others in pushing against law enforcement at the arched entrance to a passageway into the building. The group of rioters collectively pushed against officers, at times rocking together in a coordinated way, to gain entry to the interior of the building. He remained in this area for a period of more than 45 minutes. Later, according to the court documents, Fischer moved to the west front of the Capitol. Once there, he threw chairs, an orange traffic cone, and a pole towards officers.
Source description: Charging Documents; Local news articles; News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Adam Avery Honeycutt
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; *18:1752(a) Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority;
Additional details: Indicted by a Bill of Information; Sentenced 5/11/22 to 90 days in jail, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: Adam Honeycutt, 39, is charged with entering a restricted area without lawful authority as well as violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds. His home was raided, and agents found 4 guns as well as marijuana and drug paraphernalia. There were also 3 children in the house.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Nolan B. Cooke
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Acts during civil disorder; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Unlawful activities on Capitol grounds;
Additional details: Indicted by a Bill of Information; Sentenced 6/9/22 to two months of home detention, 36 months of probation, $500 restitution, 60 hours community service
Short narrative: Cooke has been arrested for a series of charges that pertained to his activity at the January 6th, 2021 Capitol protests. Cooke says he came to the Capitol to be heard, and was at the front of the crowd pushing against the officers who were enforcing the restricted access to the Capitol Building and Grounds.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Reva Vincent
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Indicted by a Bill of Information; Resident of KY; "Sentenced 9/21/22 to 24 months of probation, 60 hours of community service, $1,500 fine, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Reva Vincent, 57, was charged by information and ordered to attend an arraignment/plea agreement hearing on March 23, 2022. She has been charged with parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Waynick & Waynick
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers;
Additional details: Resident of TN; Son also arrested
Short narrative: Jerry McKane Waynick, along with his father, Mark Waynick, were arrested on February 17th in responce to their actions during the January 6th riot at the United States Capitol. Both Waynicks were observed on body-camera, CCTV, and cell phone video assaulting officers along the Western Front of the building. Jerry Waynick was specifically seen beating an officer with an orange traffic pilon. After breaching the police riot line, both Waynicks were seen on CCTV footage inside the Capitol building, specifically in both Senate and House wings, and in the Rotunda's Statuary hall.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental reports and releases (DOJ)

Name of case: United States of America v. Nicholas J. Lentz
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Indicted by a Bill of Information; Sentenced 5/10/22 to 36 months’ probation, including 30 days’ home detention, 100 hours of community service, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: Ex-marine, Nicholas Lentz, 41, a former cop has been arrested and charged for his role during the Capitol protests.
Source description: Charging documents, court documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Marcos Panayiotou
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of CA/NJ/PA; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Reported to be with USMC with 1st Maintenance Battalion in Camp Pendleton, CA switched from active duty to reserves February 2020; "Sentenced 11/29/22 to 14 days of intermittent incarceration, 36 months of probation, $1,500 fine, $500 restitution."
Veteran status: Former active duty and current reserve components
Short narrative: Marcos Panayiotou, 29, was arrested and charged for his role in the Capitol Protests. Investigators pulled his military records, and found drivers licenses for him from New Jersey and Florida, and learned he had been a member of the 1st Maintenance Battalion at Camp Pendleton in California until February 2020. He was released from active duty in May 2020 and enrolled as a Marine reservist.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court doumcnets, Local news aritlce

Name of case: United States of America v. Juliano Gross
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of NJ; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced - 12/9/22 to 24 months probation, 45 days home confinement, 100 hours community service,  $500 restitution"
Short narrative: Juliano Gross, from Kearny, NJ, now 28, is accused of documenting his own participation in the 1/6/21 raid on the U.S. Capital on TikTok. Gross admitted to the FBI he livestreamed the insurrection on TikTok in an effort to raise money. Court documents state that Gross also confirmed his clothing on Jan. 6, 2021: a red Trump hat and an American flag mask. Prosecutors say that a person matching that description can be seen in surveillance footage from that day as well.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Kenneth Rader
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of IA; Expressed support for QAnon; "Sentenced 9/29/22 to 90 days of incarceration, 36 months of probation, $500 restitution"
Short narrative: According to a criminal complaint filed Jan. 11, 2022. Rader told FBI agents in September 2021 that he had attended the Jan. 6, 2021 rally and walked to the Capitol grounds after hearing a "boom." He told agents he looked inside the Capitol, but never entered. However, Rader is charged with illegally entering the Capitol and spending about 3 minutes inside during the insurrection. Security footage shows Rader, dressed in a blue "Trump 2020" hoodie, entering the Capitol at 2:14 p.m. through the Senate wing door that had already been broken by protesters. A screen shot from the video shows Rader standing near the door. According to the complaint, the video shows Rader enter the building, stand near a broken window, speak with several unidentified men and then exit. In an interview with the FBI, two of Rader's relatives identified him as the person shown and in a photo taken outside the Capitol.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Local news articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Athanasios Zoyganeles
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of IL
Short narrative: Athanasios Zoyganeles was arrested for his involvement in the January 6 riot at the Unietd States Capitol after a plethora of Facebook posts and messages provided to law enforcement confirmed that Zoyganeles was inside the building. Most noteably, Zoyganeles had posted (and later deleted) a video of himself allegedly inside the Capitol rotunda saying "Hey Nazi's, we're here, where are you?". Other posts seemed to be live-reactions to what he was seeing and doing within the Capitol. He was seen extensively on CCTV footage inside and outside the building.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Heneghan & Kicinski
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of FL
Short narrative: Jon Nicholas Heneghan and Carol O'Neal Kicinski were arrested following their involvement in the January 6 riot at the United States Capitol. Heneghan and Kicinski, who are beleived to be in a relationship, were seen on CCTV footage both inside and around the Capitol building. Noteably, they were seen moving through the Rotunda and later as part of a larger group moving towards to House Chambers.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Vincent J. Gillespie
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Additional details: Resident of MA
Short narrative: Vincent Gillespie, 60, was among the rioters in the Lower West Terrace of the Capitol who engaged in pushing, shoving, yelling, and fighting with law enforcement officers. According to prosecutors, he took a police shield and used it to ram officers while shouting “traitor” and “treason." Gillespie is charged with assaulting, resisting, or impeding officers, civil disorder, engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds and related offenses.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental reports and releases (DOJ)

Name of case: United States of America v. Raechel Genco
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) and (2) Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority
Additional details:
"Sentenced 9/27/22 to 12 months of probation, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution.
"
Short narrative: Raechel Genco, 37, faces charges of knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority. She traveled from Pennsylvania to D.C. with Ryan Samsel, and she can be seen in pictures and videos from that day crossing police barricades with him. Police were tipped off to 37-year-old Raechel Genco after her boyfriend was arrested for his role in the violence in D.C.
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Mathew Capsel
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) and (4) Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; 18:111 Forcibly assaulted resisted, opposed, impeded intimidated, or interfered with any officer or employee of the US or of any agency in any branch of the US government while engaged in or on account of the performance of official duties;
Additional details: Expressed support for QAnon; "Sentenced 12/16/22 to 18 months in prison, ordered to pay restitution in the amount of $2,000 and was ordered to complete 24 months of supervised release."
Short narrative: On January 6th, 2021, Mathew Capsel, partook in breaking and entering the Capitol building. From videos posted on social media, it appears that Capsel is fighting against National Guardsmen attempting to hold the line with riot shields until he was pepper sprayed. The FBI say Capsel was recorded in a TikTok video attacking National Guardsmen as they were “attempting to hold the line with riot shields” on Jan. 6 at the U.S. Capitol. The FBI said that two witnesses, over the span of five days, came forward and identified Mathew Capsel (born in 1993) as a Capitol rioter, submitting screenshots of his “Mateo Q Capsel” Facebook profile. A Twitter profile with the name “Mathew Capsel” clearly indicates that “Mateo Q” is a reference to QAnon.
Source description: Charging Documents, News article

Name of case: United States of America v. Jeffrey Schaefer
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of DE; Sentenced 11/18/22 to 30 days of incarceration, $2,000 fine, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: Jeffrey Schaefer was first brought to attention of law enforcement by a tipster who took screenshots of his social media accounts. In one alleged post by Schaefer, he posted an image of what appears to be the inside of the U.S. Capitol, with the caption, "THE CAPITAL HAS BEEN BREACHED... IT IS FILLING UP... THEY CAN'T STOP US." The FBI was able to link a Facebook photo of Schaefer with an image from a body camera worn by a police officer at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. The FBI also obtained video from inside the Capitol in which Schaefer is allegedly seen entering the building through a broken window on the Senate side. This video suggests that he was inside the Capitol for approximately 28 minutes, the FBI said.
Source description: Charging Documents; News articles; Local news articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Lloyd Casimiro Cruz Jr.
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of MO; "Lloyd Cruz Found guilty at bench trial 1/13/23 as to Counts 1s and 2s of the Information."
Short narrative: On Jan. 3, 2021, Lloyd Casimiro Cruz Jr. drove with friends to Washington, D.C., to attend then-President Trump's rally three days later, according to court documents. On Jan. 6, Cruz watched Trump’s speech and then marched with the crowd to the U.S. Capitol, court documents indicate. He allegedly told the FBI, who interviewed him several months later, that he observed Capitol personnel remove the lower barriers so that people could walk closer to the building. He also allegedly told agents that he saw people dressed in “dark clothing,” who he assumed were antifa, pushing and removing barriers on the upper level of the Capitol. (There is no evidence that antifa played any major role in the attack on the Capitol.) Cruz told investigators that he then went to get food from a food truck and saw gas and rubber bullets being deployed on people at the upper barriers. According to court documents, Cruz's further stated that he went back onto the Capitol grounds to help anyone who might be injured, but did not enter the building. In June, the FBI interviewed Cruz voluntarily again. He allegedly stated that he recorded footage on his GoPro camera and gave the content to the FBI. The contents of the camera, in addition to security camera footage, allegedly show Cruz inside the building. The FBI interviewed Cruz three additional times and during the final interview he did confirm he was inside the building, court documents indicate. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Matthew Jason Beddingfield
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(E) Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings;
Additional details: Resident of NC; In part identifed by Huffington Post, Ryan Reilly and others and video organized by Pro Publica and Sedition Hunters
Short narrative: Matthew Beddingfield, 21, of Middlesex, North Carolina, is charged in a criminal complaint filed in the District of Columbia with assaulting, resisting, or impeding officers using a dangerous weapon or inflicting bodily injury, civil disorder, engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds, and related offenses.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental reports and releases (DOJ), Local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Joshua John Portlock
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) - Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of TN
Short narrative: "Wearing a black beanie stitched with a yellow wreath commonly associated with the Proud Boys and a white cowboy hat that referenced the Stop the Steal slogan, Joshua John Portlock allegedly shrugged when officers ordered him out of a tunnel into the U.S. Capitol building. In reply, Portlock allegedly gestured to the crowd surrounding him and said “I can’t with this." He then pleaded with officers to help a fellow rioter having a medical emergency and continued preventing police from closing doors into the Capitol building, according to the statement. Just a half-hour or so before that, FBI agents allege that Portlock pushed open metal barricades and used a large sheet of plywood to drive back a line of police officers in front of the Capitol. Portlock allegedly also joined a crowd of other protesters, chanting “heave-ho” and passing Capitol Police riot shields to other protesters in an attempt to push past officers blocking access to the tunnel into the Capitol. Portlock is a manager with Mitsubishi Motors, according to a LinkedIn page referenced in the FBI statement of facts. Court records show he was arrested on Nov. 3 in Smyrna, Tenn." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Samuel Christopher Montoya
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(E) - Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of TX; Indicted by BIll of Information
Short narrative: Samuel Christopher Montoya, 35, from San Marcos, TX was arrested and charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building, Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building, Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building,Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings, and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for his participation in the January 6, 2021 Capital riot. It has been reported that Montoya is a video editor with Infowars. On January 11 the FBI says it received a tip to the National Threat Operations Center from a family member of Montoya who said they had video proof Montoya was in the Capital. The FBI "says the video captures Montoya’s movements outside and then inside the Capitol Building until he arrives by the doors outside the Speaker’s Lobby, where it depicts the shooting of the woman publicly identified as Ashli Babbitt." (Fox 7 Austin). Montoya pled guilty on 11/7/2022 to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Source description: Charging documents, Court Documents, Local news article, Governmental reports and release (DOJ)

Name of case: United States of America v. Lucas Denney
Group affiliation: Three Percenters (III Percenters, 3%ers), Patriot Boyd of North Texas (PBONT)
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; *18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; *18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of Justice/Congress; *18:1512(k) Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; *18:1752(a)(1) and (a)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds resulting isn significant bodily injury; *18:1752(a)(2) and (a)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds resulting in significant bodily injury; *18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of TX; " Sentenced 9/28/22 to 52 months in prison, three years of supervised release, restitution to be determined at a later date by the Court."
Short narrative: In December 2020, Lucas Denney allegedly used social media and other means to recruit members to join his self-proclaimed militia group, the Patriot Boys of North Texas, as well as encourage them to travel to Washington, D.C. Court records indicate that Denney engaged in physical violence at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. Denney can allegedly be seen wearing a mask with a Joker grin printed on it, as well as a hat with the Three Percenters symbol on it. According to the FBI, he grabbed and shoved a police officer, then attempted to grab a canister of crowd-control spray from a different officer. Denney was also allegedly seen later picking up a long metal pole from the ground and swinging it at an officer. Approximately 10 minutes later, he was seen grabbing a large tube and launching it toward a line of law enforcement officers, court records indicate. As the afternoon progressed, Denney was also allegedly seen carrying a baton and swinging his arm and fist at an officer. Denney has been detained, pending further proceedings. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Cantrell, Cantrell, & Cantrell
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of IN
Short narrative: Jared Paul Cantrell, Quentin G Cantrell, and Eric Cantrell, a group of cousins from Indiana, were identified through security images from inside the Capitol on Jan 6 2020 and by witness information provided to the FBI regarding Jared Paul Cantrell’s social media posts. They have been charged with four misdemeanor counts related to entering the Capitol. They were all arrested March 10 2022.

Name of case: United States of America v. Loammi Yazdani-Isfehani, et. al.
Charges: *18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of OH; Sentenced 11/10/22 to 24 months of probation, including 100 hours of community service, $500 restitution
Short narrative: On February 18, 2022, Abigail Yazdani-Isfehani, along with her siblings Loammi and Loruhamah, was issued a complaint for entering a restricted area and protesting on Capitol grounds as a result of their presence at the January 6th riot at the United States Capitol. The siblings had traveled to DC from their Ohio home for the rally scheduled earlier in the day and were subsequently seen on CCTV and cell phone videos walking around the Capitol Rotunda and Statuary Hall. She pled guilty to the parading charge and was sentenced to 24 months of probation and community service.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents

Additional details: Resident of OH; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Identified through facial recognition; According to Statement of Facts, "Yazdani believes that the violence that occurred inside of the Capitol was caused by Antifa."; Sentenced 11/10/22 to 14 days of incarceration, followed by 24 months of probation, 100 hours of community service, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: On February 18, 2022, Loammi Yazdani-Isfehani, along with his siblings Abigail and Loruhamah, was charged via Bill of Information for entering a restricted area and protesting on Capitol grounds as a result of their presence at the January 6th riot at the United States Capitol. The siblings had traveled to DC from their Ohio home for the rally scheduled earlier in the day and were subsequently seen on CCTV and cell phone videos walking around the Capitol Rotunda and Statuary Hall. He pled guilty to the parading charge and was sentenced to 14 days in prison, 24 months of probation, and community service.

Name of case: United States of America v. Myers & Gianos
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of PA
Short narrative: Michael Gianos, 33, was linked to another South Jersey suspect who was charged in March, Lawrence Stackhouse of Blackwood. A search of Stackhouse's cell phone uncovered incriminating text exchanges with both Gianos and a Philadelphia woman, 30-year-old Rachel Myers, who also was arrested Dec. 1, authorities say. Gianos has been arrested and charged for his role in the Capitol protests.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Myers & Gianos
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of PA
Short narrative: Rachel Myers, a 30-year-old who works at Delilah’s Gentlemen’s Club in Philadelphia, was charged along with Michael Gianos, who traveled to Washington with her for the Jan. 6 insurrection, the FBI says. According to the warrant, Myers stayed in a hotel with a man named Lawrence Stackhouse, of Blackwood, N.J. Stackhouse was arrested in March after several tips from coworkers who said it was “common knowledge” he was at the Capitol and had called out of work Jan. 5 and 6 to attend. In the days after the election of President Joe Biden, Myers and Gianos texted each other expressing the belief that the election had been stolen from Donald Trump and planning a trip to Washington to stop the certification process.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Nicholas Rodean
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 18:1361 Destruction of Government Property; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) act of physical violence in the capitol grounds or building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; *405104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Charged by Bill of Information, then formally by indictment; "Found guilty 7/12/22 of the felony offense of destruction of government property, and six misdemeanor offenses, including entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a Capitol Building; engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building; committing an act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds of Capitol Building, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol Building."; "Sentenced 10/26/22 to five years of probation, including 240 days of home detention, ordered to pay $2,048 in restitution."
Short narrative: Nicholas Rodean, 26, was charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; Destruction of Government Property; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; and act of physical violence in the capitol grounds or buildingfor his role in the January 6th Capitol riot. Rodean was photographed inside the Capitol during the riot and seen in footage interacting with Capitol Police Officer. Rodean was found guilty and sentenced to five years of probation, including 240 days of home detention, ordered to pay $2,048 in restitution. He was gound guilty for one felony and various misdemeanors.
Source description: News Articles, Charging Documents, Governmental reports and release

Name of case: United States of America v. Iraj Javid
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of DC and employed by WMATA

Jarrid could be seen most noteably in the cell phone footage of the shooting the resulted in Ashli Babbits death, as he was one of those who was standing next to her. Jarrid could otherwise be seen throughout the Capitol building.

Johnson was seen through a number of cell phone and CCTV videos entering the building through a window near the Senate Chambers, and then could later be seen in the Senate Chamber itself.

Name of case: United States of America v. Nancy Barron
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of IN
Short narrative: Nancy Barron was arrested and charged on March 11, 2022 for her role in the January 6th riot at the United States Capitol. Barron could be seen through numerous CCTV and cell phone videos storming the doors along the Eastern Doors of the Rotunda. While inside the Capitol, Barron had made a number of selfie-style videos where she talked about her movements within the biuldings, including one where she could be seen asking other rioters where Speaker of the House Nacy Pelosi's office was.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Christopher W. Ortiz
Charges: *18:1752(a) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building;
Additional details: Resident of NY; "Sentenced 8/9/22 to 12 months’ probation, with the first 2 months to be served in home detention, 100 hours of community service, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Christopher W. Ortiz, 27, was charged with Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority and Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds following his participation in the Capitol raid. Ortiz posted content to his instagram story that shows his illegal entry to the Capitol. Ortiz's identity was confirmed by a tipster. Ortiz pleaded giulty on March 24, 2022.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Brian Raymond Jones & Patrick John King
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of WA
Short narrative: Brian Raymond Jones researched the marijuana laws in Washington, D.C., before traveling there to attend the pro-Trump rally on Jan. 6, 2021, according to an FBI statement of facts. After the rally, he allegedly marched to the U.S. Capitol and, with co-defendant Patrick King, then smoked marijuana inside the building, according to their middle school classmate who claimed to have seen photos on Facebook and tipped off the FBI in February of 2021. Investigators say surveillance footage shows Jones passing through the Senate Wing doors shortly after 2 p.m. and then walking through the rotunda. According to the FBI, Google records allegedly show Jones spent the evening of Jan. 6 searching phrases such as “Is it illegal to go into the Capitol” and “Unlawful entry charge,” among others. Court documents also allege that Facebook records show Jones told Facebook friends he deleted anything “political” from his account and was creating a second account for only close friends and family, as he grew anxious about getting arrested for allegedly entering the Capitol. He was arrested March 23, 2022, in Seattle. (NPR)
Source description: Court documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Brian Raymond Jones & Patrick John King
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of WA
Short narrative: Patrick John King told friends on Facebook that he “smoked weed n s***” while in the U.S. Capitol and “was part of rushing the riot police,” according to an FBI statement of facts. King also allegedly wrote to friends on Facebook that he “went to punk congress… let them know we ain’t f***ing around no more." Google records allegedly show King, similar to his co-defendant Brian Raymond Jones, spent the evening of Jan. 6, 2021, searching phrases like “Is it illegal to go into the Capitol,” “US Capitol facial recognition” and “Unlawful entry charge,” among others. A business owner near King’s home tipped off the FBI after one of King’s family members came into his business, in which a television was tuned to news coverage of the Jan. 6 riot. King’s relative allegedly told the business owner that King was “involved in that” and that he “went inside” the Capitol that day. King was arrested March 23, 2022, in Mount Vernon, Wash. (NPR)
Source description: Court documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Riley D. Kasper
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon and Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of Green Bay, WI

Kasper was arrested and charged on March 15, 2022 for a number of trespassing and assault charges relating to his participation in the January 6 insurrection at the United States Capitol. Kasper could be observed in numerous CCTC, body-cam, and cell phone video from the West Terrace at the front of the riot line. At one point he could be seen pepper-spraying a number of Capitol Police officers before retreating from the riot line. Riley was wearing a full camouflage outfit for the day, along with multiple pieces of tactical equipment

Name of case: United States of America v. Brian Glenn Bingham
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers or Employee of the United States in the Performance of their Official Duties; 18:231(a)(3) - Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) - Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating or Picketing a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of FL
Short narrative: Brian Glenn Bingham, 35, from Port Charlotte, Florida, is charged with federal offenses that include assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers; obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder; and violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds, among other charges. He allegedly pushed and grabbed an officer. He was arrested on June 23, 2021. He has ties to Florida and New Jersey.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental Reports and Release (DOJ), Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Jacob L. Zerkle
Charges: 18:111(a) Assaulting a Federal Officer; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building;

Short narrative: Jacob L. Zerkle was arrested and charged with a number of counts relating to his presence at the January 6th riot at the Unietd States Capitol. Zerkle could be seen in numberous Capitol Police officers body-cam footage assaulting officers and attempting to break through the riot line along the West Lawn. Zerkle confirmed to law enforcement upon arrest that it was him in the aformentioned body-cam footage, and admitting to physically interacting with officers
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Jake Maxwell

Name of case: United States of America v. Archer & Bonenberger
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of PA
Short narrative: Melanie Archer and Jordan Bonenberger, who are both charged, were allegedly seen together on police body and surveillance camera footage during the Jan. 6, 2021, U.S. Capitol insurrection, court records indicate. FBI agents contacted a person who had known Archer for a long time and casually knew of Bonenberger. That person was allegedly able to identify some photos of the pair outside the Capitol, but was less sure about images from inside the building. Prosecutors say the clothing and likeness of the images that allegedly show Archer and Bonenberger outside the Capitol match with images from inside the Capitol. In addition to the previously mentioned tipster, FBI agents also received information from other tipsters who knew Archer. According to those people, Archer allegedly told them she was inside the Capitol on Jan. 6. Archer declined an interview with the FBI. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Archer & Bonenberger
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of PA
Short narrative: Using police body camera and surveillance camera footage, FBI agents allegedly identified Jordan Bonenberger and Melanie Archer, who are both charged, as having been present during the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol. Multiple tipsters were also able to identity Bonenberger in images taken outside the U.S. Capitol, court documents indicate, and one tipster noted that the person the FBI identified as Bonenberger outside the Capitol was wearing the same clothes as a person captured by surveillance footage inside the building. Bonenberger initially agreed to an interview with the FBI, but declined in person. After seeing Bonenberger in person, FBI agents say they were able to confirm a match between him and images from the riot. In court, attorneys refer to Bonenberger as a member of the military, which the U.S. Marine Corps confirmed to NPR. According to a USMC spokesperson: “The Marine Corps is aware of the situation, and we will fully cooperate with federal authorities as appropriate." The spokesperson added that Bonenberger is "pending administrative separation from the Marine Corps for unrelated misconduct" and that the "administrative separation process was started prior to the indictment.” Bonenberger is a corporal and has no service deployments, according to the Marines. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. John Franklin Lammons
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of TX; Indicted by a Bill of Information
Short narrative: John Franklin Lammons was arrested and charged for his participation in the January 6th riot at the United States Capitol. Lammons, along with a friend, had traveled to the Capitol from Texas earlier in the week with the intention of participating in the planned demonstrations. As the crowd frenzied, Lammons made his way to the front of the crowd near the entrances for the Statuary Hall. Lammons conversed with police to secure the release of an injured rioted from behind the police line, and simmilarly brushed with police both in and outside the building. He was seperated from his friend for the majority of his actions, but later left the Capitol grounds with her.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Shawn Price
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:231(a)(3) -Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder;
Additional details: Resident of NJ; "Shawn Price Sentenced 4/3/23  to 12 months and one day in prison for interfering with law enforcement officers during a civil disorder, and $2,000 in restitution."
Short narrative: Shawn Price, 26, from Rockaway, New Jersey is a self-proclaimed Proud Boy, and he has held a leadership position in his chapter. He is accused of being on the "lower west terrace helping to push other individuals forward into a line of law enforcement officers" during the January 6, 2021 riot at the Capitol and has been charged with a number of federal offenses.
Source description: Charging Documents, Governmental Reports and Release (DOJ, Local News

Name of case: Unietd States of America v. Narayana C. Theiner
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of MD
Short narrative: Narayana Rheiner was arrested and charged on March 1, 2022 for entering a restricted building and other charges relating to his involvement in the January 6th riot at the United States Capitol. Rheiner could be seen in multiple body-camera and cell phone videos engaging in physical altercations with Capitol Police along the riot line on the Western Terrace, and could later be seen entering the building through the northernmost entrance on the Western Terrace.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Hand & Robinson-Hand
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Husband also arrested
Short narrative: “We’re in the capital (sic). Taking our house back … we’ve Been tear gassed etc.,” Mandy Robinson-Hand allegedly wrote in Facebook posts, which a tipster then submitted to the FBI. The FBI claims surveillance footage from the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, appears to show Robinson-Hand, formerly known as Mandy Robinson-Lanning, entering the building through the Senate wing door just before 2:30 p.m., holding her cellphone aloft. She and her husband, Charles Hand III, who is also charged, were then filmed walking hand in hand through the Capitol Visitors Center and the Crypt, court documents allege. According to an FBI statement, the video footage shows Robinson-Hand appearing to restrain her husband from advancing toward a scuffle involving police and protesters. Robinson-Hand and her husband were arrested March 11 in Butler, Ga. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Hand & Robinson-Hand
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Wife also arrested
Short narrative: Charles Hand III attended the Jan. 6, 2021, rally to “protest and stop the certification of what I personally believe to be an election stolen from the American people,” according to screenshots of his Facebook page included in an FBI statement of facts. His post also included the accusation that “Antifa sporting Trump gear were the ones who caused the chaos and who vandalized and attacked the Capitol Police," though there is no evidence suggesting antifa played any major role in the attack. According to court documents, video footage shows Hand breaking off a piece of metal fencing outside the U.S. Capitol and pocketing it in the early afternoon. More than an hour later, surveillance footage from inside the building allegedly captured Hand and his wife, Mandy Robinson-Hand, who is also charged in relation to the riot. Court documents indicate that surveillance footage shows Robinson-Hand restraining Hand at one point as he allegedly tried to move toward a scuffle between police and protesters. Hand and his wife were arrested March 11 in Butler, Ga. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents

Name of case: United States of America v. David Joseph Gietzen
Charges: 231(a)(3), and 2: Civil disorder and aiding and abetting; 111(a)(1): Assaulting, Resiting, or Impeding (3 counts); 1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(a): entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(a): engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 5104(e)(2)(f): act of physical violence in the capitol grounds or buildings;
Short narrative: On April 1, 2022, David Joseph Gietzen was indicted for his participation in the Capitol insurrection; he obstructed/interfered with a law enforcement officer, interfered/intimidated an employee of the United States, and used a pole as a deadly weapon to assault an employee of the United States, and remained in a restricted building while engaging in physical violence with a deadly weapon which was a pole.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental reports and releases (DOJ), local news article

Garcia posted about his plans to attend the demonstrations on Facebook prior to his travel to DC, and subsequently televised his expoits on the Capitol grounds through the same Facebook profile. He was seen breaching the Western Terrace entrences, and was later seen roaming the halls near the Rotunda.

Name of case: United States of America v. Jerry Daniel Braun

Braun was identified after an his Uber driver tipped him off to the FBI, saying that he bragged about his participation in the riot while in the car.

Name of case: United States of America v. Steven Miles, & Matthew Lebrun
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1361 Destruction of Government Property; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of FL
Short narrative: Steven Miles and Matthew LeBrun were both arrested and charged on April 7, 2022 for their actions during the January 6 insurrection at the United States Capitol. Steven Miles could be seen through numerous cctv and cell-phone videos along the West Terrace riot line both with and without LeBrun. The pair could later be seen smashing and breaching a window near the Senate Carriage Door before wandering the halls of the Senate Wing. Miles had also been observed in cell phone and body-camera footage shoving and hitting a Capitol Police officer
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental reports and release (DOJ)

Name of case: United States of America v. Jeffrey Munger
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of IN; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced 10/21/22 to 30 months of probation, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution."
