Jeffrey Munger, of Goshen, is facing charges of entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building and parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Eric Gerwatowski
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of NY; Identified with aid from Sedition Hunters and Twitter; "entenced 3/9/23 to 24 months’ probation, 30 days home detention, $2,000 restitution, 60 hours of community service."
Short narrative: Eric Gerwatowski, 31, was released without bond, and he is prohibited from possessing any firearms or explosives, or from traveling outside of the continental United States without the court’s permission. He is also restricted from traveling to Washington, where his case will be tried, unless required as part of his prosecution. As Capitol Police attempted to close the doors to prevent rioters from breaching the building, he yanked one open, turned to the crowd and shouted, “Let’s go!” He allegedly directed rioters inside and entered the building himself.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court docuemets, Governmental reports and release (DOJ)

Name of case: United States of America v. Matthew Montalvo
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of FL
Short narrative: "Matthew Montalvo is a real estate broker specializing in vacation home sales near Florida’s Disney World resort, according to his business website HomeSalesNearDisney.com, of which screenshots were included in an FBI statement of facts. On Jan. 6, 2021, Montalvo allegedly spent about 25 minutes walking around the U.S. Capitol’s second floor, according to the FBI statement, which includes photos from video surveillance footage that appear to show Montalvo carrying a tan backpack through the building. The FBI statement also alleges that Montalvo admitted to an FBI agent in December of 2021 that he went inside the Capitol that day. He was arrested April 26, 2022, in Kissimmee, Fla." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court docuemets

Name of case: United States of America v. Cale Douglas Clayton
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:661 Theft in a Federal Enclave; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; *18:641 Theft of government property; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of MO
Short narrative: "Cale Clayton, 41, of Drexel, Missouri, is charged in a criminal complaint filed in the District of Columbia with assaulting, resisting, or impeding officers, civil disorder, theft of government property, and related offenses. He was arrested in Drexel, Missouri...Jan. 6, as early as 2:55 p.m., Clayton was illegally on Capitol grounds, pointing his finger at officers and shouting, “We are going to win … You might spray me with pepper spray. I don’t give a f---. There ain’t enough for millions of people here and you know it.” He remained at the Capitol throughout the afternoon. From 3:20 to 3:25 p.m., he yelled and pointed at officers from beneath scaffolding at the Capitol, saying, among other things, “You guys are losing a lot of bodies” and “Get that pepper spray out … not enough.” Later, at about 4:15 p.m., Clayton was on the Upper West Terrace of the Capitol, where police officers were attempting to clear the area. While there, on two separate occasions, he grabbed a police shield being held by a law enforcement officer. He also took a police baton that was dropped by a law enforcement officer. While holding the baton, Clayton grabbed yet another officer’s shield. Police attempted to recover the baton from Clayton, and he made contact with his right hand with one of the officers. He also grabbed a police officer’s helmet in another confrontation." (DOJ OPA)
Source description: Charging Documents, Governmental reports and releases (DOJ)

Name of case: United States of America v. Roy Nelson Franklin
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of Justice/Congress and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of IL
Short narrative: Federal prosecutors say that Roy Franklin was one of the rioters that made his way to the Senate floor on the day of the riot at the U.S. Capitol. Court documents indicate that Franklin traveled to Washington, D.C., with his friend Thomas Adams Jr., who was charged in April of 2021. The criminal complaint references an article from *Insider,* published the day after the riot, that says Franklin tripped while at the bottom of the Capitol steps and fell onto an officer who he says “barely reacted.” The article reported that Franklin followed a group of people who were climbing scaffolding and entering the building through a window that was smashed. Once inside, Franklin allegedly followed people onto the floor of the Senate and observed “a shirtless man with an animal skin headdress and his face painted red, white, and blue stood at the speaker's chair, wielding a bullhorn, and flexing his biceps” who was presumably Jacob Chansley, also known as the QAnon Shaman. Months after the riot, agents say they tracked Franklin down at his house, executed a search warrant and seized gear that they claim can be seen in images of that day and in particular the footage from the Senate floor: a Trump 2020 Keep America Great flag, a plaid patterned shirt, a pair of Nike shoes and a baseball cap emblazoned with “United States of America” and a flag in the center. During the execution of the search warrant, an FBI agent alleges that he overheard a conversation between Franklin and his significant other. In the conversation, Franklin allegedly admitted that he was in the Capitol building. He also allegedly said, “You had to be there, the whole thing was fun.” (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Seefried & Seefried
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building; 18:1752(a)(4) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with physical violence against property; 18:1361 Destruction of government property; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or building
Additional details: Indicted by Bill of Information; Resident of DE; "Found guilty 6/15/22 of the felony offense of obstruction of an official proceeding, and four misdemeanor offenses, including entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a Capitol Building; disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building, and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol Building."; "Sentenced 10/24/22 to 24 months in prison, one year of supervised release, $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative: On April 7, 2021, in Washington D.C., Kevin Seefried, age 51, of Delaware; and Hunter Seefried, age 23, of Delaware, were charged with obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting that offense; entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; and parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building. Hunter Seefried was additionally charged with entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with physical violence against property; destruction of government property; and an act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or building. The two men entered the Capitol building during the January 6 riot through a window that Hunter Seefried broke open with a wooden 2 x 4. Kevin Seefried was photographed holding a Confederate battle flag. The two men were motivated by their rightist: anti-government ideology.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Release (DOJ)

Name of case: United States of America v. Ryals & Griffith
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; *18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of OK; Pleaded guilty 5/5/22; "Sentenced 10/18/22 to 9 months of incarceration, 36 months of supervised release, $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative: Jerry Ryals was charged with 18 U.S.C. § 231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; *18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; *18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following his involvement in the January 6th Capitol insurrection Ryals plead guilty on 5/5/22 to the count of Civil Disorder (following a superseding information) and sentencing information is pending. ""We reclaimed our Capitol, just to be slandered by the media," Ryals wrote on Facebook after the riot, according to the FBI. "Things are headed in the direction of a Revolutionary war against the corruption of our government. "It is our responsibility to handle this at all costs. We are not animals, we are not barbarians, we are the heart of this country and the last ones to stand up for your freedom." Ryals, an apprentice electrician, traveled to Washington D.C. with his boss, Anthony Griffith, to attend the President's rally. The FBI said both men admitted going inside the Capitol. Several witnesses identified Ryals and Griffith." (USA Today)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Governmental Reports and Releases, Local News

Jarrin left shortly after he entered the building

A second witness identified him in a photograph in a news article later posted about the attack. There are photos of Heathcote at the doors of the Capitol and one interacting with a capitol officer.

Name of case: United States of America v. William Todd Wilson
Charges: 18:2384 Seditious conspiracy; 18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of official proceeding
Additional details: Resident of NC; 3rd member of Oath Keepers to plead guilty to seditious conspiracy and agree to cooperate with the government's investigation
Short narrative: "William Todd Wilson is the third member of the Oath Keepers, an anti-government extremist group, to plead guilty to a charge of seditious conspiracy and agree to cooperate with the government's investigation into the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol. Wilson was a county-level leader of the Oath Keepers based in North Carolina, and he conspired with other members of the group to "oppose by force the lawful transfer of presidential power," according to a statement of offense Wilson signed and submitted in federal court as part of his guilty plea. In the days and weeks after the November 2020 presidential election, Wilson exchanged messages with other members of the Oath Keepers about how they believed Joe Biden had stolen the election and, as Oath Keepers leader Stewart Rhodes allegedly put it in one message, "we aren't getting through this without a civil war." On Jan. 5, 2021, Wilson drove from North Carolina to a hotel in Vienna, Va., which is near Washington, D.C., and brought with him an "AR-15-style rifle, a 9-millimeter pistol, approximately 200 rounds of ammunition, body armor, a camouflaged combat uniform, pepper spray, a large walking stick intended for use as a weapon, and a pocketknife," court documents state. Some members of the Oath Keepers allegedly remained at the hotel with a stash of weapons in order to act as a "Quick Reaction Force" that could bring arms into D.C. "in case of worst case scenarios," as Rhodes reportedly wrote in one message. On the day of the riot, Wilson breached the Capitol and helped force open doors to the building's rotunda, according to court documents. Prosecutors allege that at least 14 Oath Keepers breached the Capitol. Wilson left the building and later that evening gathered with Rhodes and other Oath Keepers at the Phoenix Park Hotel in Washington, D.C. At one point, court documents state, Rhodes called an unidentified person via speakerphone and "repeatedly implore[d] the individual to tell President Trump to call upon groups like the Oath Keepers to forcibly oppose the transfer of power." The person "denied Rhodes's request to speak directly with President Trump," according to court documents, which do not state what relationship that person may have had to Trump. Afterward, members of the group reportedly had dinner at an Olive Garden restaurant and discussed the possibility of taking further actions to fight the transfer of power. In the days after Jan. 6, Wilson deleted messages and information about the alleged plot and threw his cellphone into the Atlantic Ocean." (NPR)
Source description: Court documents, news articles, governmental reports and releases (DOJ)

Name of case: United States of America v. Matthew Joseph Buckler

Name of case: United States of America v. Logan Grover
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of CO; Indicted by a Bill of Information
Short narrative: Logan Grover, from Erie, Colorado, has been charged and arrested for his role in the Capitol protests. "In the complaint, federal authorities claim Grover was present at the Capitol on Jan. 6. The FBI got at least two anonymous tips, one of which included a screenshot of a Facebook post, that Grover had flown to Washington D.C. with the intent of marching on the Capitol. Grover faces four federal charges: Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority, Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building, Violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds, and Parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a Capitol building." - CBS
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Kyle Fitzsimons
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Using a dangerous weapon on certain officers; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers;18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
Additional details: Of Lebanon, ME, arrested 2/4/21 by FBI Maine; Spoke of 'Great Replacemnt'; "Found guilty 9/27/22, following bench trial the previous month. Fitzsimons was found guilty of seven felony charges: one count of obstruction of an official proceeding; four counts of assaulting, resisting, or impeding law enforcement officers, including two involving a dangerous weapon or bodily injury; one count of interfering with a law enforcement officer during a civil disorder, and one count of engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds. He also was found guilty of four misdemeanor charges including: entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building or grounds; and committing an act of violence in the Capitol Building or grounds." (DOJ)
Short narrative: Kyle Fitzsimons, 37, of Lebanon, Maine, was charged with Civil Disorder; Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; Using a dangerous weapon on certain officers; Inflicting Bodily Injury on Certain Officers; Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildingsfor his role in thei January 6th riot. Fitzsimons was seen on officer body camera footage assaulting officers and charging the police line. Fitzsimons pled not guilty, but was found guilty "of seven felony charges: one count of obstruction of an official proceeding; four counts of assaulting, resisting, or impeding law enforcement officers, including two involving a dangerous weapon or bodily injury; one count of interfering with a law enforcement officer during a civil disorder, and one count of engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds. He also was found guilty of four misdemeanor charges including: entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building or grounds; and committing an act of violence in the Capitol Building or grounds" (DOJ). Sentencing information for this case is still pending.
Source description: Charging documents, Court Documents, Government Press and Release (DOJ), News article

1752(a)(1): Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Ground; 1752(a)(2): Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 5104(e)(2)(D): Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 5104(e)(2)(G): Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in
a Capitol Building
Additional details: Father also arrested
Short narrative: "Matthew Bokoski and his father, Bradley, who is also charged, were inside the U.S. Capitol for about five minutes, but their time there was well-documented, court documents show. Prosecutors say Bokoski took photos and videos, including one showing his outfit, which included a red and blue “Trump 2020” flag on his back and a red and blue hat with a pompom on top. One of Bokoski’s Facebook posts, which the FBI says it uncovered through a search warrant, allegedly read “...only thing I’m guilty of is trespassing on federal property if you want to get down to it. I kept my distance from police and even thanked them for being out and making sure things don’t get insane.” Prosecutors say Bokoski confirmed his presence in the Capitol in an interview and shared photos with investigators. Bokoski also said in the interview that the rally was effective because it shut down government, court documents show. Bokoski was arrested in May of 2022." (NPR)
Source description: Charging documents, local news articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Barry Bennet Ramey
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of TX
Short narrative: "Barry Bennett Ramey was arrested...on charges of assaulting police, engaging in physical violence on Capitol grounds, entering a restricted building and civil disorder stemming from his alleged role in the Jan. 6 assault on the U.S. Capitol Building...Prosecutors allege Parler videos from Jan. 6 show Ramey spraying a U.S. Capitol Police officer in the eyes with a chemical irritant on the stairwell between the Lower West and Upper West terraces. A few seconds later, prosecutors say, the video shows Ramey spraying a second officer...During the investigation of Ramey, FBI agents in Miami allegedly learned from multiple confidential sources that Ramey was included on a master list of Proud Boys members in Southern Florida. They also determined a cellphone associated with his number had been at the U.S. Capitol Building on Jan. 6. In February, an FBI agent left his business card with an associate of Ramey’s while attempting to interview him. A day later, the agent received a call from Ramey’s attorney, who said his client had learned the agent wanted to interview him. Then, earlier this month, according to court documents, the agent received a call on his work cell phone from a person he believed to be Ramey who asked if it was him and, cryptically, “And you still live at [your affiant’s home address]?” When the agent asked who was calling, Ramey reportedly hung up immediately. A short time later, the agent said, he received a text message from the same number which included the VIN for a vehicle he’d previously owned. The agent then received a follow-up text reading, “Check that VIN number. ;).”" (WUSA)
Source description: Charging Documents, News article

Name of case: United States of America v. Thaddis Derone Johnson Jr.
Charges: 1752(a)(1): Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Ground; 1752(a)(2): Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 5104(e)(2)(D): Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 5104(e)(2)(G): Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: "Sentenced - 12/19/2022 to 24 months probation, 60 days home confinement, 60 hours community service, $500 restitution"
Short narrative: "On Jan. 8, 2021, the FBI obtained information that Thaddis Derone Johnson Jr. was at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, according to court records. The FBI interviewed Johnson shortly after, but he told the FBI he traveled to Washington, D.C., on Jan. 6 at “the request of United States President Donald Trump,” but did not enter the Capitol. In September of 2021, however, a confidential human source provided open-source video that showed Johnson near a door of the building, wearing a red “Keep America Great” hat. In addition, CCTV footage showed Johnson enter the building through the Northwest Side door and walk through the Capitol, including the Senate parliamentarian’s office. In May of 2022, the FBI interviewed Johnson again, who this time admitted entering the building and confirmed that he was indeed the man depicted in the photos taken from inside the building." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Levi Gable
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parade, Demonstrate, or Picket in any of the Capitol Buildings
Additional details: Resident of OK
Short narrative: "Gable posted about his experiences on Facebook, which an acquaintance promptly forwarded to the FBI. Gable's post stated he was among the first to make it inside the Capitol. "Capitol Police backed away from their stations and allowed protestors to make our way to the building," Gable wrote in the post. They wanted to protest Vice President Pence's statement that he would not challenge the results of the 2020 election, he said. Although his comments said the protest was peaceful, his video showed people yelling and chanting, court records show. During an interview with Gable on Jan. 21, 2021, the FBI said he repeatedly denied entering the building. However, the FBI found multiple photos of Gable in surveillance footage." (USA Today)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Jennifer Horvath
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1): Knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; *18:1751(a)(2): Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(D): Disorderly conduct on capitol grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of CO; Indicted by a Bill of Information; Sentenced 11/4/22 to 36 months of probation, including 90 days of home confinement and 14 days at a residential facility, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: On May 27, 2022, Jennifer Horvath was indicted for her participation in the Capitol insurrection; after unlawfully entering the building a video was taken of her putting a "Trump 2020" hat and sunglasses on a Winston Churchill statue. Horvath later bragged about participating in the event on Facebook where an individual tipped off the police about her participation. She was sentenced 11/4/22 to 36 months of probation, including 90 days of home confinement and 14 days at a residential facility, $500 restitution.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court Documents, local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Jamie Lynn Ferguson
Charges: 1752(a)(1): entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 1752(a)(2): disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 5104(e)(2)(D): disorderly conduct in a capitol building; 5104(e)(2)(D): Disorderly conduct in a capitol building or grounds; 5104(e)(2)(g): parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a capitol building
Additional details: Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced - 12/23/2022 to 24 months probation, 60 hours community service, $500 restitution"
Short narrative: On May 12, 2022, Jamie Lynn Ferguson was arrested for her involvement in the capitol riot. Photographs captured Ferguson circling the rotunda of the Capitol and the hallways. A Facebook post by Ferguson was found where she admitted to going to DC for the riot and inviting others to participate as well.
Source description: Charging Documents, local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Christopher Ray Grider
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Cvil disorder;18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstrcution of an official proceeding; 18:1361 Destruction of government property; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol building
Additional details: Resident of TX
Short narrative: Federal prosecutors say they first learned about Christopher Grider's alleged involvement in the Capitol riot because he gave an interview to a local TV station in Texas. "The president asked people to come and show their support. I feel like it’s the least that we can do. It’s kind of why I came from central Texas all the way to D.C.,” Grider told KWTX. Grider said he witnessed the police shooting of Ashli Babbitt, who was killed by a Capitol Police officer while trying to climb through a broken window inside the Capitol. Prosecutors allege that Grider handed his helmet to another rioter, who used the helmet to break the glass window that Babbitt then tried to climb through. Grider also allegedly "attempted to push open the doors and then kick the doors in an attempt to breach the entrance leading to House Chamber where members of Congress were located." Grider was arrested in Austin, Texas, on Jan. 21, 2021, and was indicted on multiple charges, including destruction of government property, on Jan. 26, 2021. (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Local news

Name of case: United States of America v. Georrfrey Samuel Shough
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of TX; "Geoffrey Shough Sentenced 3/22/23 to six months in prison for interfering with a law enforcement officer during a civil disorder, 12 months of supervised release, and restitution of $2,000."
Short narrative: Geoffrey Shough was arrested on March 1, 2022 and charged with entering a restricted area, civil disorder, and other charges as a result of his participation in the January 6th riot at the United States Capitol. Shough was seen on cell phone and CCTV footage clashing with police along their western riot line, and again as he forced his way through the door to the House wing. He was then seen numerous times walking around the capitol grounds, both in and outside the building. A review of Shough's financial records shows a payment of $130 make out to "Oath Keepers" on his bank records, and Shough was seen wearing an Oath Keepers patch on the back of his helmet during the riot. While it is assumed he has some affiliation with the group, it doesn't appear that he was coordinating with other Oath Keeper units during the day.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Rodney Kenneth Milstreed
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:113(a)(4) Assault by Striking, Beating or Wounding; 18:113(a)(5) Simple Assault; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of MD
Short narrative: "Federal prosecutors allege that, in the days after the 2020 election, Rodney Milstreed messaged a friend on Facebook warning that things could get "ugly" in the country, along with a photo of multiple military-style rifles, ammunition and a medical kit. On Nov. 25, 2020, court documents state, he posted on Facebook, "I pray every night. I hope we dont have to hurt anyone. THESE JUDGES BETTER DO THE RIGHT THING." On Jan. 6, 2021, Milstreed allegedly threw a flagpole "javelin-style" at a group of Capitol Police officers guarding the outside of the U.S. Capitol. Later that day, Milstreed can allegedly be seen on video trying to move bike racks that police had set up as a barricade around the building and taking a smoke grenade that was on the ground on the side of the rioters and throwing it toward police. Milstreed then allegedly pulled and shoved a photographer working for The Associated Press, who was covering that day's events. That evening, prosecutors say, he messaged a Facebook friend, "We f***** them federal cops up." Milstreed was arrested on May 24, 2022, in Brighton, Colo." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Jackson & Jackson
Charges: 231(a)(3): Civil disorder; 111(a)(1): Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officer; 1752(a)(1): entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 1752(a)(2): disorderly and disruptive conduct ina restricted building or grounds; 1752(a)(4): Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; 5104(e)(2)(F): Act of violence in the capitol grounds or buildings
Additional details: Brother also arrested
Short narrative: On June 2, 2022, Adam Lejay Jackson and Brian Scott Jackson were issued a complaint for their participation in the Capitol riot. The pair posted about their participation in the riot in a since-deleted Facebook post. They were aswell pictured inside the capitol attacking and throwing things at a line of police officers. Adam Jackson was also seen pushing police officers with a riot shield to force his way into the Capitol.

Name of case: United States of America v. Nordean et. al.
Charges: 18:2384 Seditious conspiracy; 18:1512(k) Conspiracy to obstruct an official proceeding; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding and Aiding and abetting; 18:372 Conspiracy to prevent an officer from discharging any duties; 18:231(a)(3),2 Civil disorder and Aiding and abetting; 18:1361, 2 [2 counts] Destruction of government property and Aiding and abetting; 18:111(a)(1) [2 counts] Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers
Additional details: Resident of Miami, FL; former national charman of the Proud Boys
Short narrative: Enrique Tarrio, 38, of Miami, FL, was charged with Seditious conspiracy; Conspiracy to obstruct an official proceeding; Obstruction of an official proceeding and Aiding and abetting; Conspiracy to prevent an officer from discharging any duties; Civil disorder and Aiding and abetting; two counts of Destruction of government property and Aiding and abetting; two counts Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers. Tarrio was charged with Dominic Pezzola, Ethan Nordean, Charles Joseph Donohoe, Zachary Rehl, and Joseph Randall Biggs. The five men, all members of the Proud Boys, encouraged and coordinated other Proud Boys to travel to the Capitol for the January 6 riots, entered the Capitol Building and caused damage while inside, and attempted to cover up their communications regarding their coordination. Their actions were motivated by their rightist: anti-government ideology. Tarrio has pled not guilty, the case is currently pending. [Note: Dominic Pezzola was initially charged with Michael J. Greene and William Joseph Pepe (Case ID: 04162021_MJG_PROUDBOYCAP3 and 04162021_WJP_PROUDBOYCAP2, but Pezzola was removed from the case. Pezzola was named 3/7/22 in superseding indictment for the 4PROUDBOYS case, replacing 1:21-cr-52, and named again in the supersceding indictment from 6/6/2022. Charles Donahoe is not included in the supersceding indictment from 6/6/2022, as he pled guilty earlier in the proceedings)
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, Governmental reports and releases (DOJ), News articles, Local news articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Rutledge et. al.
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of VA; Father also arrested; Indicted by a Bill of Information
Short narrative: "Meghan Rutledge and her father, William Thomas Bostic Jr., breached the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6, federal prosecutors allege. According to charging documents filed in court, investigators were tipped off to Rutledge's alleged involvement by two people who knew Rutledge and had seen her post photos to Facebook from in and around the Capitol that day. "After miles and miles of walking and climbing and climbing some more we made it inside the capitol building," Rutledge allegedly wrote. "What an experience for the books." Federal investigators also used surveillance footage to identify Rutledge among the mob inside the building, according to an FBI agent's statement of facts in the case. Those investigators also allegedly found evidence that Bostic, Rutledge's father, had communciated by phone, "with an individual who coordinated convoys, communication plans, maps and packing lists for individuals planning to participate in the events on Jan. 6,. On the packing list provided by the protest organizer, the following items were recommended: ASP baton, body armor, helmets and portable chargers." Both Rutledge and Bostic were arrested on Oct. 13." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

The indivudals were seen wondering inside and outside the Capitol, taking pictures of themselves and of other indivudals.

Name of case: United States of America v. Kash Lee Kelly
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(A) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of IL; Sentenced 11/10/22 to 70 days of incarceration, 12 months of supervised release, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: On June 7, 2022, Kash Lee Kelly, a "Trump-loving former Chicago-area Latin Kings gangster" was indicted for knowlingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority; violent entry and disorderly conduct on capitol grounds. He was indicted with 11 other members of the Latin Kings in 2017 for running a drug-dealing ring, although he avoided the racketeering charges brought against his peers. He was sentenced for the unrelated drug charges after the January 2021 protests. The charges are based on widely publicized photos, Kelly's social media, and a recorded interview in which Kelly admits to entering the Capitol. He was sentenced 11/10/22 to 60 days of incarceration, $500 in restitution.
Source description: Charging documents, News Article, Court Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. David Walls-Kaufman
Charges: 1752(a)(1): Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 1752(a)(2): Disorderly and Disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 5104(e)(2)(D): disorderly conduct in a capitol building; 5104(e)(2)(G): parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a capitol building
Short narrative: "David Walls-Kaufman came to the attention of the FBI after he was named in a civil lawsuit related to the Jan. 6, 2021 attack on the Capitol, court documents show. Screenshots used to identify Walls-Kaufman in that suit, found by the Sedition Hunters, showed Walls-Kaufman in what the FBI calls a “scuffle” with law enforcement. Prosecutors say he wore a red, white and black motorcycle jacket, which they say can also be seen in a youtube screenshot of Walls-Kaufman discussing his work as a chiropractor. Court documents say Walls-Kaufman appeared on body-worn camera footage and surveillance video, which show him inside the Capitol. Prosecutors say they were also able to confirm Walls-Kaufman’s phone number and that his cell phone used cell sites inside the Capitol. Walls-Kaufman was arrested in June of 2022." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Leticia Vilhena Ferreira
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of IL; Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced 10/6/22 to 14 days of incarceration, three years of supervised release, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: Leticia Vilhena Ferreira was arrested and charged for her role in the January 6th Capitol protests. Ferreira was observed on CCTV footage entering the Crypt of the Capitol building and partaking in the activities around that area. She had sent numerous texts, videos, and pictures from her mobile phone from within the Capitol building showing her movements and actions, and was later identified by law enforcement fromt those phone records. She is a Brazilian national who is living in the US. It is unknown if she also possesses US citizenship
Source description: Charging Documents

Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;

Short narrative: "McFadden and his fiance Carrie Ann Williams were identified after the FBI discovered Williams had been tagged in a social media post by another accused rioter, Williams’ cousin Aaron Mileur. However, Mileur told agents they were all inside the Capitol, and agents later saw them in surveillance video." (USA Today)

Name of case: United States of America v. Anthony Michael Mazzio Jr.
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;

Short narrative: Anthony Michael Mazzio Jr was arrested for his role in the January 6th riot at the United States Capitol. Mazzio could be seen on CCTV footage, and in numerous cell phone videos, entering the building near the Rotunda and lingering in the building for roughly an hour before leaving. Mazzio could be seen in these videos wearing a full camouflage outfit, complete with a black plate carrier across his chest and carried a gas mask with him.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents,

Charges: 18:371 Conspiracy; 18:1512(c)(2),2 Obstruction of an official proceeding and aiding and abetting; 18:1361, 2 Destruction of government property and aiding and abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 1512(c)(1) 2, tampering with documents or proceedings and aiding and abetting
Short narrative: On June 22, 2022, Michael Greene was indicted for his participation in the capitol insurrection. "He participated in an online meeting on Nov. 9, 2020, in which Rhodes outlined a plan to stop the lawful transfer of presidential power. Greene later was chosen by Rhodes to be an operations leader for activities on Jan. 6. Greene, Rhodes, and others made plans to bring weapons to the area to support the operation. The co-conspirators then traveled across the country to the Washington, D.C., metropolitan area in early January 2021. Between Jan. 1 and Jan. 5, 2021, according to the indictment, Greene and others transported firearms, ammunition, and related items to the Washington, D.C. metropolitan area." (DOJ Release)
Source description: Charging documents, local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Ryan Kelley
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Knowingly Engage in any Act of Physical Violence Against Person or Property in any Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1361 Willfully injure or commit any Depredation Against any Property of the United States
Additional details: Indicted by a Bill of Information; Kelley is running for Michigan governor in 2022. He also founded the American Patriot Council, a conservative org that calls for the arrest of Democratic figures in MI
Short narrative: Ryan Kelley, 40 and Michigan's Republican gubernatorial candidate, was issued a criminal complaint on June 8, 2022 for his involvement in January 6. His presence outside and inside the Capitol was corroborated by tips and CCV footage.
Source description: Charging documents, News Articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Josiah Hueso
Charges: 1752(a)(1): Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Ground; 1752(a)(2): Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 5104(e)(2)(D): Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 5104(e)(2)(G): Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Indicted by a Bill of Information
Short narrative: "“A huge group of us stormed inside … we were basically shouting at the cops,” says Josiah Hueso in CNN footage shot outside the U.S. Capitol riot on Jan. 6, 2021, according to an FBI statement of facts. A tipster who’d known Hueso for some time sent a link of the video to the FBI, adding that they’d heard Hueso “brag” about his involvement at the Capitol, according to the statement. The FBI claims surveillance footage shows Hueso entering the Senate side of the Capitol and heading into the parliamentarian office at one point. People were picking up items inside the office, Hueso later told the FBI, but he says he told them not to steal anything. He was arrested May 25, 2022, in San Diego." (NPR)
Source description: Charging documents, local news articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Pollock, et. al
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder [3 counts]; 18:111(a)(1)and(b) assaulting, resisting or impeding certain officers using a dangerous weapon. [2 counts]; 18:111(a)(1)and(2) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers and aiding and abetting; 18:641 Theft of government property [2 counts]; 18:111(a)(1) assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers [4 counts]; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly or dangerous weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds with a deadly weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) act of physical violence in the Capitol grounds or buildings
Additional details: Weapons used included flagpoles and a riot shield stolen from an officer on scene; Defendant remains at large; Resident of FL
Short narrative: On July 1, 2021, Jonathan Pollock, 21, of Lakeland, Florida, was federally charged alongside Joshua Doolin, Michael Perkins, Olivia Pollock, and Joseph Hutchinson III for their crimes in relation to the Capitol riot on January 6, 2021.Pollock allegedly charged at capitol police with a flagpole, dragged two officers down a set of stairs, kneed a police officer, punched two officers in the face, and committed other acts of assault. Pollock pushed through a metal barricade carrying flagpoles. He assaulted an officer and stole their riot shield and proceeded to slam into the police line. He assaulted multiple other officers with the shield. Pollock was indicted on charges of 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon [2 counts]; 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers [5 counts]; 18:641 - Theft of Government Property [3 counts], but still remains at large.
Source description: Charging Documents, Governmental Reports and Releases, News articles

Hutchinson alledgedly grabbed the metal barricade and pulled it back for the other rioters. He kicked a line of police officers while Jonathan Pollock grabbed a riot sheild from one of them. Hutchinson then assaulted multiple officers on the steps of the Capitol. Hutchinson has pleaded not guilty to the charges of 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 18:111(a)(1) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers [3 counts]. Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Remaining in a Restricted Building With Intent to Impede or Disrupt Official Functions; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct on the Capitol Grounds, Parading in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details:
Purchased $50K worth of firearms following Jan 6; Indicted via Bill of Information; "Hatchet Speed found guilty 3/7/23 following a bench trial
"
Short narrative: Hatchet M. Speed, born Daniel Abraham Speed, is a Petty Officer First Class in the US Naval Reserves assigned to the Naval Warfare Space Field Activity. He also worked as a defense contractor conducting "advanced analysis for the DOD" and other federal agencies. Speed is charged with his connection to the January 6 riot at the US Capitol. IN conversations with an undercover FBI agent, Speed expressed anti-government, anti-semitic positions including opposition to BLM and anti-fascists, and plans to attack members of the ADL. He praised domestic terrorist Eric Rudolph and the so-called Unabomber, and spoke of browsing Telegram as a source of radicalization. He blamed antifascists for breaching the Capitol. He claimed to have been present at the Capitol with friends who were Proud Boys, and although it does not appear he was a 'patched' member, he at times claimed affiliation with the Proud Boys.
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Robinson, et. al.
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parade, Demonstrate, or Picket in any of the Capitol Buildings
Additional details: Resident of SC, father, brother, and sister-in-law also arrested; Indicted by a Bill of Information
Short narrative: On May 16, 2022 Linwood Alan Robinson II was issued a complaint for his involvement in the Capitol riot. He and 4 other family members, 3 of which were charged with him as co-defendants, were some of the first breach the Capitol and were in the group closest to the internal House door. Photos captured from Capitol surveillance footage and a facebook post of a family gathering corroborate their identity.
Source description: Charging Documents,Court documents, Governmental reports and releases (DOJ), local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Tyler Earl Ethridge
Charges: 231(a)(3): Civil disorder; 1361: Destruction of government property; 1512(c)(2): obstruction of an official proceeding; 1752(a)(1): entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 1752(a)(2): disorderly and disruptive conduct in a  restricted building or grounds; 5104(e)(2)(D): Disorderly conduct in a Capitol Building; 5104(e)(2)(G): parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a capitol building
Short narrative: On July 7, 2022, a complaint was issued against Tyler Earl Ethridge for his participation in the Capitol insurrection. Ethridge, a pastor, was seen removing gates that barricaded the protestors from the Capitol, he was seen climbing a media scaffolding urging other rioters to move forward. He also took videos inside the rotunda and posted them to his social media after the event.
Source description: Charging documents, press release, local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Samuel Fontanez Rodriguez
Charges: 1752(a)(1): Entering and Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds; 1752(a)(2): Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 5104(e)(2)(D): Disorderly or Disruptive Conduct in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 5104(e)(2)(G): Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Indicted by a Bill of Of Information
Short narrative: On July 6, 2022, a complaint was issued against Samuel Fontanez Rodriguez for his participation in the capitol insurrection. Rodriguez was pictured in and around the Capitol building on the day of the riot. He was pictured in front of a "Black Lives Matter sign" bending down with his knee on top of the neck of another protestor, mocking the death of George Floyd. He also gave himself up to the FBI by calling them in an attempt to "clear his name".
Source description: Charging documents, local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Benard Joseph Sirr
Charges: 231(a)(3) - Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 1752(a)(4) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 5104(e)(2)(E) - Impeding Passage Through the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 5104(e)(2)(F) - Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings.
Short narrative: On June 22, 2022, a complaint was issued against Benard Joseph Sirr for his participation in the capitol riot. Surveillance from the capitol shows him assaulting, violently and repeatedly, a capitol officer while heading into the building. He was also seen on a Youtube video pushing his way into the Capitol and was pictured inside the halls of the capitol.
Source description: Charging documents, local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Luke Lints
Charges: 231(a)(3): Obstruction of law enforcement during civil disorder; 1752(a)(1)- Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 1752(a)(4): Engaging in physical violence in a restricted building or grounds; 5104 (e)(2)(E): impeding passage through the capitol grounds or buildings; 5104(e)(2)(F): Act of physical violence in the capitol grounds or buildings
Short narrative: On June 24, 20222, a complaint was issued against Luke Michael Lints for his participation in the Capitol insurrection. Lints was seen with a crowd of people fighting back against police officers trying to enter the cpaitol. He was also seen with a police riot shield pushing back against the police and used a riot shield to restrict an officer from closing a door to protect himself from the rioters.
Source description: Charging documents, local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Castle & Difrancesco
Charges: 1752(a)(1): Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds; 1752(a)(2): Disorderly and Disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds; 5104(3)(2)(D): disorderly conduct in a capitol building; 5104(e)(2)(G): parading, demonstrating, or picketing in a capitol building
Additional details: Believed sister also arrested; Indicted via Bill of Information; "Sentenced 11/22/22 to 30 months of probation, $2,000 fine, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: On May 27, 2022, a complaint was issued for Kimberly Difrancesco and Trudy Castle for their participation in the Capitol riot. A tip was sent to the FBI claiming the tipster's spouse had received pictures from an individual that appear to be taken inside the Capitol. Castle and Difrancesco were pictures wandering the halls of the Capitol as well as outside the building.
Source description: Charging documents, local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. William Stephon Kit
Charges: 1752(a)(1)- Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 1752(a)(2)- Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 5104(e)(2)(D)- Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 5104(e)(2)(G)- Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Short narrative: On July 28, 2022, a complaint was issued against William Stephon Kit for his participation in the capitol riot. Kit, also known as Seymore Views on his Youtube channel, took pictures of himself inside and outside the capitol with other rioters. He was also pictured on security footage inside the capitol building wandering the halls.
Source description: Charging documents, local news article, press release

Name of case: United States of America v. James Robinson
Charges: 1752(a)(1)- Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 1752(a)(2)- Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 5104(e)(2)(D)- Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 5104(e)(2)(G)- Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Indicted by a Bill of Information
Short narrative: On July 29, 2022, a complaint was issued against James Robinson for his particpation in the capitol insurrection. Robinson was pictured outside the capitol building with other rioters, as well as inside the capitol. He was pictured in the rotunda holding a flag and standing with other rioters.
Source description: Charging documents, local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Jarod Thomas Bargar
Charges: 1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A)- Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 5104(e)(1)(A)- Unlawful Possession of a Firearm on Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 504(a)(1) and 2502.01(a) and 2506.01(a)(3) - Unlawful possession a pistol, firearm, or ammunition outside their home or place of business, in the District of Columbia, without a valid license and registration certificate issued by the District of Columbia; 2506.01(b) - Unlawful possession, sell, or transfer any large capacity ammunition feeding device, in the District of Columbia
Short narrative: On July 29, 2022, a complaint was issued against Jerod Thomas Bargar for his participation in the capitol riot. Bargar was pictured outside the capitol with other rioters, took pictures of himself with other rioters, and posted them to his Facebook page. Bargar is also accused of bringing a firearm onto capitol grounds, which was discovered by police and conphiscated. This charge is a felony.
Source description: Charging documents, local news article, press release

Name of case: United States of America v. Antonio Lamotta
Charges: 1752(a)(1)- Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 1752(a)(2)- Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 5104(e)(2)(D)- Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 5104(e)(2)(G)- Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of VA
Short narrative: On August 8, 2022, a complaint was issued against Antonio LaMotta for his participation in the capitol insurrection. LaMotta, who was previously arrested for bringing a car full of guns to a 2020 election vote re-counting, was pictured inside the captiol on security footage as well as in the rotunda. He was also pictured outside with other rioters. His lawyers originally tried to argue he was never inside the captiol, that was prior to pictures of him in the capitol were released.
Source description: Charging documents, news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Landon Manwaring
Charges: 40:5104(e)(2)(G)) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of UT; Mother also arrested; "Sentenced 11/28/22 to 30 days of incarceration, 35 months of probation, $500 restitution."
Short narrative: On August 10, 2022, a complaint was issued against Landon Manwaring for his involvement in the Capitol raid. He is only charged with Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building.
Source description: Charging documents, Database

Name of case: United States of American v. Chilcoat & Chilcoat
Charges: 1752(a)(1)- Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 1752(a)(2)- Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 5104(e)(2)(D)- Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 5104(e)(2)(G)- Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building; 5104(e)(2)(b): Entering and remaining the gallery of congress; 1512(c)(d): obstruction or impeding any official proceeding
Additional details: Resident of OH; Wife also arrested
Short narrative: On August 10, 2022, a complaint was issued against Donald and Shawndale Chilcoat for their participation in the capitol riot. The Chilcoat's were pictures, via themselves and via security footage, outside and inside the Capitol building. They also took pictures of themselves and others on the Senate floor. Shawndale Chilcoat posted multiple times on her Facebook explaining how her and her husband had gotten in the building, posted photos of them inside the building and on the Senate floor, and as well took and posted videos of other rioters in and outside the Capitol building.

Name of case: United States of America v. Joshua Knowles
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of AZ; Has state and federal case
Short narrative: "Knowles, wearing a Trump 2020 beanie, was originally arrested by the Metropolitan Police Department for refusing to leave the Capitol grounds after refusing to do so when warnings were broadcast throughout the area. The FBI later received tips that he was inside the building during the riot, locating him on surveillance video and reading text messages with his wife after using a search warrant to seize his phone." (USA Today)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Benjamin Cole et. al.
Group affiliation: Three Percenters (III Percenters, 3%ers), Guardians of Freedom
Charges: 18:23l(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(l) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2)Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds
Additional details: Resident of FL
Short narrative: On August 16, 2022, a complaint was issued against Benjamin Cole, 38, of Leesburg, John Edward Crowley, 50, of Windermere, Brian Preller, 33, of Mount Dora, and Jonathan Rockholt, 38, of Palm Coast, and Tyler Bensch, 20, of Casselberry, Florida. All defendants are charged with the same felony charges of Civil Disorder and Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds. The first four defendants are also charged with Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds. The men all "self identify as part of “three percenters” (AKA “3%ers”, “III%ers”, or “Threepers”) based on their adherence to the sub-ideology or common belief known as Three Percenterism." These defendants "are also self-identified members of a Guardians of Freedom subgroup called B SQUAD" (DOJ Press Release).
Source description: Charging Documents, Government Releases and Reports, News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Devin Kiel Rossman
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2) (D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Indicted by a Bill of Information; "Sentenced - 12/9/22 to 36 months probation, 32 days intermittent confinement, $2,000 fine, 60 hours community service, and $500 restitution"
Short narrative: On May 16, 2022 Devin Kiel Rossman was issued a complaint for his involvement in the Capitol riot. Photographs and video surveillance show Rossman was inside the Capitol and near Nancy Pelosi's office on January 6th. Rossman also posted on Facebook on the day of the attack, sharing pictures.
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, local news article

Name of case: United States of America v. Bobby Wayne Russell
Charges: 18:111(a)(1)- Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3)- Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1)- Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2)- Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4)- Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F)- Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
Additional details: Resident of AK
Short narrative: On August 24, 2022, a complaint was issued against Bobby Wayne Russell, 48 of Arkansas for his involvement in the Capitol raid. His presence is corroborated by cell phone data and video surveillance. "According to court documents, on Jan. 6, 2021, Russell was among rioters confronting officers at a line of bicycle barricades on the southwest side of the Capitol grounds. Russell resisted police orders to move away. After he was sprayed by a police officer with a chemical irritant, Russell grabbed onto a bike rack. The barricade broke apart, and Russell pulled the jacket of a Metropolitan Police Department Officer, causing both to fall at least four steps to the ground." (DOJ Press Release)
Source description: Charging Documents, Government Releases and Reports, News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Jonathan Copeland
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) and (b)- Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon or Inflicting Bodily Injury; 18:231(a)(3)- Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1)- Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2)- Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4)- Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D)- Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G)- Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of OH
Short narrative: On August 24, 2022, a complaint was issued against Jonathan Joseph Copeland, 28 of Ohio. "According to court documents, on Jan. 6, 2021, Copeland was among rioters who illegally entered the Capitol grounds, advancing past barricades. He failed to stay back despite commands from law enforcement officers. He moved to an area near the scaffolding and joined other rioters in pushing a large, metal sign into a line of law enforcement officers. He shoved the sign into officers attempting to secure the area. He then walked into the Senate Doors and moved through areas including the Crypt and Capitol Visitor Center" (DOJ Press Release)
Source description: Charging Documents, Government Releases and Reports, News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Kellye Sorelle
Charges: 18:1512(k) Conspiracy to Obstruct an Official Proceeding; 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1512(b)(2)(A)-(B) Obstruction of Justice--Tampering with Documnents;
Additional details: Resident of TX
Short narrative: "Kellye SoRelle has worked as an attorney for the far-right anti-government militia known as the Oath Keepers, though she does not represent any of the Oath Keepers currently facing criminal charges connected to the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol. Footage taken by a documentary filmmaker on Jan. 5, 2021, shows SoRelle at a meeting in a Washington, D.C., parking garage along with Stewart Rhodes, the founder and leader of the Oath Keepers, and Enrique Tarrio, then the leader of the far-right group the Proud Boys. Both Rhodes and Tarrio have been charged with seditious conspiracy. Federal prosecutors allege that SoRelle conspired to prevent the certification of the electoral college vote on Jan. 6 and entered restricted grounds outside the U.S. Capitol. Prosecutors also allege that on Jan. 7, 2021, SoRelle "did corruptly persuade and attempted to corruptly persuade" people to withhold or destroy documents or other records that were subject to a grand jury investigation. SoRelle was arrested on Sept. 1, 2022, in Junction, Texas." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Additional details: Resident of FL
Short narrative: On September 2, 2022, Neil Ashcraft was indicted for his involvement in the Capitol riot, as well as his theft of a U.S. flag and flagpole from the Capitol grounds.

Daniel was photographed and videoed with a group of protestors shoving and pushing police officers to the ground, using barricades to pin them to the ground. Daniel was also seen charging a police officer with a deadly weapon. Joseph is videoed charing a capitol police officer and knocking them to the ground, as well as participating with other rioters to knock police officers to the ground.

Name of case: United States of America v. Salvatore Vassallo
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building;
Additional details: Resident of NJ; Indicted by a Bill of Information
Short narrative: "Vassallo hopped over a rail on to the Upper West Terrace after being denied entry by an officer at around 3:48 p.m. then was involved in an altercation as officers tried to force rioters to leave the Capitol grounds, according to charging documents. Videos show him facing off against officers, the FBI stated, then charging “seemingly unprovoked” at a Metropolitan Police Department officer as he assisted other officers and fended off rioters’ attempts to resist." (USA Today)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Mikhail Edward Slye
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds;18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;

Source description: Charging Documents, News Article, Press Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Jeremy Bertino
Charges: 18:2384 Seditious Conspiracy; 18:922(g)(1) Unlawful Possession of Firearm
Additional details: Resident of SC
Short narrative: On October 6, 2022, Jeremy Bertino was indicted with Seditious conspiracy and unlawful possession of a firearm after he was found to be planning an attack of over one hundred Proud Boys with the "Ministry of Self Defense" for several months leading up to the attack on the Capitol building on January 6th. Bertino was injured in a physical altercation in December 2020 so he did not attend the riot himself, but encouraged the group via social media while the attack was in progress.

Name of case: United States of America v. Macsen Rutledge
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Short narrative: In 2022, Macsen Rutledge was arrested and charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following his participation in the Capitol riot. Rutledge was identified via photographs as being illegally inside the Capitol building during the January 6 riot. Rutledge was able to be identified in part due to his "bear-like hood" he is seen wearing in photos and videos.

He was identified through a selfie with his wife, Julia Sizer, who was sentenced earlier this year.
Source description: Charging Documents, Local News

Name of case: United States of America v. Joseph Howe
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2) 2, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1361 2, Destruction of Government Property; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of KY
Short narrative: "According to court documents, on Jan. 6, 2021, Howe and others left a rally near the Ellipse and headed towards the U.S. Capitol. En route, Howe was recorded on a camera stating, “We’re getting into that building.” Howe was wearing a body armor-style vest underneath his outer jacket. Upon arriving near the Capitol, Howe and others illegally entered the grounds. Howe went to the front of a mob of rioters confronting law enforcement officers at bike rack barriers near the scaffolding of the northwest steps. Police officers struggled for control of barriers, and some used their batons to try to keep the rioters away. A few minutes later, Howe can be seen on video wielding a baton, similar to those used by police. By then, he also was wearing eye goggles and a gas mask...Once the police line was broken, Howe ran up the stairway toward the Upper West Terrace. As he ran up the stairs, he pushed a U.S. Capitol Police officer. Howe was among the first rioters to reach the Upper West Terrace and Senate Wing Door. He kicked the door at nearly the same time that the building was first breached by rioters. He then went inside at approximately 2:13 p.m. He moved through the building including the Crypt. In the Crypt, he verbally engaged with law enforcement officers, pushing forward through the police line. He exited the Crypt at 2:38 p.m." (DOJ Press Release)
Source description: Charging Documents, Governmental Reports and Release

Name of case: United States of America v. Gottfried & Slaughter
Charges: 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical VIolence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical VIolence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings
Additional details: Resident of Puyallup, Washington; Stepson of Richard Slaughter
Short narrative: In November, 2022, in Washington, Caden Paul Gottfried, 20, and his stepfather, Richard Slaughter, 40, were charged with an eleven count indictment following their participation in the Capitol riot. Name of case: United States of America v. Wyatt & Therres
Charges: 18:111(a) - Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers or Employees; 18:231(a)(3) - Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 18:1752(a)(1) - Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Authority; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4) - Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Violent Entry and Disorderly Conduct on Capitol Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) -Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Buildings;
Additional details: Resident of MD; Stepfather also arrested
Short narrative: "Douglas Wyatt, 49, and his stepson, Jacob Michael Therres, 25, both of Fallston, Maryland, are charged in a criminal complaint filed in the District of Columbia with assaulting, resisting, or impeding officers, and interfering with law enforcement officers during a civil disorder, both felonies, and five related misdemeanor offenses. They were arrested on Nov. 14, 2022...According to court documents, on the afternoon of Jan. 6, 2021, Wyatt was involved in multiple assaults of law enforcement officers with a chemical spray on the Lower West Terrace of the Capitol. He also shouted numerous obscenities at officers and helped pull away another rioter’s flag from an officer who attempted to grab it. Wyatt also handed a long, heavy plank to Therres, who used it to strike an officer in the head. The officer has experienced lingering medical effects from the blow to the head. Therres also sprayed a chemical irritant towards a line of officers." (DOJ press release)
Source description: Charging Documents
